description:
Great hole in the wall place with large portions! We ended up ordering one item per person  (group of 4) and probably went home with a pound or two of food left. 

Kung pao shrimp was flavorful and had the right amount of spice. We also tried the house chow mein, house fried rice and shrimp chow mein. All in all tasty food.
author: Kathya C.

description:
Sam Wo is a family-owned business that's been running for over 100 years and has a deep history rooted in SF Chinatown. I've heard all about Sam Wo for decades but haven't visited until recently. 

Maybe it's the hype, maybe it's the press, maybe it's the reopening, but I had pretty high expectations for Sam Wo. Unfortunately, everything came up short. 

BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll - one of the, if not the, most popular dish here. The rice noodle was thick and hard. The BBQ pork was bland and dry. Ask for mustard, hot sauce, or soy sauce to give this some flavor. 

Fish Jook - some people like their porridge super watery while others like it thick, to each their own. I actually like the consistency of the porridge here since it's between the two. However, for a Fish Jook, the fish is supposed to be the star of dish and it wasn't very fresh so it came out very bland. 

Beef Stew Noodle Soup - beef was tender and noodles had the right chewiness to it. Although the broth could be a bit richer, this dish always hits the spot. 

Duck Chow Mai Fun - more like lo mai fun instead of chow mai fun, but I think it tastes better this way. The sauce gives the noodles a nice savory and fragrant aroma to it.
author: Nancy C.

description:
More a 3.5 but maybe because of all the hype around this place I felt a little let down. Or maybe I didn't order the right food but I got a bowl of beef brisket and wonton with egg noodles in soup and a Hong Kong milk tea. 

The milk tea was very disappointing. Very bland, not strong for a supposed Hong Kong milk tea. Maybe if I ever go back I will ask for it to be stronger. 

The noodles were just ok. The soup was ok and they give you a decent amount of wontons and noodles for the price ($8.25). The beef brisket was on the fattier side.

Fyi, I arrived at around 2:30pm on a Saturday and they were busy but not packed.
author: Chung H.

description:
So disappointing. I'm sorry to say, but all of our four different dishes lacked flavor and tasted the same. Very underwhelming. Chicken Broccoli, Mongolian Beef, Barbecue Pork Rice and Veggie Chow Fun.

We expected a lot more from the reviews and being so close to Chinatown. Maybe it was a bad day for them. I don't know. But I wouldn't order again to be honestly speaking.

When you are hungry, you only have five bites and get rid off the rest. This was our Sam Wu experience unfortunately.
author: David R.

description:
It's a no for Sam Wo. It's not up to par with other Chinese food restaurants. The food was edible and the service was friendly. But no. We ordered three items:

Bbq Noodle Roll Appetizer: it's just that, a chewy bland flavored roll filled with bbq pork.

House Won Ton: the won ton were ok, broth was bland. Meat was mediocre at best.

House Chow Fun: this was probably the best of the entrees. But compared to other restaurants it's below standard.

For whatever reason this place was pretty busy and I guess it's popular for the late night crowd. But if I were up at 2am, I'd probably hit up Jack in a Box before I come back to Sam Wo.
author: Michael L.

description:
This place gets packed! There was already a line forming before the place even opened. Glad we came early, got in line and waited for just a bit for the place to open. It isn't that big of a place, few seatings downstairs and a few upstairs. By the time we walked in, the seats downstairs were taken so we went up and were seated.

Food:
-duck dry mixed noddles: was just alright, I wouldn't order again.
-pork chow mein: good, would order again
-Chinese broccoli- recommend it
-chicken fried rice: good, recommend it

Gets packed so get here early, variety of things on the menu to try.
author: Yukta R.

description:
Overall - great flavors & quantity for the price. I came right at opening, but I wouldn't wait in line to eat here. Nothing special tbh, but the restaurant has a deep history, which makes it a tourist scene for most.

Pros - the house fried rice was really well made. Not overly greasy, good amount of meat, and pan fried to the right level. The price is also very affordable (every entree should be $10-12 mostly) given that it's a well known tourist spot.

Cons - if you want the rice rolls, go with bbq pork. We ordered the shrimp and it barely had any shrimp inside. It was filled mostly with pan fried bean sprouts and it kept on "sweating" and made the dish very wet. Would not recommend.
author: Jaesung J.

description:
I had dinner here with a good friend while in town for work. This was my second time coming here. I'd had lunch here about a year ago on a previous trip to the Bay and remember it being much better the first time. 

It's not a very large place, but they have a few more tables upstairs. They put us at a small table for 2 people but then told us to move to a bigger table after we ordered because we ordered so much food. 

We started with the chicken wings, bbq pork roll and my friend wanted spring rolls. The spring rolls are only ok. The chicken wings were better the last time we came - they were only ok this time. They could've been crispier and were lacking salt. The bbq pork roll was good both times. 

For mains, we ordered the house chow fun, chicken chow mein, fried rice and string beans. The chow fun was ok, but lacked flavor. The meat was kind of undercooked and the noodles were all sticking together. 

The string beans were good and the fried rice was a bit bland. They went well together though. Overall this meal was disappointing in comparison to my previous memory but still fine overall.
author: Ashtar B.

description:
The short: enjoyed the jook

I arrived here a little bit before 6 pm on a Wednesday. At first, I thought the restaurant had closed, but then I realized they open the gates promptly at 6. My friend and I were the first ones in so we got a choice of tables! (There's also upstairs seating.) 

We ordered:
+ Pork and preserved egg jook: really good. Jook/congee is comfort food for me, and I really like preserved eggs, so this was a solid dish in my book. The jook was lightly flavored and piping hot.
- BBQ pork chow mai fun: I wasn't a fan of the bbq pork in here. It could use a little more juiciness and flavor.

The service was solid and they renovated the place so it does look very modern and clean.

Before heading to this place, I read other Yelpers' reviews that this place has bland food. Not so. I confirmed with the manager that this is a Cantonese style restaurant. That means that Cantonese food will not have strong flavors such as Sichuan style food.

Verdict: would come back for the jook (congee)
author: Catherine W.

description:
My fiancé and I knew we had to eat in Chinatown while visiting in SF, and we came to Sam Wo off a local's recommendation. She was right, it didn't disappoint! I wouldn't say the servers were super friendly or anything, but they were very busy and kept our food coming out fast, which is what matters :) 

We had the BBQ Pork Noodle Roll, Kung Pao Shrimp, and Sweet and Sour Pork to share for lunch. The portions were really good, it was definitely enough for the two of us! The Noodle Roll was really good, especially the filling. We had never had anything like that before, so it was fun to try. 

The other two entrees were really good as well, exactly what you would expect! Definitely a good stop in Chinatown, especially if you don't want to walk all the way up the hill on Clay Street lol.
author: Ashley D.

description:
Came here on Friday at lunchtime, and the wait was only about 10 minutes. The service was fast and super attentive, which is unusual for me at a Chinese restaurant. I found the food to be mediocre and not authentic, although the prices were extremely good for the portions.

BBQ Pork Noodle Roll ($6.50) - I loved how chewy the noodle roll was, but the BBQ pork was extremely subpar for me. It was dry and tough, with little flavor.

BBQ Pork Wonton Soup ($7.25) - The BBQ pork was once again dry/tough/lacking flavor, but the wontons were awesome since they had a delicious filling. The broth was pretty oily and didn't have too much falvor, which was also disappointing.

I would hit this restaurant up again if I was looking for a cheap, filling meal in Chinatown. Other than that, however, I don't this spot lives up to all the hype.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
Yes, service is generally pretty bad. But the food is delicious, and the prices are AMAZING. 

The bbq pork rice rolls are a staple, we always order it when we come. Then the string beans, I like them because they taste like home, but they aren't for everyone. Their rice and noodle dishes are generally pretty standard if a little stingy on the meat (what did you expect w/ their prices). And yes, last time I was there, they tried to serve us a beer that was half split. What can you do, it's a Chinese restaurant. 

Overall, I'll be back, likely with a bunch of friends in tow.
author: Sophie W.

description:
The wait here was around 20 minutes at 7pm on a Friday with a group of 5. We came bc it was known as the oldest restaurant in Chinatown. We ordered chicken with string beans, bbq pork rice rolls, Mapo tofu, and House chow fun. Our vegetarian friend got veggie fried rice and veggie chow mein. 

Get the bbq rolls. They're sooo flavorful and cheap. Dip it in the spicy red sauce and you'll be in heaven.

String beans were good too! The mapo tofu had a lot of
Flavor but wayyyy too salty. I wouldn't order again or would order it over rice next time. House chow fun was good but nothing special. A bit under salted but again that's where that spicy sauce comes in. 

Would I come out of my way to try this? No it's just Chinese food. But it was definitely better than other places I've tried
author: Lydia A.

description: This place is 100  years old. It's a San Francisco landmark in heart of San Francisco Chinatown. It's been acknowledged by city and state governments. I was ready to experience some of San Francisco finest Chinese food. I had the Duck Fried rice and it was delicious. I also had the Wonton soup with noodle and it was tasty. My favorite was the house chowmein and was the best I had ever. No sprouts the way it should be with chowmein. The restaurant had lots pictures with lots of famous people.
author: Juan V.

description: Love at first bite! I officially LOVE Sam Wo Restaurant! My wife used to frequent the original location, and would rant and rave about the food in general, especially the BBQ pork rice noodle rolls. So, fast forward several years, here we are. The food was delicious! Of course we ordered the BBQ pork rice noodle rolls, Spring rolls, and Beef Chow Fun. The service was attentive, friendly, and quick. It is a very casual spot, and their can be a wait, but worth every second. We will definitely be coming back.
author: Jenn M.

description:
I've been here three times - twice for lunch, once for late night takeout. 

The food is decent. I really appreciated how clean everything tasted - usually Chinese food makes you feel like you took about 5 straight shots of canola oil, so this was a nice change. There are definitely menu items that you should and shouldn't order; the wonton noodle soup, porridge, and rice plates are great, whereas stuff like ma po tofu was just so-so. I like my ma po tofu to set fire to my tongue and then taser it after leaving it numb, but the one I had here was all bark but no bite.

The history of the place is pretty cool, having been open for over 100 years now. The place is pretty nicely renovated and clean, which is pretty rare for almost any joint in Chinatown. 

I feel like you get better service if you can speak Cantonese. I spoke Mandarin and the service was good, probably a tier below speaking Cantonese, but when my friend ordered in English, the service almost felt rude. But that's okay - you can be as rude as you want as long as my food is good. I'm here to eat, not to be told how handsome I am.
author: Calvin Z.

description:
"There comes a time when the world gets quiet and the only thing left is your own heart..."

Deja Vu all over again. Sam Wo is legendary for being known as San Francisco's oldest restaurant. No official records exists, but historians date this "Hong Kong" style eatery back to around the great San Francisco quake of 1906. The earliest surviving photo of this historic restaurant dates to 1912, and the aged restaurant already looked old! I've been here before, well maybe not in 1906 silly, but back with the ex, pre-yelp days, and at the original location. Ohhh boy, the old location was like eating in a dungeon, and if you were lucky, or unlucky enough, you were served by the honorary Edsel Ford Fong aka "World's Rudest Waiter". Sadly he passed away decades ago, but his notorious ways are what urban legends are made of. Today many imitators and knock offs try to capture his sarcasm, but Edsel Ford Fong was an original and that will never be replaced. His "rude waiter" style was so over the top that it was more like a hilarious episode of Seinfeld. Yet, there was still a reclusive charm about him... and a restaurant called Sam Wo. 

Last night I was feeling a bit nostalgic so decided to drop in to Sam Wo. Realize much has changed since a decade ago... a move down the road, the wife left me for another woman, and the prices oh the prices have caught up with the times. Yet, it was no turning back, son. The "new" Sam Wo is much bigger than the dungeon-ish old location, but it's actually still in an older building. And ironically it still has that rickety old steps to the second floor. 

I enter with no fanfare and there's no spirit of Edsel Ford Fong anywhere. It's a new restaurant with the old menu and a story of once was... but hey, it's okay and times must go on. I did find many framed photos and newspaper clippings of the old location on the walls everywhere, so that was a nice touch. 

I settle in and order the famous Won Ton Soup (w/ the BBQ Pork) and a side of Spring Rolls. Hot Tea is a must, unless you go the alcohol route. It was crowded, but a managed chaos of patrons. A mixture of local Asians, European tourists, and San Franciscans just clinging on to the old story. And before you know it... my dinner is served in your typical Chinatown ware. Yes, please. The Spring Rolls were nice and crisp. The Won Ton Soup was also a win... except I'd pass on the BBQ Pork topping next time. The Chinese Tea complimented the meal like always. My neighboring tables were doing entree family style, and those meals looked darn good too, albeit pricier. 

In the end, I'd recommend Sam Wo, but with a disclaimer attached - don't expect the Sam Wo of the past and expect prices of today, tbh I thought the entree prices were a bit steep for a Cantonese casual style restaurant. Yet, even though the legend of Sam Wo probably died a little with the passing of Edsel Ford Fong, his spirit is still here, I guess, maybe in the popular rice noodle appetizer? Time always moves on and the next generation will never experience the "world's rudest waiter", he was certainly original and in a funky century old building made this even more of a urban legend.
author: Eric R.

description: A big disappointment! Perhaps reading all the good reviews made me believe there is a lot more about this place. A house special fried rice which needed a pile of soy sauce and chili paste for it to taste. Kung pao chicken which was so underwhelming I did not know what to make of it. Sesame chicken that were dried out and tasted like cardboard. Lastly a steam fish with bok choy that needed more salt and pepper to taste. If this place was famous then the previous cooks are no longer around.
author: Monette M.

description: We came here because I wanted Singapore noodles sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo badly. I am very glad to have popped by here. First, we sit down and got a free beer (Tiger beer reps were there offering it... Not through Sam Wo).. then we order a BBQ pork roll, Singapore noodles, and mapo tofu which came out wicked fast even though they were super busy. We showed up 30 min after they opened and the place was already packed and the food still came out quick! It was great! The Singapore noodles were everything I wanted, the mapo tofu was nice and spicy (the tofu melted in your mouth), and the BBQ pork roll was delicious (first time I've had this). I would recommend this restaurant to anyone visiting the area.
author: Rhianna M.

description: Incredible Chinese food and reasonable prices. Servings are enormous, so plan to have left-overs or share!! Highly recommend the House Chow Fun!
author: Jenn P.

description: Solid place to drop by in SF Chinatown for a reasonably priced and well-portioned meal. Their beef chow fun is tasty, enough sauce and seasoning to avoid being bland yet without being overly liquid. Serving size is fairly big (see photo). Staff was friendly and wait was short. Good for an easy meal!
author: Philippe D.

description:
Sam Wo Restaurant is located in San Francisco Chinatown.

I had planned to visit this place when it reopened.  The staff was attentive and friendly as I got a table.  I was handed a menu and a pot of Hot Tea.

After a quick look, I ordered the Scrambled Egg with Beef over Rice Plate.  While waiting, I took in the surroundings.  I was seated on the first floor.  I'll have to sit upstairs next time.

After a quick wait, my food was ready.  It was the ultimate comfort food -- tasty and filling.

I returned later that evening for a quick bathroom visit -- I'll have to try their late night menu next time.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Whenever someone mentions Sam Wo, it takes me back to my late teens in the late 80's and early 90's as the "Go to place" for late, late, late night dining. It was definitely one of the spots to go to for people getting out of the clubs and are starvin' for some nourishment after some booty-shakin' sessions. 

My friends first introduced me to this establishment when we were "hanging around" at 2 o'clock in the morning hungry for some late night grub. They ordered the scrambled egg with shrimp over rice and this has been like one of my comfort food since then. The difference between other places is they cooked the eggs runny, which is just the way I like it. I would sprinkle some pepper with a dash of soy sauce and mix it all up with the rice and it was heaven in my mouth. Yeah, it probably wasn't the best Chinese food I've ever had, but it was always the most delicious thing I've ever had at 3 o'clock in the morning. 

The original location was on Washington Street, and claimed to be the oldest Chinese Restaurant in Chinatown as the records dates back to 1907, a year after the Great Earthquake in 1906. Back when we would frequent this place, there was a waiter on the 2nd floor we called "Lee" and although not as famous as Edsel Ford Fung (AKA "World's Rudest Waiter), he certainly had his moments. I don't even know if his name was Lee since he never corrected us. My friends called him Lee, so I just rolled with it. 

As the years passed and my party days were over, I did take my family here several times on rare occasions until Lee wasn't there anymore. I would always have a craving for the scrambled egg with shrimp dish and it never disappointed me. Then when they closed in 2012 due to health reasons, we thought that was the end of an era. 

Fast forward to present day and this was my first visit in probably over ten  years. Although in a different location, just a block away, it still recaptures that essence of the original location. And the server we had was so very nice, a far different time and era has indeed begun. 

The new menu is certainly different and more expansive than the previous place, but they still offered the runny scrambled egg with shrimp over rice. Although it didn't taste exactly the same as I remember it, it was close enough to bring me a little bit of joy with a slight tear in my eye. All the memories and experiences we've had at Sam Wo came out like a floodgate. We've witnessed so many things (good, bad and weird) that I can probably write a whole novel on this restaurant alone with different chapters, I kid you not. 

Is it the best Chinese food out there? No, and far from it. But it holds a special place in my heart full of nostalgia from a different era of San Francisco that I miss. Or maybe the friend that I lost too early, who introduced me to this place at a young age, who was probably smiling from above as we stepped back in time just to catch a glimpse of yesterday.
author: John G.

description: My group ordered the bbq pork rice rolls, fish congee, pork and liver congee, and beef stew wonton noodles for breakfast. The bbq pork rice roll and the beef stew were the standouts. The wontons in the noodle soup and the two congees were average. I would only recommend the bbq rice rolls.
author: Marie S.

description:
Known as one of the oldest Chinese restaurants still in operation in Chinatown as well as a restaurant that used to be known for having the worst service ever, Sam Woo is a place that my boyfriend insisted that I try at least once, even though he was born and raised in Chinatown and says it's only OK. So away we went for an evening. We got seating immediately because it was the later part of the evening and it felt completely crammed full of tourists and non-Chinese people. That's a good sign for a Chinese restaurant.
The food is slightly more expensive than other Chinese food and while I won't say it sucked, I can't say it was amazing. It was merely OK. I think my favorite part was that they took credit card, something that not a lot of Chinese places take. Would I come back? I would never suggest it, but if someone else wanted to come here, I suppose I could.
author: Jenn T.

description:
My first visit to the new location. Been eating at Sam Wo on visits to San Francisco since 1987. I got off the plane and went straight to Sam Wo  I was not disappointed. At 2 PM on a weekend, there was a ten minute wait to get in. 

They now take credit cards. The waiter was nice to me and kept my water full. The food was the same. Larger portions than most Chinatown restaurants. Prices were a bit higher than they were at the old location. Fried rice was very good. (4 stars). I had two Chinese doughnuts. It was enough for four people. Had too much. The Chinese doughnut is a special dish at Sam Wo. It is only $1. for a portion big enough for two people. Always ask for sugar, to coat each piece of doughnut with. They are excellent! Five stars. Never found anything like them, anywhere. 

Saw a steady stream of people coming in at such a late hour for lunch. A good sign. Less quaint than the old location. You do not walk through the middle of the kitchen and up a steep flight of stairs to get to the dining room. Also, menus used to be taped to the wall, in English and Chinese for the waiters. You pointed to what you liked and they understood, because they could not speak English. That is not the case any more. No skylight on the first floor, with artificial light to enhance the sunlight.  The street is quieter than Washington Street, as well.There is no more sharing of tables when they get busy. Now you put your name on a list, but you will not share a long marble table with strangers. 

They now sell beer. And prices are higher, but very reasonable.
author: Steven G.

description:
This place was recommended to me by colleague. Hands down, the best chow mein I have ever had.
It was super fresh and even though the portion was huge, I finished all of it. The place is very small but I went around 3 pm on Wednesday so there were plenty of empty tables. 
Everyone working there were super friendly and sweet!!! 
Overall, it is a fast and cheap meal! Definitely a must try while in San Francisco.
author: Irina R.

description:
I have been to Chinatown many times since I was a kid so I can't give a good enough explanation as to why I haven't dined at Sam Wo's before. Their location on Clay Street is conveniently next to the Portsmouth Garage right in the heart of SF Chinatown. When you walk in you need to write your name and number of people in your party on the waitlist. I thought I had to wait a long time until I realized they have a second floor with more tables.

I dined in on my lunch break and had an appetite. I ordered:

-Chicken chook(porridge) 
-Chinese donut
-Bbq pork rice roll

Everything was delicious and authentic. The chook had big slices of chicken and the thickness was just right. The pieces of Chinese donuts made it even more enjoyable to eat. Their bbq pork rice rolls are famous here and a must try. I had some pieces before the chook came out and they were very tasty. It comes with some spicy mustard if you're in the mood for a kick. 

My server didn't say much, but assisted me when I needed something. It's a great spot for lunch or dinner. I'm going to order their beef chow fun next time and bring my family and friends along with me.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I came with a small group of tourists to check out this restaurant in Chinatown as recommended by our tour guide. We arrived around late noon and there was a small line.  The restaurant appeared very small with limited seats.  It didn't look like it would accommodate large groups so our group split up and we sat at different tables.

I ordered a noodle dish with pork and it was absolutely hearty and delicious. I was hungry and cold and the dish resolved both issues, LOL. Our table ordered the BBQ pork noodle roll which was just okay to me. I enjoyed my noodle dish a lot more.

The staff were friendly and they could definitely use more help to speed up the wait time on the line. Thankfully we didnt have to wait a long time for the food. It was impressive that this restaurant has been around for over 100 years and the food was still tasty.
author: Teresa S.

description:
Honestly, I am shocked by the number of positive reviews of this place. This was such a disappointing meal...I don't even know where to begin. I guess I should have known from the demographics of the clientele when we walked in that this was more a tourist trap than any semblance of an authentic Chinese restaurant.

First of all, the BBQ pork fresh rice rolls were NOT incredible like everyone else describes. The pork felt grainy in my mouth...like it was old and overcooked. It wasn't especially flavorful either and I suppose the spicy mustard was alright...but it's not like I've never had that flavor before in my life. I will say though that this was the most edible dish that we ate. 

We also ordered the duck chow foon which was extremely bland and the beef stew which really should be named beef tendon stew because almost all of the pieces of "meat" were actually tendon. I'm a fan of tendon...but I like a good 1:1 ratio of meat to tendon at least. There really was not much to say of the flavor either...it didn't seem particularly "beef"-y.

Really, a hard pass on this restaurant.
author: Jess Y.

description: Fabulous hole in the wall with amazing and authentic food. The duck fried rice was to die for and the sweet and sour chicken was the best I ever had. Highly recommend.
author: Beth M.

description:
Plenty of options - Noodles, soup, chow rice and rice plates.  
Price is ~$10

Highlights
- The Beef noodle is really good.  Tons of soft/tender meat.  It is one of the best I have had.  Our waitress even offer for more soup if we want. 
- Beef Chow Fan - Just ok. 

Decor- small /narrow little restaurant.

Kids friendly- It is a small little place.  I think they 

GF friendly- soy sauce in general is not GF.   You can get the rice noodle but ask them to skip the soy sauce.   Please do ask if their rice noodle has flour.
author: May Y.

description:
This place was as good as Chinese food gets, but don't make the same mistake that I did and take table number 8. I don't have a problem with being next to the bathroom but that was too close and at one point the back door opened sending cold wind into my side forcing me to put my sweater on. 

The food was so good from the chicken fried rice to the beef chow mein to the spicy Mongolian beef. I was more than satisfied with how quickly everything came out including our chicken dumplings. Next time I go, ill try to sit upstairs like the people who we met on our way in did.
author: Rudy M.

description:
Sam Wo is famous among tourists because of the rude service...look it up for more info. 

They even have merchandize like t-shirts you can buy. The lady up front was nice and they were busy. The food was just so so. The Chinese donut was cold, spring rolls and hte chicken rice noodles were all just OK.
author: Sunil R.

description: Don't see the hype for this place. Yes they're open until 3am, but their food reflects that. Bland at best. I do love the hole in the wall feel, but it's missing the hole in the wall flavor. Staff was friendly, and there was about a 15-20 minutes wait. There's a kiosk inside to check in (very helpful), and even a live wait time on yelp! Wouldn't come here again, even if a friend wanted to try it. Strong pass in my book. Too many other Chinese food options in SF to come here again.
author: Quoc K.

description:
I'm a little disappointed in this little place. The food was okay, the service and ambience as expected.. but there's so much hype about the rice rolls here that I was expecting to LOVE it. 
I ordered a shrimp roll and it was.. fine. Fairly filling, but definitely needed the sauce (it's a spicy mustard). I kinda wish I'd gone for my usual egg and shrimp over rice.. serves me right for being a sheep!
author: Poppy C.

description: Will give this restaurant a 5 star because it exceeded our expectations. We came there 15 mins before the opening time. We thought it's just a normal size servings but then we were very happy with what they served (because we came from San Diego and we were really starving) And the serving time is fast too.
author: Maan F.

description:
I've been twice, and I think Sam Wo is great for lighter Chinese fair.  I particularly like that the portions are fairly large and have cheap prices, especially in comparison to most SF places.  My favorite dish is the BBQ Pork Noodle Roll.  I really like the thick rice wrapping and the mustard sauce.  It probably has horse radish so it feels like wasabi.  
I also like the 油条（chinese donut), but that's mostly cause I don't get to have it very often.  I think everything is pretty good, and the flavors are fairly light so you can soy sauce or the chili sauce if you want more of a kick.  I also really like that they open late because it was fun to go with friends at midnight.
author: Darren Y.

description:
This century-old place surely doesn't disappoint. The six of us got seated upstairs and ordered
- Beef noodle: a must 
- Beef soup noodles: same as above, different noodles
- Shrimp fried rice: you can actually see each rice which shows the high level of cooking skills
- Mixed fried rice
- Curry BBQ pork noodles: it was OK. I was being exploring and wished I ordered beef noodles
- Duck dry noodles: very good 
- BBQ pork rice crepe: OK but seems like a must for every table 

I love the duck dry noodles the best, and the beef noodle soup is a must! There were tons of beef and tendons and you cannot miss it!

Service was great too!
author: Sunny X.

description: My friend recommended my family try R&G Lounge for dinner while visiting SF but we didn't expect there to be such a long wait on a weekday so we went around the corner to try this place instead. There was also a wait here but it didn't seem as long so we stuck around. They have a cool photo booth screen at the front for you to take photos and send to yourself so that definitely helped pass the time. There's also a park across the street for kids, which is great. We did have wait quite a while for our party of 7 but when we were finally seated, we of course over-ordered and got way too much food. Coming from NYC, everything was just ok for us but one interesting difference is how the congee here is made differently with bigger chunks of rice in a more watery consistency. It was cool to eat at what's dubbed the oldest restaurant in Chinatown.
author: Brietta Y.

description:
Was craving some noodle soup to help cure my hangover and figured that it would be a good time to visit Sam Wo since I haven't visited since the renovation. The food was bland and I left the restaurant feeling disappointed and not satisfied. 

Ordered the Wonton Noodle Soup, Combination Chow Fun, BBQ Spring Roll, and String Beans. The wonton noodles was bland, chow fun noodles tasted burnt and tasteless, and string beans still tasted raw and undercooked. The only dish I enjoyed here was the signature BBQ Spring Roll with the spicy mustard sauce.

The only positive thing about this place is the friendly service and the fact that this restaurant accepts credit card. I wouldn't recommend eating here for authentic Chinese food since there are plenty of other options in Chinatown.
author: MyTien P.

description:
Made a wrong turn and ended up in San Fran. 

Me and hubs were looking for awesome Chinese food. This was everything we were looking for an more. 

We order duck fried rice and shrimp fried rice along with duck chow mai fun and wonton soup. 

Service was great! We were there for lunch around 12:30. We got the last available table. :)

Highly recommend this place. Some of the Best Chinese I've had  in years
author: Elyse D.

description:
I went to Sam Wo for lunch during the week and it did not disappoint. I was feeling a little under the weather and wanted a nice hearty soup. I was seated quickly and a very nice waitress came over with some hot tea and menus. 

I ordered their bbq pork and wonton noodle soup. It did not disappoint! The bbq pork was nice and flavorful and the amount of pork was just right. The wontons were fresh tasting and filled with a nice big shrimp and pork meat. The broth was very flavorful and I did not feel the need to add any chili oil to it for extra flavor. The extra noodles at the bottom of the bowl made the soup super filling. 

I was able to check out other dishes while I was waiting on my soup and I definitely can't wait to go back to try the fried rice and other dishes.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I think it's a solid choice if you're in Chinatown and you don't know where to go. It's a cramped space but it's clean, modern and has a charm to it.

The food ranged from alright to good. Generally I'd say that it's Cantonese food that skews on the bland side. One complaint I have is that nothing was served particularly hot. I like my Chinese food steaming!

The Pork Rice noodle roll is good but served cold FYI. It had a good flavor and was stuffed with a good amount of pork, but the coldness threw me off a bit.

The chicken wings and Beef stew with mixed noodles were the best things we ordered. Chicken wings were crispy. Beef stew was tender and had a good savory flavor.

I'd skip:
-MAPO TOFU: typically not a good idea to order a Sichuan dish at a Cantonese place. There was a strong sourness coming from Sichuan pickled vegetable which felt out of place. No mala flavor either.

-Duck Chow Mein: it wasn't served hot. It also didn't have the wok hei flavor that I seek out of a dish of fried noodles. It tasted like it was cooked out of a nonstick skillet over low heat. Also too greasy.

The girl serving us was SO SWEET. She split the bill among 5 credit cards which is insane, shout-out to her.
author: Gabriel H.

description:
Service was superb we came in 15 minutes before their closing. Food was fresh and fast. I felt like this place was very much like my mom's cooking. If it were better would have gotten a 5 star. 
Beef stew - was ok. I can taste the herb and spices, may not be for everyone. Beef was good, could be better.
House Special fried rice - so so.
Barbeque pork rice noodle - was superb a must try .
author: Steven C.

description: Perfect gem of an old school Chinese restaurant. Everything is quick, simple and delicious. Great to eat at a spot with some history and character
author: Sasha D.

description: Had the bbq roll and beef stew dry noodle. The food was simple but really tasty. From looking at the food others ordered that seems to be the style of this restraunt. All the dishes I saw had very 2-5 ingredients and very minimal sauce. I am actually really impressed with how good the food tasted with so little sauce.
author: Diane Z.

description:
Came here for a to go order for lunch since I work in the area. I needed something cheap and comforting. We came in 30 minutes before closing and they were relieved we were ordering to go.

Duck jook: nice amount of duck-porridge. A little bland, but I felt clean instead of greasy

Chinese donut: I've never had it was it was fried dough. No salt, no sugar. It was pretty good and fluffy

BBQ pork dry noodle: not much BBQ pork. Tasted really traditional, but a little plain. I would have preferred chow fun.

Overall, an okay place to check out. I liked how they had a photo op outside.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Friends from out of town were craving Chinese food when I realized I have never gone out for Chinese food in SF before. But, when in Chinatown, gotta get Chinese food! I had to scrounge Yelp for a good Chinese restaurant that was close enough to where they were. I chose Sam Wo since their website said they were the oldest restaurant in SF Chinatown so why not? Why not do something slightly touristy when tourists are in town? 

The restaurant looks super small but there is definitely more room upstairs. Going upstairs felt like I was in Asia for sure (like how not fancy and slightly unclean everything is) and we didn't actually wait that long after I put my name on the wait list. 

I'm surprised at how good the noodles are, like a guilty pleasure type of feeling. It's not gourmet or Michelin type but it does taste authentic and comforting, like my grandma made it. The garlic gai lan was a bit too garlicky for my taste but it helped to balance our carb-loading with some veggies. I want to say it was pricier than I expected for hole-in-the-wall Chinese food but it was good. I want to say this is a place I would want to eat at if I were drunk. You know what I mean? 

All in all, not exactly where I would eat at all the time but if friends are visiting SF and want some touristy Chinese food, I would bring them here again.
author: Peggy C.

description:
Horrifically bad. I have no clue why this place gets the rating it does. We ordered the pork roll, fried rice, chicken chow mein and bbq pork noodle soup with wontons. 

The broth of the noodle soup tasted like the residual water left from boiling the noodles. There was no flavor. It was bland and tasteless. The noodles didn't have the chew that you would expect from alkaline noodles and it made them mushy. How can you call it bbq pork noodle soup? 

Tourist trap along with being one of oldest Chinese restaurant is how, I think, this place thrives. All I can say is the emperor has no clothes.
author: Annie B.

description:
Omg! Great food. I really like how they reinvented themselves. I like the marketing of telling their story and having that PHOTO BOOTH outside their main entrance. It was a good touch. I like the effort. The best part is that while they obviously updating themselves with the techy marketing campaign, their restaurant is still very down to earth with great food and service. 

Oh yes, great supper food. They are open very LATE. Best thing to have at 230am!
author: Kelly L.

description:
There's a TV over the entrance that shows media coverage of Sam Wo's over the years on a loop. One of the clips is an episode of Conan O'Brien where Conan pokes fun at the restaurant, partly for being run down and unsanitary. "Wow, these guys are good sports", I thought to myself. Almost immediately afterwards, I noticed that the cook (a section of the kitchen is completely visible from the cashier's counter) had a persistent cough. Half of the time he was coughing without covering his mouth, directly over the food he was preparing. The other half he was coughing into the back of his hand and then wiping his face with said back of hand, and getting back to preparing food bare-handed without the slightest pause. After watching this for a few minutes, the Conan clip seemed less light hearted and more mean spirited. 

Four stars were still in play for Sam Wo's, because what's a little mucus between a restaurateur and his guests? They had good buzz after all, and the menu was promising. Unfortunately, the dishes came up short. The pork noodle roll appetizer was fatty and sweet, but with a little too much cilantro for my taste. The combination wonton soup had pork and shrimp; it had plenty of wontons and meat, but could have used some salt. The chow mein and chow fun were decent yet similarly bland. The sesame chicken was good, though offset by the Mongolian beef, which was honestly sort of heinous. 

Everyone I know tells me that SF Chinese food is supposed to be superior to the Seattle offerings. While this may still be true (there's plenty of Chinatown's vast expanse left to explore), Sam Wo's was a pretty mediocre experience that I hope does not end up being representative of the food scene here.
author: Abdullah A.

description: Talk about the best Chinese food you will ever have in your life! Everything we ordered was beyond amazing. We got there about 30 minutes after it opened and it was a good time because when we got seated, there were at least 50 people waiting in line (so get here early). I was impressed the most by the type of oils and quality food they use. We didn't feel overly full or sluggish after eating it (Chinese food usually does this to us). Truly a Chinatown Gem!
author: Joanna M.

description:
In my opinion, this place is a solid 3.5. I gave a 4 because the guy was very nice and friendly. I'm not sure if he's a manager or the owner but he seems very passionate in what he is doing and even in a busy time he had a smile and he was very sweet to all the customers. 

The food is pretty average here, the beef chow fun, and the chicken fried were okay, they did satisfy our late night cravings but they weren't the most delicious. 

On the other hand, the BBQ spring rolls were very delicious, the BBQ pork tasted savory and there were veggies inside the roll too. We also enjoyed the spring rolls.

Overall, it was a pretty good experience for the late night cravings!
author: May T.

description: This food at this restaurant is delicious and very fresh. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Monica G.

description:
I am not sure about the high ratings and I respect people's review and their experience however in my case, the food is okay. 

We came in on Saturday, September 15 at 7pm. Staff are friendly and very accommodating. They are really pleasant. The food serving is not generous, they used tiny plates and the food has just an ordinary taste compared to other restaurants I've been. Their jasmine rice is very hard and not fresh. Seemed like it was just microwaved. I'm only visiting the city of San Francisco so throughout my stay in the city, I ain't coming back. Perhaps I'm trying other Chinese restaurants out there.
author: Creighton J.

description:
So we chose this place based on the yelp reviews. But the food was lackluster at best. I ordered the vegetable chow fun. Zero flavor. I  wet very rarely send food back, but this one I absolutely had to. 
I don't see myself going back.
author: Jamie S.

description:
Hungry in the middle of the night and craving Chinese food? This is the place. No, I did not say this place have GOOD Chinese food... it opens late and serve average/bland Chinese food. 

We came here after 10pm on a Wednesday night and ordered:

Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings - crunchy, but no flavor
Pork Rolls - served cold, wish it was warm/hot
Wonton Noodles x2 orders - bland
Beef Chow Fun - we liked this dish the most, pretty good

Total: $42.29 - Food came out quick, hardly any wait. Service was meh, very typical for a late night place. Yes, they accept credit cards.
author: Jenny Y.

description: The noodle roll that i ordered was EXCELLENT (in the appetizer section) and I would gladly eat it again. The wonton soup combination i ordered was not for me but I saw some other items on the menu that I wish I had gotten. This place was recommended to me by a San Francisco resident and I was happy that I went! You have to sign your name on a list on their wall as a waiting list but it works out just fine. Food comes out super fast. I was dining alone and felt comfortable doing so there.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
Late night Chinese and searching on Yelp, Sam came up.  I remember my parents taking us here when we were small and lived in Pacifica.  It looked much different back then and now has a more modern feel to it...well, modern for Chinatown.  

Dinner was simple, pork rice noodle, duck mei fun, and kung pau chicken.  Yolie had a Sapporo and I just had green tea.  We had spent most of the day tasting wine, so I was just hungry.  We sat upstairs and it is cozy.  If I lived up here, I'd probably stop by at least twice a week to eat through the menu.  Prices are great!   In the world of shi-shi and "craft" dining, it's nice to eat some place simple.
author: Mikey H.

description:
Must do.
Everyone.
Everyone must do Sam Wo's...
One of the best late night carb overloads in town.

That's how I felt before the "reopening."  The old Sam Wo's was legendary.

Edsel was a character, & a huge part of the whole experience.

"The whole experience..."
You walked in, went through the kitchen, & up some very rickety stairs.  You sat your fine self down in stools that were meant to be uncomfortable enough so as not to invite lingering.  To say the venue was bare bones is a major understatement.  And the place had what basically became a mantra.  

Order the barbecue pork noodle rolls.

ORDER THE BARBECUE PORK NOODLE ROLLS.

That is exactly what an old friend told me when I moved to North Beach circa early 90's.

Edsel?  He was like the famous soup nazi, times a thousand.  "What do you want? (dissatisfaction on his face) See...you should order this..."

That was pretty much the drill.  He had a reputation for being snarly & snarky, but actually he was really a pussycat in disguise.

Staples.  Chow Mein.  Fried rice.  Anything chicken.  And those barbecue pork rolls.  I remember someone actually brought those rolls to a potluck dinner party in the neighborhood. 

And everyone knew them.  "Oh, Sam Wo's!"

It's also legendary for being open so late.  3 am.

4 instead of 5 stars because Edsel is gone.  Very sad face.

And the "charm" of entering through the kitchen is also gone.  

But, it's still one of the best carb overload joints in the city.  And still legendary.

Go.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Quick service, yummy food and great price (5 plates for $40)! Only thing is the lady keeps on speaking Chinese to me when I am speaking to her in English.
author: SuYen N.

description:
This place is a real established for Chinatown cheap eats. Newly renovated interior is interesting, spacious. So late night hunger pangs are calling? This is a spot to satisfy all your greasy Chinese food cravings! 

Wonton noodles are ok. Guess nothing is comparable to Hong Kong wonton noodles, the gold standard, no exception here. Noodles didn't have the chewy texture that wonton noodles should have, and almost certainly overlooked and somewhat soggy. The wontons were ok by American standards, but definitely not a HK wonton level. The wrapping is way too thick, and the filling doesn't have the right bite.

The real stand out and why I will definitely comeback though is the Beef Chow Fun. A dry soy sauce based stir fried flat rice noodle with beef. The noodles were perfectly fried with that smokiness taste that comes from a good wok fry. Yeah, it's greasy and heavy but who cares? It's soooo good washed down with some ice cold beer!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
You know when a restaurant has gotten so popular that they feel like they can serve you subpar food? Yep, that's Sam Wo. This ranks as a top 10 Yelp disappointment (definition- a place that has 100+ Yelp reviews and the reality of the service/ food is far below  the Yelp reviews) for me. 

I came here expecting a 4 star Yelp restaurant and was sorely disappointed. The place was packed at 6pm on a Wednesday evening so I thought, "That's a positive sign!" I had to hike my 6'3" frame upstairs to get the last table. 

We ordered:

1.  Duck fried rice- edible, but terrible. It tasted like it was partially fried rice drenched in oil 
2. Sesame chicken- this could possibly be the worst sesame chicken I have ever had at any Chinese restaurant. There was no flavor, only color. Halfway through the dish, the chicken pieces were so tiny, they were so hard to scoop up (see photos)
3. Chinese broccoli stir fried with garlic- easily the best dish of the night. Good portions and decent flavor, but I expect this.

So I sat there with my brother who rarely rips ok food places as we both tried to eat what was in front of us. On the bright side, the photos of Conan O'Brien visiting were right next to us.

$38 out the door including tax and tip for 2 people. 

I won't be coming back here again. I don't have very many 2 star reviews for restaurants because I know it's a hard industry, but people need to know.
author: Darren M.

description:
This was the one place that I have never thought that I would be coming here for lunch... And I have heard a lot of this Sam Wo Restaurant and it's history that this Sam Wo Restaurant was here for about over a 100 years!!! It was a last decision by me just to come here for lunch which was on a Wednesday on my PTO Day from work!!! 

When I got here this place was packed since Sam Wo Restaurant is nearby the Financial District of San Francisco!!! But I was really lucky that there was a table for one available for me!!! And what I have ordered for myself was a favorite that I always like to eat and that would be the Beef w/ Raw Egg over Steam Rice!!! 

After when I finished up my yummy Beef w/ Raw Egg over Steam Rice all I can say is that... I  really liked how Sam Woo Restaurant cooked their Beef w/ Raw Egg over Steam Rice!!! The waitress who came with my ordered was very friendly!!! This is the one Chinese Restaurant that I would definitely would wanna go back and try another thing to eat at Sam Wo Restaurant!!!
author: William B.

description:
My bf and I were craving Chinese food and lucked out with a 5 minute wait.

When you come here, first thing you should notice is that you don't come here for amazing service or trendy hipster decor. You come for the food. And for the cheap prices.

We ordered a few things: 
Sauteed string beans, what you'd expect.
Pork wonton soup, mmmm yummy especially with chili sauce.
Scrambled egg with pork over rice, huge portion but I thought I was ordering the runny egg with rice and pork so was slightly disappointed it was a legit scrambled egg. Still tasted good but wasn't what I wanted.
Also the BBQ pork roll. Wished the wrapper was thinner but otherwise had great flavor! Comes with spicy mustard dipping sauce. This is pretty popular, every table was getting it.

Note: they take credit cards but it takes forever to get it run and get it back. It'd be a lot easier if you just paid cash.
author: Mandi W.

description:
It doesn't have the dirty old charm the old location had, but that's not necessarily a bad thing! They've been around for over 100 years and they still serve really solid food! There's usually a short line mixed with tourists and locals. I've been going here for years and mostly order stuff that's off the menu. You'll see all the tourists ordering super Americanized Chinese food. The beef chow fun. Shrimp fried rice. You'll never see me order any of that!

Get the BBQ Pork roll. And just a small dab of the hot mustard. Super good! I won't share the off menu items because they sometimes sell out and I am selfish. The waitress asked me how I knew about one item and I told her I've been coming here for 20 years. She gave me a look and said, "yeah, only the locals know!"
author: Aaron Y.

description: My first time trying egg omelette on rice, apparently it's a Cantonese classic?! It's delish! We got the one with beef - the gravy on the omelette is salty so be sure to mix it with rice! The beef wonton soup was ok - the wontons are filled with a filling that tastes almost like spam (also is pinkish like spam)  I much prefer HK wonton garden in NY
author: Weich Y.

description:
Sam Wo is a rare find. It is a pretty casual place for grabbing a quick meal, yet has pretty decent food and it is open until 3A on Fridays and Saturdays. 

I have been here both for lunch and late supper before and the food was consistently good both times. My favorite is their chicken wings and it would be worth a visit to this place if only for the chicken wings.
author: Doruk B.

description:
Sam Wo is a joint that is open late, near China town, that serves HK style Chinese comfort food. I thought the food was decent, but the dishes were hit or miss for me. I would come back here if there was no line and I was in the area.

There is limited seating. Service OK for Asian standards and is kind of slow.

I really enjoyed the:
HK milk tea
BBQ pork noodle wrap (char sui) with spicy mustard sauce

I also ordered the:
Runny eggs with shrimp over rice - just okay, wasn't very tasty. The rice wasn't fried, it was kind of stale.
author: Sean W.

description:
I'm soooooooo glad this restaurant reopened.  It's a very sentimental place for us since there's family history tied to this place. 

He would bring home take out at least once a week and I would wake up and eat dinner with him while he told me stories of his day, his life, his dreams, etc. 

Back to the food.  It's still as good as I remember it to be and it's the ONLY place that I know that serves a plate called Raw Fish Salad.  I can honestly say it's my favorite dish in the entire world.  I love the Sashimi pieces but I love the combination of flavors from the pickled ginger and other picked veggies, the fresh lemon juice and fish, and the crunch from the noodles and sesame seeds.  I haven't found another place that makes this dish exactly the same and I started searching a few years ago when this restaurant initially closed down. 

The moment I heard this place had reopened, I jumped in my car for my favorite dish and brought my entire family with me.  

We our other favorite which was the beef stew and again, it was as good as I remembered it to be.  Tender and flavorful from slow cooking over time.  

The rest of the dishes were good.  Simple, easy and flavorful and common among other Chinese restaurants. 

I am certain that I will be back over and over again.
author: Linda V.

description:
Yelp 100 Challenge 2018 (27/100)

This was such a great find in Chinatown! 
Thank you Yelpers for helping me find it.

It's very inexpensive and the food is really good! My boyfriend and I ate every last bite. Our favorite dishes were the chicken chow fun and fried rice.  We also got the chicken and broccoli, but I think we would get something different if we went again.

The reason for the -1 star is because of the service.  We were so happy with the food, but the woman seemed like she hated us. :/ 

Overall, would go back and definitely recommend to anyone that's wanting to try out some good food in Chinatown.
author: Ashley G.

description:
BBQ Pork Rolls are AMAZING. I live in Chinatown and I come here regularly for them. Sometimes I'll get them for lunch on my way to work since it's a lot of food on it's own. DON'T FORGET THE SPICY MUSTARD.

The other food is ok but not groundbreaking. We often order the chow fun here and it's good but the sauces aren't quite as good as the noodles. Last times we ordered the Sichuan chow fun (got a little side eye since that's not the traditional style for chow fun) and it was good - the curry was kind of gritty but the shrimp was amazing. Next time I'll probably order a dif chow fun and just add shrimp.
author: Bodhi L.

description:
The BBQ Pork Rice Noodle is a MUST! It's hands down the best I've had hence the 5 stars. All of the ingredients tasted fresh, especially the noodle!

Also ordered the house fried rice and sesame chicken which were pretty good. The place is small so if you have a large party it's probably best to takeout. The staff was friendly.
author: Josh L.

description:
I think the best part of this place is the price. It's not the tastiest chinese food I've ever had but they had most of the basics here and it wasn't bad. Service was fast and they were really nice, but the food was just okay.

I believe that what draws people here the most is the fact that they've been in business for 100 years. But that still doesn't mean that it tastes great. It pretty much tasted like any generic chinese food restaurant I've ever been to that wasn't a chain restaurant. And, being Asian myself, I've been to probably hundreds of them.
author: Michelle E.

description: I am so happy they re-opened after shutting down about two years ago. The food here is still very yummy and I believe the place is still family-owned. Prices have increased but still very affordable. I can tell that the business is trying to keep to it's roots. Keep it up, will be back :)
author: Lushi Z.

description: Fast! And sooo much food. We loved our waiter as well. He was very sweet. Very happy with the place. Thanks yelp for the recommendation!
author: Liz K.

description:
This place is authentic as it gets 
It was so packed in a great location 
I ordered the beef and tomatoes chow mein
The best way I could describe it is that it's a Chinese spaghetti
It tasted great along a Chinese beer
author: Jonathan M.

description: This is one of old Chinese restaurants in San Francisco. I had fried rice and salt and pepper tofu. The food was good and the service was quick. You can get free hot tea.
author: Fala H.

description:
I ate here once because this place is known for their fresh noodle wraps.  That was the only thing worth getting.  The wonton noodle soup and jook was way below par and the rice dishes bland.  This place might have been featured on the tonight show but I'm not going to be tuning in to this spot anytime soon.  Service was better than expected

Food 2.5
Service 4
Overall 3
author: Patrick C.

description: Mediocre late night Chinese food. The combo wonton soup had a tasty broth and was good for 4 people as an appetizer ($10). However, the "salt and pepper" wings needed SALT and PEPPER. I salt and peppered them myself. The kung pao shrimp sauce was watery but the Mongolian beef was a little better. Service was friendly and fast, and the restaurant seemed clean. Limited seating downstairs, but they have more tables upstairs. I'd return if nothin else was open in the area late night but wouldn't expect too amazing of food.
author: Natasha K.

description: Wonton, noodles are normal food, it is good if the restaurant can do proper cooking. At Sam Wo, they do the right things. Yam is pork wontons improve the taste and soup is good with some shrimp and pork. Besides, bbq roll is really good! So I give 4 stars.
author: Zhijian J.

description:
Not a bad spot to frequent if you live close by.

Food is overall decent, moderately priced and fairly consistent. Open late on weekends which is a plus, though their hours are weird so make sure to check first. 

One note, their chicken wings are like crack.. be careful.
author: Darin M.

description: I ate here with family which included adults and finicky children. Everyone loved their meals. We ordered had spring rolls, veggie fried rice, chicken with broccoli, wonton soup, chop suey, and a couple of other dishes that I can't remember for the meat eaters at the table. We all enjoyed everything. The flavors were great distinct and well balanced. I look forward to another meal here in the near future!
author: Russ S.

description:
This place is a bit mixed for me, since it had some pretty good items, but also some rather mediocre ones. The place is located across the street from the park where all the people are playing cards and Chinese checkers. 

The good item is the meat rolls, which are like rice paper rolled pieces of BBQ pork, served with a delicious mustard sauce. The mustard is one of those yellow hot and spicy kinds that you usually see served at dim sum, but it is mixed with a soury vinegar like substance, and also sweetened, which ended up complimenting the BBQ pork rolls really well. That would have been given a 4 star!

Unfortunately, I also got the Duck Dry Mixed Noodles, which wasn't nearly as good, and in some ways, quite bad. There were a ton of noodles, which was great, but the duck tasted like it was just boiled, and had the meat shredded off of it and placed on top of the noodles, and then they added lettuce and green onions on top. 

Not quite the most delicious dish. There was also way too many noodles in relative comparison to everything else, and the sauce mixed with the noodles was a bit of a letdown.
author: Tyler T.

description:
I'm shocked this place has 4/5 stars. Did I get a meal from the wrong place? I ordered Beef Chow Fun and Wonton Noodle Soup from Caviar delivered to my house.

Never had I had worse chow fun AND wonton soup from any other Chinese restaurants in my LIFE. I am truly baffled how a Chinese restaurant can't even "meet expectations" on two STAPLES of a Chinese cuisine - This only goes to show the quality of the rest of their food. 

The chow fun was SUPER oily, but the worst part was, it had ZERO flavor. Usually, these noodles are oily because the more oil the more flavor. I'm not sure how this equation worked out here. It felt like they  put a bunch of oil in the wok, and let the noodles swim around in the oil for a very undercooked amount of time. Voila no flavor. No salt. No soy sauce. Most of the onions were just plain raw. WTF. I won't even let the stringy and chewy beef get in the way of this complaint, but that was just the cherry on top. I was eating chunks of flavorless noodles that had congealed together. 

The wonton noodle soup was just flabbergastingly bad. Forget al dente noodles, these noodles were beginning to liquify in my soup. WTF. Did they use expired noodles? The wontons themselves were terrible. The meat was showing through the poorly wrapped and broken wonton skins, and a lot of them were RED. Not normal for wonton meat. I ate a couple, and the craftsmanship sucked. Ginger CHUNKS in each bite. 

Getting riled up while writing this omfg lol. Needless to say, I will never ever go back here.
author: Vickie Z.

description: We were around Chinatown and upon checking yelp, we decided to try this place. The place was packed and line was a bit long. We ordered their sweet n sour pork, shrimp fried rice, bbq pork wonton noodle soup and bbq pork noodle roll. I was surprised to see mustard sauce when they served the noodle roll. I was hesitant to try it because I've never seen any mustard sauce served before in a chinese restaurant. We were surprised how good it was as a dipping sauce for the roll. We can't get enough of it. I would have preferred to skip the noodle soup and just get another bbq noodle roll. The sweet n sour pork was okay, not too sweet. Fried rice was delicious with a good amount of shrimp.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
3.5 stars.

My party of seven was seated upstairs.

We ordered:

BBQ rice roll (amazing. Mustard sauce had a kick)
Wonton mein (the wontons were delicious)
Duck fried rice (okay)
Duck mai fun (vermicelli... not great)
Chicken wings (beyond salty!!!!!!!!!!!!)

Restrooms downstairs... fairly clean.
author: Jenny L.

description: I honestly don't see what the hype is. I'm Chinese and am not necessarily picky about Chinese food, but couldn't understand why there's a line out the door. The food is solid, around a 3 Star. We were seated 5 of us in a tiny table that probably could comfortably fit 3 max. Service was like any other Chinese restaurant: negligible. And the Chinese food itself was just fine. Maybe we ordered the wrong dishes...
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I can never get a photo of the food here, just because I'm too busy and focused on the amazing food! 

Every time I go to San Francisco now, I HAVE to go here. Everything on the menu is great. The only remotely bad thing is that its a really small restaurant and always packed - but totally worth it!
author: Alexandria R.

description:
The restaurant was located in Chinatown. The space was small but they were able to fit quite a few tables along one wall. The interior had a cute wall graphic of Chinese food! Overall, it felt very cozy.

[Beef and Bok Choy Chow Mein] The noodles weren't too greasy or dry, which I really appreciated. They were very generous with the beef and the bok choy. The bok choy was fresh and easy to chew. (Not the type that gets stuck in your throat!)

This place definitely had a humble, homely feel to it. I will definitely swing by again!
author: Annie Z.

description:
I'd been going to the old Sam Wo location since the 1970s and was suspicious of the new version. It was fun to visit for old time's sake, but the experience was mediocre. Much of the charm of the old location was walking past the kitchen, up the teetery old steps to the grubby second floor dining area, but I guess that's why the health department shut them down.

Food is still relatively cheap, but the roast duck chow fun is now bland and lacking that charred finish that I used to love. The BBQ noodle roll was good, and my husband loved his BBQ pork chow mein (actually, I loved it, too, and at it instead of my so-so chow fun.)

Sam Wo seems to still draw tourists, myself included, but they will have to step up their game if they want us to continue to come.
author: Patti I.

description:
I'm renaming this place to Sam whoooaaaa that food tastes good when you're drunk! But really, it tastes very yummy in general... However, it's the perfect ending to a drunken night out. I was introduced to this lovely spot by none other than my fellow Yelpers! After going to a few bars in the area, we had worked up a bit of an appetite. It was suggested that we hit up Sam Wo, and I was all for it! I wasn't all for the journey of a walk that it took to get there though (everything seems farther away when you've been drinking).
 
When we arrived, I was a little stunned. At first glance, this place looked super tiny. We were guided up a flight of stairs by a host and lo and behold; they had a second floor with tables to accommodate larger parties. I noticed that they also had a TV in the corner that was playing an Asian soap opera in the background. There was 7 of us in total, so you know we were about to be feastin' it up!
 
The spread:
 
*BBQ pork rice rolls
*Salt & pepper chicken wings
*Noodle wonton soup
*Beef chow fun
*Wonton noodle soup
*Mongolian beef
*Sesame chicken
*Shrimp fried rice
*Pork Jook (porridge)
 
I have to say that overall, I was pretty impressed! It didn't take them long to prepare everything and one by one, our dishes began to arrive right after one another. I would say that I enjoyed the Mongolian beef, sesame chicken, and the wonton noodle soup the most. I looove Mongolian beef and although it wasn't spicy, it presented great flavor. The wonton noodle soup was hot and the broth tasted great! The sesame chicken was super on point; not overly sweet or over battered with a little bit of crunch. I didn't particularly care of the pork jook or the salt & pepper wings. The pork jook lacked seasoning and the salt & pepper wings were a little too salty. A few of noticed the mounds on salt that had been loaded on the fried skin. Despite the minor mishaps, everything else tasted really good!
 
The service was pretty much spot on! There was one gentleman in general who serviced our table for the entire time that we were there, and he pretty much remained upstairs for the duration of the time. We were stuffed! When the bill came, I was actually shocked! All of that food only costed us a total of $100! One thing I LOVE when it comes to Chinese food is when it's good and CHEAP! I can't forget to mention that this place is open until 3 am on the weekends! We rolled in there around midnight and didn't end up leaving until after 1 am.
 
All in all, this is an excellent spot for some late night grub when you're in the city! I look forward to coming back here again in the future and trying out more of their dishes.
author: Shayla B.

description:
Had high hopes for this spot. The portions are huge, the prices cheap, loved the 100yr history behind it, and the cute hostess was super helpful and friendly on the upside. I ordered the trademark bbq pork noodle and the house special fried rice. 

The pork noodle had a thick rice noodle that was tender and tasty but the filling was your standard chinese takeout minced pork and was very dry with no bbq flavor to it. The house fried rice I will say was family size huge and didnt skimp on the chicken, shrimp, pork, beef, or scrambled egg. The problem was it had zero seasoning of any kind and wasnt fried at all. It was pretty much just meats mixed into plain albeit oily white rice.

The experiance wasnt bad between the good service, quick arrival, and interesting conversation with some aussie tourists while I waited but idk if ill be back. Im not a picky eater and was so hungry I ate half of it anyway but it was bland to the point where I just donated the other half to the homeless gentleman who lives outside my office building.
author: Sean G.

description: Whenever I'm in SF I always try to stop by. My favourite is the BBQ pork wonton noodle soup, which is a large portion of wonderful soup that is always light and filling.
author: Emiliano C.

description:
I don't really get the hype of this restaurant, but I guess my expectations for Chinese food are really high, coming from Markham.

The prices here are VERY affordable for San Francisco. Most of the dishes are $7 - 11  USD.

A lot of the dishes at Sam Wo are VERY simple. It's always some combination of (Soup) + veggies + meat + Noodles/rice. The meat portions are also quite small. Especially in the noodle stir fries, you can barely even see the meat since the slivers blend right into the dish. 

I also dislike how they only have two types of noodles: rice noodles and egg noodles. I really like thick/heavy/hand-pulled options, but it seems to me that a lot of their ingredients are premade.

I ordered the beef rice noodle soup - decent. The beef in my beef noodle soup consisted mostly of fatty parts. I would say 40% of the chunks were actual lean meat. Also, there were NO vegetables apart of green onions (they don't count!). They don't even have cilantro or radish :( which I think are absolutely essential for beef noodles. The broth was very savoury and rich, but it was very "one-dimensional." Maybe they used a poor quality soy sauce, or not enough ginger... either way... the noodles back home are MUCH better in comparison. The amount of noodles they put in the soup noodles versus the stir fry is also noticeably less... not sharable between duos or families.

The servers were very nice, and the place had a very authentic vibe, but I felt like this was more of an overrated tourist dining spot than anything else. Not a hole in the wall.
author: Monica X.

description:
We are in China town!! Was craving for some ramen but since it was Labor Day, the spot I was tying to go to was closed. So I asked yelp where else? This place is close by and the reviews were pretty good. We had immediate seating but we sat upstairs which was pretty muggy. I was sweating waiting for our server. 

We ordered the wonton soup and duck chow fun. Duck chow fun was too oily and it barely had any meat in there, mostly noodles. Flavor was a bit lacking... but I highly recommend the won ton soup! Broth was amazing and I wish I had a bigger bowl and added veggies. It was interesting reading about their famous rudest waiter and learning about him on the wall downstairs. Price was very reasonable. I would come back here again but not for the chow fun.
author: Barbara F.

description:
Had to eat some Chinese food while in San Fran area. Found this place on yelp with decent reviews and decided to give it a try. 

I must say we are glad we did. It is very small and you're sitting very close to others, but the food is worth it. The staff was patient while we choose what to eat. Once we were ready they helped us quickly. 

I've had beef and broccoli before but never this warm and fresh. I don't know if it was because I was hungry or because I was in vacation, but it tasted amazing. Hopefully we will be back for more soon.
author: Lucy L.

description:
I ordered the Mixed Vegetable Chow Fun ($8.25) at around 12 pm on a Sunday afternoon. 

When I first arrived to this restaurant, I noticed that there were a lot of people standing around. I was told that I had to put my name on the waiting list. I think this is quite common because I saw a lot of names on the waiting list. In total, I had to wait for about 10 minutes to be seated and this was for a table of 2. When I finally got seated, I noticed that the space was very narrow. I had to sit on a stool and the table was kind of high. I felt like I had to lift my arm a lot to pick up food from my plate but that could be because I'm not really tall, :P. 

My dish was good, although it was very oily. There were a lot of vegetables, such as cabbage, green beans, and broccoli. The broccoli was slightly raw and the green beans were very crunchy. Even though there were a lot of customers waiting for their food, I found that the food arrived quickly. 

The employees were nice and really busy. The restaurant was fairly clean. I'm surprised that this place is over 100 years old!
author: Kristina M.

description:
First off, the restaurant is very small and crowded. My boyfriend and I arrived for a late night dinner after landing at the Oakland airport around 11pm. It looked promising because it was pretty busy.

Our waitress wasn't very happy or welcoming at all and seemed that she didn't really want to be there. When we ordered, our food came out super fast which was nice because we were starving.

We ordered the egg rolls, the wonton soup, chow mein, string beans, and sesame chicken. I have to say I was super underwhelmed by all of the dishes. The chow mein had an interesting curry flavor that really caught us off guard. The sesame chicken, wonton soup, and string beans were a bit bland. The egg rolls were alright. Definitely disappointed.
author: Tabetha S.

description:
Food 4/5. Ambiance 4/5. Service 5/5. 

I've passed this place so many times visiting Chinatown and I'm so sad that I didn't discover this place before. This is one of the cleanest Chinese restaurants in Chinatown I've ever been in. Walking into the restaurant, it's been remodeled and filled with modern decor. Apparently it's been open for more than 100 years and I can see why. At first glance, it doesn't seem like there is much tables, but there is actually an upstairs area! 

We got a few appetizers to share. We got the BBQ pork roll which came with a mustard sauce with a dip. Beware, the mustard sauce is very potent. The roll had a thick outer rice layer and filled with Chinese BBQ pork. I was skeptical at first glance, but the roll was actually delicious. Simple, yet delicious. Great as an appetizer. 

I personally got the broccoli and beef over rice and it was delicious. Probably the best I ever had. The sauce ate deliciously with the rice (not too salty), tender beef and well cooked broccoli. I tried the chow mein and it wasn't oily at all and was well flavored and balanced. It also had pieces beef that was just as tender. I also tried the rice porridge and it was just like my moms made with thicker pieces of rice. I would recommend getting the Chinese donuts if you get the rice porridge as it adds a crunchy element to it! Although, this is not the best Chinese donut I ever had. 

The service here was actually really good! The waiter was constantly filling up water and the good came very fast. Overall, if you are visiting or just in the area, it's a perfect place for lunch or a late night dinner.

Tips -  The BBQ pork rolls was delicious and was a great appetizer to any meal. 

Pros - Great service and clean for a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. 

Cons - Won't be able to fit large groups of people! Pretty narrow.
author: Brian N.

description:
Had to post an afterward picture. 
My friends and I came here after we had a few drinks because it was the only place opens in the neighborhood. We ordered house chow mien, beef noodles with wonton and some other dishes which I forgot the names to. Everything tasted very greasy but what do you expect from Chinese food? Super hot inside, no fan no ac and I went on a cold winter night. It was just too hot. I think it's a good place to grab a bite after club or lounge.
author: Hong T.

description: Great Chinese food. Every time I'm in San Francisco I stop here. Their food has a lot of flavor and they take pride in it. Staff is very friendly and the business is very clean.
author: Jorge A.

description: The old location was the best Chinese food experience you could buy for the money. The new location is nothing but a tourist trap.
author: Shane H.

description: I'm all for mom and pop shops. This place has a nice homey vibe and the staff is very attentive. I think what's cool is the decor in the restaurant and how they're quite thoughtful and put little wall hanging hooks for you to put your bags on so they don't have to be put on the floor. Food wise, loved the tomato and beef over rice! Definitely worth the $8 I paid, you get a massive plate you could probably share with another person (though I demolished it by myself) and it's super flavorful (if you are a tomato lover, you'd love this). I'd come here again or order take out if I'm in a rush. My friend got their duck chow fun and it reminded me of the good home cooked meals my mom would make me growing up. What I like is that it's not too saucy and not too dry like how some chow fun dishes can be. It's simple but packs good flavor with each bite.
author: Amber P.

description:
I absolutely love this place! It was a cold, windy day in the bay (when is it not?) and I thought a good bowl of jook would be perfect for an early dinner. 
I walk into the restaurant was was seated in the front main area. The server was very efficient and polite. I enjoyed a bowl of hot jook with duck and the bbq port noodle roll.
The jook was seasoned the way I like it, and the duck was a nice touch. 
I have never had anything like the bbq pork noodle roll, it was a cold dish, but it had a crunchiness to it  as well. The spicy mustard is the perfect condiment too (it is very hot!) I look forward to returning to this spot when I am in the bay!
author: Virginia M.

description:
Sometimes you can't just believe the rating any more.
