I was almost going in the one 1 block away but it had only 2.5 stars rating, the restaurant was packed, the dim sum looked so good, we walked away to go to Sam Wo w a 4 stars. It was a complete disaster, they must be lying, C'mon give me a break, this was no 100  years restaurant, it probably was at one point but probably sold to these amateurs, the wonton soup broth was right out of a can , they didn't even bother adding any soy sauce. The wontons were tasteless, it was pure cardboard. We were so upset, the server came by several times to ask if everything was ok, she was nice and I was very tired n hungry, it was not worth it to tell her the truth, perhaps I should have instead of going hungry at 2 pm on Thanksgiving Day! The fried chow fun taste was ok but the beef was tough, probably horse meat?? I exaggerated but it was tougher than my shoe  leather. I could not eat the meat but ate some of the noodle. 
Do not come here unless you are a starving student, a backpacker or have not eaten in 2 days !!! I realize I was confused w SAM WOO a reputable establishment in los Angeles n Irvine, this place was a hole in the wall n more people should call them out. They advertised in the free map so got a big share of the tourists, this is a tourist trap!!
author: Cheryl N.

description: This place was super good! A classic in San Francisco won't disappoint! I can't wait to go back.
author: Joel C.

description:
Really wish I tried their signature shrimp noodle dish... But came here late at night as a midnight snack and ordered what the guy next to us ordered: duck noodle soup with wontons! It was pretty good but the duck meat was a little gamey for me.. egg noddles were great though.  Will definitely have to go back when I'm in town again. 

It's reasonably priced, open til super late/early. Definitely a must eat in SF it seems.
author: Christine J.

description:
100+ years of history in this restaurant! It just looked so quaint and just sooo... San Francisco China town. It's in a very typical SF lanky - narrow but high - two story building. Our server spoke little English - which was perfect and to be hoped for- but mostly got the order right, even though he was friendly and fast. 

They have some good looking dishes. We only ended up with Chinese donuts which were a little underwhelming, and not hot. The duck dry noodles - served a mixture of cold and hot - and mostly too salty. My wife liked it a lot more. 

Finally the bbq pork roll. That thing saved this review! The rice dough was so soft and the meat so tender. And the spicy Chinese mustard packed a Bruce Lee roundhouse kick straight to the schnozz. Way stronger than wasabi. Loved it. But I'm a sucker for pain I guess.
author: Jeff O.

description: We were looking forward to trying this place as it is a famed sf Institution (rude waiter!).  Sadly, this place is a sadly mediocre restaurant. Any decent takeout place could do better. My husband got duck chow mein, I got veggie chow mein. Both were greasy with over cooked vegetables. Service was fine, food came quickly. It was cheap and "good enough", but hardly worth a detour.
author: Dina J.

description:
Went on a weekend afternoon and to my surprise there was no wait. Good portions for a nice price. Quality was okay, but comparable to other restaurants in the area. The atmosphere is great for eating with friends. We ordered:

Tomato Beef over Rice: pretty saucy and tastes like bbq sauce. 

Chinese Broccoli: Decent. 

Sesame Chicken: Good, but pieces of meat could be bigger. 

Pork Rice Roll: Their famous dish. Pretty good, nice quality -- try it with hot mustard. 

Jook: Very good!

Chow Mein: A little disappointed they don't do "Hong Kong" style noodles but the thicker noodles weren't bad.
author: Kate S.

description: I had the Kung pao shrimp with rice and my son had the yang chow fried rice. The portions are large (more than we could eat) and the food is excellent. Acting on the suggestion of another yelper, we also had the bbq pork roll which was wonderful dipped in the red sauce on the table. The yellow sauce that is served with it was very spicy but also good if you like spice!  Definitely worth the wait. Don't let the line dissuade you. There is additional dining upstairs.
author: Donna T.

description:
Dry noodles! Dry noodles! These are the star. yummmmm. (okay, no we didn't get the BBQ pork noodle rolls, but try that too). 

We ordered the house fried rice, vege stir fry, and bbq pork dry noodles. The dry noodles came out first, and we slurped it down before the rest. The other dishes were just okay. Great prices for the middle of China Town San Fran. 

We came Thanksgiving day and didn't wait to long for a table during lunch. We were aiming for a light lunch--somewhat effective. 

We enjoyed our service!
author: Diane K.

description: The house rice noodles are crazy good. So fresh. I never leave a review, this one made me pick up my phone
author: Kris D.

description:
You know when you're sick, and the only thing that will make you feel better is your mother's cooking?  Well, I couldn't have any of that because I was in town for a wedding, but I hoped to find something, anything, that could come close to a home-cooked meal.

After a quick search on Yelp, the fiance and I headed to Sam Wo Restaurant.  We added our name to the wait list and were immediately seated!  I saw that they had congee on the menu, and knew that I had to get it.  Specifically, I needed the preserved egg and pork congee, it's one of my ultimate comfort foods.  He was craving noodles, so he got the chicken chow fun.

At Sam Wo, they use thinner noodles than I normally expect for the chow fun, but, the sauce and seasoning for the dish were delicious.  He added some hot sauce on top, and he finished the mound of noodles in no time!

My congee was a little more bland than I'm used to, so I added some pepper and sipped away.  The bowls and portions are quite large, I feel like they're meant to be shared.  Service was friendly and attentive.  Our meal was only $17!  Not bad!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
They don't have the iconic pulley thing anymore to serve dishes since they've shut down and reopened.  But something about San Wo still made me want to check them out.  Having not felt so well earlier I suggested somewhere to my friend that serves soup.  His office is by the TransAmerica building, and I think he's mentioned Sam Wo before too so I said why not and suggested to meet here for lunch.  

We were easily able to get a table upstairs, which yes is a bit awkward but roomier than downstairs.  I got the BBQ pork wonton noodle soup, and he got the house special chow fun.  He also asked for a coke.  The young waiter served it to him with just the can.  No glass, no straw, just the can.  Who does this?  Now not to stereotype but I'm Chinese, third generation ABC (American Born Chinese) to be exact, yet I still do what my grandparents used to do with soda, the rare occasions I get a can of soda, I rinse and wipe it down then I pour it into a separate glass.  There's actually a decent amount of Chinese people, including those who are grannies that dine here, and I know if they drank soda they would be doing the same thing, so I don't know why he didn't even bring my friend a glass or the very least a straw to drink it out of.  

Anyways, onto the food.  The broth had that clean taste and didn't make me thirsty.  But it was a bit bland which makes me think that they dont use MSG.  The wonton filling is a bit stingy and I think it's all pork instead of the usual shrimp and pork mix.  Also they were pretty darn pink still (however I've seen articles saying sometimes this still happens when boiling).  Noodles were fine.  The texture of the cha siu (BBQ pork) was almost too soft.  It was lean too with no actual BBQ portion such as the nice sweet salty char.  I was also disappointed how they didn't include any bok choy.  His house special chow fun used thinner noodles than what's typically used in chow fun.  His tasted slightly better than mine, but like someone else mentioned this dish definitely missed the seasoned wok taste.  He had to use a lot of soy sauce and chili sauce as well.

What's also kinda neat but odd about Sam Wo is the upstairs seating, we had to take a four seater table and it had extra seating on the side against the wall area in which I put my purse and jacket on.  But this was also intrusive when the grannies at the table in front of us left, and came was a noisy fobby lady with her even noisier three girls.  It seems like she knew a lot of the restaurant employees, perhaps a family friend or just a frequent customer, but literally we did and the guy to the next table kept staring at them whenever they would open their big mouths, but they wouldn't ask her if she could tone down her screaming or her kids' screaming, and with how the upstairs area is sound travels a lot.  The waitress that took over for our original waiter at the end was better than he was, but not even that can save Sam Wo in my opinion.

There's still some better spots in Chinatown for legit, non touristy Chinese food.  Sam Wo is slightly pricier than most quick Cantonese spots and I honestly don't know why because the food is so subpar.  I do have to say that it seems fairly clean for a spot in Chinatown though.  Get your jook, wonton mein, or chow fun fix elsewhere.
author: Cat C.

description: The food here is only two stars. Other than the history, there's nothing special about this place
author: Rui L.

description:
Hungry at 2AM? This is your spot. They are open until 3am and can cater to your drunken munchies. 

The food is mediocre. That's just the best way to describe it. We ordered the house chow mein, mongolian beef, chicken wings, beef & broccoli and they all lacked flavor. We only came here because it was the only spot open around that time and we were hungry. Would I come back? If I was in the area and it was 2AM, then yeah, probably.
author: Andrea F.

description: Wow, really amazing food for the price, and prompt and quick service! We were just walking through Chinatown and I looked up the reviews and we decided to give this place a chance. VERY well worth it, large portions and very delicious food (even my family members that aren't super familiar with Chinese food LOVED this place), very highly recommended! Stop by when you can, amazing!
author: Shana L.

description: Very nice Chinese restaurant. Tasty first dish and a huge bowl of soup managed to stuff us full. My only complaint is that we felt like we were always rushed.
author: Anatoly R.

description:
One of the best places to visit if you like spicy Chinese food. 
Highly recommended!!
author: Rishi P.

description:
Very good basic Chinese food. Recommend the wonton soup and the scrambled egg with shrimp fried rice!
Very fast efficient service. NO ATMOSPHERE BUT GOOD FOOD!
author: Susan S.

description:
Fun place to eat in Chinatown. We were seated next to the bathroom, unfortunately, so there were a few unpleasant smells to deal with, but the food was very good and our waitress was pleasant and accommodating for my wife's gluten free needs.
I would eat there again. Learned that they are famous for the "worlds rudest waiter", which was kind of fun to learn about.
author: Peter S.

description: Sam Wo (no relation to the Sam Woo chain in LA) serves up authentic Cantonese comfort food in a narrow two story space.  We had the beef tendon wonton soup, fried chicken wings, pork liver and stomach jook, and Singapore rice noodles. Everything was delicious.  The quality was better than many of the places I've tried elsewhere.  A solid place for Cantonese food in San Francisco, and the cheapest meal I had there in three days.
author: David P.

description:
I have no idea how this place is getting 4 stars on Yelp. I blame the tourists with no sense of what good Chinese food taste like. The food is mediocre at best. You can literally throw a dart at any takeout deli in Chinatown and get better food at lower prices. 

The last time I was there, someone at our table ordered the Singapore style mai fun and it was overloaded with salt. It was inedible. 

Their prices are about 30% more than what it should be. C'mon white people. It's just bland, overpriced Cantonese food which is the blandest of all the Chinese cuisines. Live a little and try something other than chow fun and fried rice. You can get that back home in Iowa or upgrade to Panda Express.
author: Pat Y.

description:
Cool little spot for a quick lunch. I got here early when they opened and it seemed to get pretty crowded when we were leaving.

The food was good and decently priced (I ordered chow fun, bbq pork rice noodle rolls, and salt and pepper chicken wings). The food came pretty quick and the servers were attentive. I do feel like there are better places when eating in Chinatown but I was starving and close by at the time. One downside to the bbq pork rice noodle rolls is that they are not served with any sauce. I am used to eating these especially at dim sum with sweet soy sauce so I was very bummed out. I would be interested in trying some of their other dishes though.
author: Allison S.

description: Very solid food. Great price ($9 chicken & rice plate). Good location in the center of Chinatown. Nicer ambiance than a lot of similarly priced restaurants in Chinatown. Speedy service.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Where to start, service was horrible!!! Waitress very rude and not helpful at all!!! The food was good and fresh, out of all the places we choice from we choose this one , we eat at Sam wood in San Gabriel all the time and never have a problem maybe it was just another day
! Or maybe she was just having a bad day but maybe we'll skip on it next time
author: Shavon F.

description:
Sam Wo is one of the few places in Chinatown that I'll give 5 stars for. This cute little restaurant  has been around for a long time yet the interior is pretty modern and clean compared to how old it is. 

The porridge here is authentic with huge portion sizes. The side dishes need a bit of work but nothing horrible especially given the affordable prices. They even take credit card. 

There is a cute seating area upstairs too so you might get a seat quick even if the place looks full.
author: Ming Y.

description:
I remember when my parents and I used to go out to Chinatown at 9pm just to eat Sam Wo at its old location. The bbq pork rice noodle roll was my ALL TIME FAVORITE. When they closed down I was pretty sad because there was no other place that made the bbq rice noodle roll the way they did and opened until 3am. 

So when I walked into the new Sam Wo, I was pretty surprised. They have a photo booth and a bunch of restaurant souvenirs for sale! The place looked clean and was decorated nicely. Which was extremely shocking because back then it was no where close to looking elegant like it does now. 

I had three orders of bbq pork rice noodle roll. I must say it still taste the same like it was before. So it was delicious and I couldn't stop shoving them into my mouth! (LOL) I understand that restaurants need to pay their workers and such, but the prices are more expensive than it was back then. 

Also, I ordered the pork and preserved egg jook. Which i was pretty disappointed because I couldn't really taste much flavor in it. No salt, no pepper, no ginger, nothing. 

Overall, I will come back to Sam Wo for the roll. You must try it if you are in SF.
author: Kristi A.

description: Decent Chinese food. Not sure what all the hubbub is about with these Yelp reviews. It's good, but nothing to write home about!
author: Dylan R.

description: Decided to check this place out, as it had really high ratings in yelp. I personally thought it was okay. I've had better wonton soup and noodles in other places. My noodles were good, but for some reason my duck on top was cold. I would've preferred a warm roasted duck, instead of cold duck meat on top of my warm noodles.
author: Tahini R.

description: The Chinese food was ok for me.  The establishment was very busy and seemed to be a popular place for tourists.  The seating was very efficient; got to reserve my table on yelp.  When I arrived, I was seated right away.  The service was ok.  I ordered my food but there was some confusion with my waiter and the order was not put in.  I didn't receive our food until 30 minutes later.  This is slow compared with other Chinese restaurants I've been to.  They get a three stars for their food and ambience.
author: Cydel T.

description:
It pains me to give this place only 3 stars.  I really wanted to give them more.  The place was clean and fairly big by Chinatown standards.  The people working there were very friendly.  And, it's close to many Chinatown-esque things to do.  However, the food was very average in my opinion.  Not bad, but just ok.  

We went with the popular BBQ Pork Roll, Chicken Jook, BBQ Pork Egg Noodle Wonton Soup, Beef with Greens, and Chinese Broccoli with garlic.  The BBQ Pork rolls was different than the ones I get from dim sum places.  This one was served cold and didn't have the sauce that is usually poured over it.  It's served with hot mustard here.  The pork itself was pretty good and I love the cilantro that was in it.  But, I prefer it the other way.  Also good was the Chinese Broccoli.  It had a good garlic kick and was still crunchy.  As for the rest of our entrees, again, they were just ok.  Nothing else to say.

There is an upstairs area, which we didn't go to.  But, that just means more seating.  Since we were with the kids at the playground across the street, we saw that it went from no one in line to 15 people in line in about 3 mins.  However, when we got there, all the people were inside and seated and there was still room to fit us at a table.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Solid Chinese place that is open for lunch much later than other places. Good food, fast service.
House fried rice was very good - flavorful and not greasy. Same goes for everything else we ordered.
author: Katherine G.

description: The classic Sam Wo with a contemporary makeup. Great hospitality and great food!!Thanks for coming back!!!
author: Mike C.

description:
WHY I WENT HERE:
- within walking distance of my client's jobsite
- in Chinatown (and a lot of other densely mainland Asia neighborhoods) a lot of businesses will be CASH ONLY, but I chose this place because they accept card purchases, which was convenient for me at the time

THE LOOK (FROM THE OUTSIDE):
- located off Clay St closer to the Kearny St intersection
- it can be easy to overlook considering it's a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown, but the sign indicates they've been around for 100 years

THE LOOK (FROM THE INSIDE):
- clean
- diner feel
- tight seating (which you'd typically find in Asian restaurants)

THE (LUNCH) MENU:
- appetizers
- soups
- rice porridge/jook
- dry mixed noodle
- chow mein
- chow fun/mai fun
- fried rice
- rice plates
- vegetable
- drinks

WHAT I ORDERED:
- tomato beef over rice (蕃茄牛肉飯) [because it was indicated on the menu that it was one of their specialties]

THE TASTE:
- it was honestly just OK for me; the tomato sauce felt like it was what you get from Chef Boyardee, the beef was chewy, and the rice looked like it was instant rice versus regular steamed jasmine rice
- also, the water tasted strange, which could've been attributed to the plastic cup it was served in

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
- this place gets really packed but at the time I got here, it was RIGHT before the lunch hour rush and was hardly busy
- I basically stood there like a loser for several minutes with no acknowledgement from the staff
- it wasn't until they cleared a table that I just finally approached it saying "can I sit here?" and the workers didn't contest
author: Sarah-Lorraine L.

description: Delicious. Tight little spot, feels like we were sitting in someone's attic with tables and chairs. (We sat on the 2nd fl). Ordered bbq pork rolls, wonton soup, beef chow fun, fried spring rolls, chicken and broccoli. All excellent. The waiters weren't really rude like it's been stated above, but I get what people are saying - more like they're overworked! Up and down those narrow stairs all the time from the kitchen! All in all really yummy authentic Chinese food in sf Chinatown.
author: Janet Yejee B.

description:
My friend and I are here for new year parade, and decide to eat lunch here.
A small restaurant, their pork rolls are the best but the only one good. Their porridge has weird taste in it, I don't recommend. Their wonton is plain.
So, the pork roll is 4 stars, the rest are either one or two stars. Their services are average in Chinatown, don't expect a fancy environment.
There's a line for it, so come at the right time, expect to wait.
author: Sihan C.

description: We yelped this one and saw all of the great reviews. So quaint and authentic. Small place but we got right in. Lots of people eating here. Our food cAme out quickly and was great!!! Won ton soup was amazing!! Egg covered beef was a bit greasy. All in all I def recommend
author: Laurie C.

description:
Came here for lunch on a walk exploring San Francisco for our first visit.  We wanted to try something in Chinatown and this restaurant was the highest rated open restaurant.  Came in at a weird hour, around 2:30 pm on a weekday and the restaurant was about half full and closing in an hour.  They didn't hesitate to welcome us in and seat us.  We decided on splitting the chicken chow fun noodles and the string beans.  The food came out fast; like in 5 minutes and the food was fresh and plentiful.  I loved the string beans!  Perfectly salty and crisp tender with just enough garlic.  The chow fun was a little bland upon arrival but after douses of soy sauce and chili sauce it was exactly what we were wanting.  

The restaurant is small and unassuming.  The staff are very friendly and refilled our waters often.  There was one TV with the repeating episode of Conan O'Brien having visited the restaurant a few years back.  Can only vouch for two dishes but the food quality, quantity and price were great!
author: Chelsea M.

description: Really good food and a nice ambience. The kitchen is downstairs and we ate upstairs, they use a dumb waiter to move the food orders between floors. I thought that was pretty cool.
author: Erik P.

description: Sam Wo might be famous for once having the world's rudest waiter, but ours was super friendly and helpful in deciding which dishes to try. Highly recommend the pork fried rice and sweet and sour... each and every flavor stands out - definitely authentic! It might be a small place, but it is so worth it! Reasonably priced, too!
author: Jennifer D.

description: I hold my rating fairly highly for Chinese food, especially Hong Kong style food. In SF, excluding the burbs, this place is as good as they come. They will have all the Staples but I would personally recommend the BBQ pork rice roll with hot mustard. Other than that, this is not a must eat, but a place to satisfy that craving
author: Jaymon H.

description:
You've heard a lot about it, it is as good and as inexpensive as they say it is, nuff said!

BBQ rice roll may not look like much, but when packed with that much "char siu" bbq pork, it definitely stands out.  I didn't get the mustard sauce personally but that's just me, the guys I came with liked it.

Fish Jook was flavorful, subtle and hard to find a good variant in SF!

House special fried rice and the chow mai fun were good, but nothing to write home about.  

Sam Wo has been around for a while, has a loyal following, interior decor may not be much but that's how the best chinese "hole in the wall" places are.  Would return!
author: Alvin H.

description:
If you are expecting an authentic Cantonese food and late night snack, don't go there.
My friend and I lived 20 years in Asia, never seen this kinda cha shu roll in Asia. The skin was too thick, cha shu has no flavor, overall, its like a plain rice paper wrapped some minced cha shu with some cilantro. 
We also ordered beef noodle soup and pork and pork organs jook, the beef noodle soup has no beef flavor, the soup taste like water. The pork and pork organs jook is nothing like the real one.
Most of their customers are non-asian, so if you want some authentic Cantonese/Chinese food, dont go there....
author: Ao L.

description:
I heard a lot about Sam Wo prior to coming and had very high expectations coming into this place. One weekday evening, I came here with a friend and was seated upstairs. At first glance, the interior is pretty cramped, which is to be expected I guess. After much deliberation, I ordered the B.B.Q. Pork Curry Noodle Soup, mostly because that was the one dish that stood out on the menu, apart from the Sampan Jook and the Pickled Cabbage Shredded Pork Mai Fun Soup. 

When my dish arrived, I eyeballed it and there was a scoop of curry powder near the top of the dish, slightly submerged into the soup. Prior to mixing the powder into the soup, the soup tasted a bit bland. After mixing the curry powder in, there was a strong taste bitter-like dish in the soup. I personally thought that there was going to be a thick curry sauce in the soup but I don't think that's how it's normally made. Anyways, the B.B.Q. pork didn't make an impression on me, and the noodles were okay. One thing I couldn't understand was why there was a dash of ketchup atop this dish. The ketchup had no synergy with the rest of the dish and I was left wondering if they meant to put sriracha in there instead. 

Overall, the dish was alright, although I wouldn't recommend ordering the soup dishes judging from this experience. Perhaps I should have ordered the jook instead with a side of Chinese donuts. The service was normal and nothing out of the ordinary. Although I didn't feel satisfied with the soup, I feel compelled to stop by again to try the jook just to be sure that I gave this place a fair shot.
author: Nelson X.

description:
My mom always raved about this iconic place and was always disappointed when she would come to visit and it would be closed, so when I was pretty excited to try it on my own. The food here is very straightforward, comfort food like rice porridge and wonton noodle soup. The ambiance is a lot more ~hip SF vibes~ than the rest of Chinatown...

The fish rice porridge was good but nothing memorable/notable, I would've liked a bit more ginger. Shrimp chow fun was yummy and the chinese broccoli was pretty standard but fresh veggies and tasty. 

I know they used to be known for their blunt waiter, but the people who work here now are seriously SO friendly and sweet. Even though it was crowded they were attentive in refilling tea and taking away dirty plates to free up space. Would come back
author: Hana S.

description:
4.5 STARS!!

REVIEWER # 343

Sam Wo is a historical restaurant that has been in the San Francisco, Chinatown area for YEARS!

My friends and I were having late night drinks in San Francisco and decided to get something to eat to soak up the late-night drinks! Luckily, Sam Wo was walkingu distance from the bars that we had been at so getting there was not a problem. What also attracted us to Sam Wo was that it opens late hours, during the weekends they are open till 3AM! Yayy Baby! Sock up those late night alcoholic drinks! 

The tradition and history of this place and Edsel Ford Fong is amazing to read about. Apparently the restaurant is in a newly opened location (former place was opened in 1912).

My Yelp friends and I entered and was greeted right away from the friendly staff. When you walk in you don't assume that they have an upstairs so I was totally shocked to hear that they had room for a group of 7 people. Less than 5 minutes later, we were being directed to an upstairs that had about 3 big tables. (They totally can cater large groups upstairs, don't let the downstairs seating discourage you). 

What was on the menu? Tons of yummy food! OMG! Its just something about eating after you've had some delicious drinks where EVERYTHING we ordered tasted extra delicious! Let me tell you what we had from the menu:
-Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings
-Beef Chow Fun
-Mongolian Beef
-Wonton Soup
-Shrimp Fried Rice
-Sesame Chicken
-BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll

I was completely expecting to wait a long time for our food but my table was surprised to see the food come out in less than 10 minutes. It was so much food that we decided to eat family style and it was the BEST decision! The portions were super generous and the prices of the food items were so reasonable!  I was able to try everything that was on the table and my favorite was those BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Rolls! OMG! Makes me wonder why I haven't explored this part of the City until now! (Where have I been?)

Overall, great night filled with tons of fun and catching up with friends! I totally recommend Sam Wo if you are in the area! Not only is the food really delicious but the customer service is top notch (Thank you Howard & the rest of the staff! Every 5 minutes the staff continuously checked in with my table and made sure we were satisfied! It was amazing! 

The restaurant was surprisingly clean, as was the restroom. I will definitely be back!
author: Porsche C.

description:
I wanted some comfort food. When deciding what to order for our office lunch, I decided on Sam Wo. Our delivery order arrived on Friday, August 11th around 11:30am via Caviar.

*Chicken Jook: Short grain rice, chicken, scallion, ginger, green onion ($9)
*Chinese Donut: Deep fried strip of dough ($2.25)

My favorite porridge / congee is actually pork and century egg jook (pei dan sau yuk juk), but that wasn't an option through Caviar, so I got the chicken porridge instead. I did note to add pei dan (aka thousand year old egg, preserved egg, etc) which they did. Not sure if we got charged extra for that, but I actually brought an egg from home just in case. I love extra pei dan, so it came in handy. I also noted extra cilantro and green onions which they didn't seem to do. There was a little in the jook itself, but I thought I would get an extra side. I ended up adding green onions I had at work, so it worked out anyways. The jook itself was a little bland to me. I had to add salt and a bunch of white pepper to give it more flavor. The chinese doughnut (you zha guo / you tiao) was delicious. Oily as they normally are, but super savory and comforting. The perfect accompaniment to soak up the jook.

Decent option for jook, but I wished it had more flavor. And I wish I had gotten my extra cilantro and green onion. Overall, 3 stars.
author: Elena N.

description:
I had chicken chow fun with spring rolls. The food was delicious, it's across the street from the park and filled with people. Service is great, it looks really small when you walk in but they have a second floor. 

I was seated right away (I was eating alone) and the food came out promptly. I stopped by around 7pm and it was definitely  worth the walk to get there. 

The food was hot and served quickly had great taste and one plate was more than enough for one person, the spring rolls tasted fresh and they were hot when they came out. The sauce was really good too. I would definitely eat here again
author: Emiko T.

description:
Wow.  This place has been operating for over 100 years?  I was a bit apprehensive entering.

So it is a standard Chinese comfort food/fast food thing, Cantonese style.  I got the dry noodles with Chicken.  (The claim of fame was duck, but I had duck the previous night.)  It was simple, fast, delicious, and made me want to come back the very next day.

I will definitely come back.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Excellent Chinese Food!  Had the Beef Stew Noodle Soup and it was super yummy and had that home style cooking feeling.  Absolutely would go back!!!
author: Paige M.

description:
I love coming up to the second floor to eat.
The narrow stairway, the close and intimate spaces, and the waiter in that bow tie that just brings it every night in terms of exceptional customer service all go hand in hand with some great and (relatively) cheap Chinese food.

On the times we came here to eat, we ended up ordering the following:

Mongolian Beef: Beef is juicy and easy to chew. I like the proportion of the beef to the veggies (onion, bellpeppers). Perfect seasoning and the one dish we have ordered 3/3 times we have been ther.e 

Chop suey: Veggies are steamed perfectly, but otherwise not very notable. They are just assorted vegetables after all. 

BBQ Pork Noodle Rolls: Apparently, this is one of their specialties. The rolls themselves are standard, as it just consists of char siu and cilantro. However, BEWARE of the mustard dip. It's more potent than wasabi. 

This has been our go-to restaurant for a while now (for our first date, NYE, and Valentines weekend), and we'll definitely keep coming back!
author: Viet N.

description:
Open late. HELLA LATE. That's probably the only reason we came since it was one of the only places open at 1 in the morning in Chinatown.

They have downstairs and upstairs seating although upstairs is more comfortable since they have benches and can seat bigger groups of people. Our server that night was extremely nice and helpful and even gave us her honest recommendations. 

BBQ PORK RICE NOODLE ROLLS
Nice light snack. It's a cold dish so it felt like it was lacking a little something since the BBQ pork was also cold. Still, I was too hungry to care. You can dip it in horseradish (also called chinese mustard) but be careful to not dip too much since it's spicy and the feeling travels up to your nose and makes you regret everything.

We also tried one of their chow fun dishes and a porridge. Neither were too memorable sadly.
author: Diana C.

description: Came here for lunch today after seeing such great reviews on yelp. I must say that I left very disappointed. There was nothing special about the foods. Ordered a house special chow mien that came out cold and bland, rice roll with bbq pork that was also bland and cold. Skin of the rice roll was thick and chewy. Also had a order of fried chicken wings which was the only good part of my lunch meal. The skin was crispy and flavor was there. Service was excellent, but definitely nothing special about the foods. I've had much better tasting foods at other Chinese restaurants. This one seems to be the spot for westerners and tourists. I give it 1 star for its excellent customer service and another star for the chicken wings and authentic hot HK milk tea.
author: Lynd A.

description: A classic hole-in-the-wall spot for Chinese food! Make sure to order the pork roll appetizer, it is their specialty, I haven't had anything quite like it anywhere else in China town.
author: Mady M.

description: Classic SF Chinatown. This place has been around for a while and is a staple Chinese style restaurant for Americans (They even have their own documentary!) . I'm a fan of their duck dried noodles. It makes for a quick snack if I need to grab a smaller late lunch.
author: Dion L.

description: Service was great! Small wait time, sigh in on list and make sure to listen for your name. Portions are large especially with soups. All around good food and good service highly recommend.
author: Anna P.

description:
Do not order mapo tofu. This is not fusion, this is simply lousy Chinese food. Minimum effort went into this plate of yuck. I regret paying 10 dollars for it. 

也太凑合了！？随便拿一包榨菜跟锅里热热就端出来跟我说是麻婆豆腐。我听见服务员讲中文了，麻婆豆腐做成这样不配讲中文。 越想越生气还百年老店呢。就算是白人你们也不能给他们喂这种东西啊。你们吃过自己做的菜吗？
author: Rui B.

description:
Very straightforward, simple, and clean dishes. Didn't order any of the house specials or rice dishes--which probably are the better dishes--but the duck jook and wonton noodle soup was fine. I also got fried chicken wings which were ok ( not heavily flavored) but it had a good juiciness to it. I probably wouldn't order it again (I'm used to chicken wings with a jalepeno and basil flavor to it, but these wings only had salt on it).

However, I really enjoyed their Chinese broccoli. The stems had a nice crunch, the leaves had a great garlic flavor, and everything was a nice green color. Their duck jook and pork+preserved veggies were alright. Like I said before, very straight-forward and clean tasting. Nothing tasted extraordinary but everything we ordered had good subtitles (their preserved veggies were a bit on the salty side). Much more authentic Chinese food than those you'd find at the touristy locations on Kearny. 

The best part was talking to the friendly server guy upstairs. He's cool af!
author: Lydia Z.

description: Awesome barbecue pork noodle roll! Wonderful as a lunch snack. Combination wonton soup was also very good, definitely a healthy portion. Barbecue pork was my favorite in the soup too. Got there right before the lunch rush hit so we were seated quickly and service was fast. Over all a cute place.
author: Natalie G.

description: Soooo disappointed!!!! The service is really bad and the waitress attitude was rude. The decoration looks so dirty as well.
author: Ann C.

description:
Delicious.

We went here to just grab some food while out and about in the city and decided to order take out once seeing how small the restaurant seated area was inside. But whether you order to go or table service you don't want to pass up Sam Wo. 

Highly recommend the Mongolian beef and chow fun!
author: Kristin K.

description: Small restaurant with a fabulous selection of fresh food. Make sure you sign in as your waiting in the line... that's step one. Secondly scout the menu as you wait. This place has been in business for 100 yrs because they get You in and out quick... so be ready to order the second your butt hits the seat. The house stir fry noodles were insane. But you're good with just about anything in this place. It looks super small but there's an up stairs... it doesn't take long to get in... I'll be back!
author: Matt H.

description: I come here very often at night because they open late. Not much Chinese restaurant open till 3 am. Every time I come in it is very busy even till the last minute they close. I mostly order for to go but I ate there before. Workers are very friendly. I wouldn't say it's the best Chinese food, other places in Chinatown have better foods. However I do like the ice milk tea!
author: Edmond C.

description: Went to Sam Woo's to order the BBQ pork roll. For $4.99 before taxes you get one roll. Kinda bothered me that the guy who was going to take my money and touching the iPad register was cutting my food too. I don't think I heard water go off for washing hands so I was a little bothered already. Tried the roll and I was disappointed it didn't taste like what I remembered. The BBQ pork isn't sweet with any glazed crust layer. The BBQ in the roll tasted soft but more on a steamed side. There was no cilantro in it. It looked like more stems of cilantro versus leaves. My mom tried it and said the BBQ pork had no flavor, the rice noodle seemed thicker than the old one from their old shop, and she didn't taste cilantro either. So disappointed. Maybe it was just a bad day for the pork roll
author: Helena C.

description: Really nice service, I guess no one can fill Fung's shoes. The food was good enough. Nothing to write home about. Definitely more touristy. The food was somewhere between Americanized and real China Chinese food, well other than the fish jook. That's not Americanized.
author: Lauren R.

description:
On New Year's Eve night in San Francisco, California, I was looking for an affordable Chinese food in Chinatown until I found this place right thru my Yelp app. For over 100 years unless if you've seen Conan O' Brien's sketch segment years ago, this well known family operated Chinese restaurant named, "Sam Wo Restaurant" brings the customers to taste their finest and delicate Chinese foods every seasons long! The atmosphere is much laid back and ongoing as I welcomed there. The concept is much simple for this relocated place. Much spacious for both floors with good ample of tables to sit. The interior design is very modern and contemporary giving this place called home like the revised Jade Fountain Cafe in Sacramento.

The employees from servers and cookers are doing a great job for making the customers like me a sensational service! Very friendly and approachable. No cons at all.

Now onto the food! I ordered the chicken fried rice, and so far as I ate it, it tasted delicious and flawless! The seasoning of that fried rice is top notch and the chicken cooked perfectly for perfection including the rest of the ingredients too. I've heard about their well known appetizer of BBQ Pork Rice Noodle roll for a while. I haven't tasted it after my first visit, yet I'll be back next time in the near future.

Parking at Sam Wo can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearest surface street parking nor the Portsmouth Parking garage (closest) if it's available. Alternatively, you can ride a bike, walk, carpool or public transportation easier without the hassles or gimmicks.

In the end, Sam Wo the most coolest and remarkable local Chinese restaurant that I've ever dined in for the first time to eat good Chinese food for less than $10! Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering of all ages! A well visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: thumbs up ons of the best chinese restaurant in china town. small place but food is great. highly recommend
author: Pau M.

description:
SO happy we were able to have lunch in the iconic Chinatown and especially at Sam Wo. We came in at lunch time on a Saturday. Luck behold they had seats open upstairs and we didn't have to wait. I actually preferred this, less busy and less people walking by you constantly. 

Very cute little hole in the wall Restaurant that has a lot of history in Chinatown. I chose this restaurant because the better half doesn't like anything too crazy in Asian food. They have a great selection of choices. 

I ordered the House Chow Mein and the better half ordered the Tomato Beef Chow Mein. My House Chow Mein was awesome, lots of yummy ingredients that really came in for an awesome flavor. The Tomato Beef Chow Mein is exactly how it sounds. It wasn't great, it literally tastes like tomato soup was poured onto the dish and stirred in. Not saying it was bad, just a little too sweet for our liking. Nevertheless, it was an awesome lunch.

I kept eyeing the fried spring rolls and noodle rolls around me. If I could eat more, I would have definitely ordered those too. They looked awesome!

There was a server that stayed upstairs that took care of all the upstairs tables. He was super kind and gave us menu recommendations. 

I loved it here and I'd definitely return!
author: Alyssa M.

description: This place has been around for many years. I went here with my mom and she said she went 30 years ago! We ordered a BBQ pork noodle roll to start. It was delicious and reminded me of a thick spring roll. Then we ordered chicken chow mein and wonton noodle soup. The broth was decent, but the noodles and wontons stood out with lots of flavor. The chow mein was fresh and was a good portion. This is a classic place to eat when you are in Chinatown SF.
author: Ismael P.

description:
Sam Wo is good, affordable, and approachable.
and Sam Wo is one of San Francisco institution that serves comfort Chinese food that I think is one of the best in the area.
it's kinda hole in the wall but clean and with friendly service.
(since they moved to the new location on Clay st).

I had Pork Noddle Rolls (9/10), Pork Organs (6/10), Dry Wonton Noodle Bowl (9/10).

by the way, get their noodle dishes, it's their specialty.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Definitely at the top of my list for late night Chinese food cravings, or any time for that matter.
Shrimp fried rice, sweet and sour chicken, green beans in black bean sauce were part of my Sam Wo introduction. I was completely satisfied. I can't wait to go back to try more.
author: Derek B.

description:
Came here as nothing else was open and this place is open until 3AM. No wonder why they have great yelp reviews because when you are hungry you gotta eat. Short uber ride here from Fisherman's Wharf where nothing was open. 

This place was a welcomed sight since we hadn't eaten since breakfast. Upon entering you will notice it is long and skinny. We were directed to a table for two. There is hooks above the table for your coats. The waitress immediately asked us what we wanted to drink and we got two sodas. Once we looked at the menu they had notations on their best items. So we ordered the bar b q pork wrapped in noodle and the special fried rice. 

The waitress agreed they were good choices and what she had for dinner. The noodle pork dish arrived. It was served very cold surprisingly but it lacked any flavor. Served with a hot mustard on the side didn't help it and I love Chinese mustard. The house rice however was the best I ever had. It was so light never had such a wonderful rice it was delicious. We were cold so this warmed us up. 

Now for the rating to be fair if I l lived here and came here often maybe a 4 star but the place seemed a little dirty to me and I am fearful of  getting sick on food thus the 3 star rating.
author: Clarissa K.

description:
We must have ordered the wrong food.  We got sat upstairs and was greeted by a very nice waiter.  We ordered hot tea, pork rolls, Chinese broccoli, Singaporean noodles, and the curry beef with a side of rice.  

The pork rolls came out quick and were served cold.  I have a feeling they were made well in advanced and were just pulled out of the fridge.  It was served with a wasabi/mustard sauce which did not go well together.  I had to make my own soy sauce and chili sauce mixture.  3/5

The Chinese broccoli was good, pretty standard, big serving.  3/5

The Singaporean noodles were probably the best.  Again huge serving.  4/5

The curry beef stew came out and there was way too much sauce.  It was overflowing out of the plate.  It was also nothing but fatty pieces of beef served with ginger, onion, and bell peppers.  It also tasted kinda sour.  Could not eat it all after attempting to eat all of the "beef".  2/5

I think we just didn't order the right things.  I'll need to come back and give it another go.
author: Nyla K.

description:
Meet the new Sam Wo same as the old Sam Wo?? 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SHhrZgojY1Q

The new Sam Wo sort of looks like the old one. The location is somewhat close to the old one.

But that is where the similarities really end.

This location is the Disneyland version: 

It is much more cleaner. The old location was so old funky and not clean. The bathrooms were horrendous. The kitchen at the entrance granted easy access to all kinds of vermin.

It is much friendlier. God I miss that old waiter that would just insult you to your face....especially non-asian diners. Although he insulted anyone in his way.

The new Sam wo has a very simple menu...but there is something lacking. The food is very generic tasting. I personally did not care for it!

Maybe late night at the old location with the Broadway strippers getting off work, The coke dealers hanging out....made the old location special.... and the food to taste, somehow, better.

Nostalgia is a funny thing.

But I miss the old location and do not think this location is that good!
author: David G.

description: Genuine Chinese dishes (not contaminated by the Americans' food habits). Tasty, solid! Simple & good ambience.
author: Maria Elice P.

description: Weve been here twice now. Both times there was a wait but it wasn't took crazy. The restaurants just really small. Really good food and the service was just ok. Had to ask for water twice. Also they had a video wall to take free selfies and gifs that you could send to yourself to pass the wait time. Overall I'd recommend to go there.
author: Young-Ju O.

description: This place was okay. Don't see the hype. When you get there you sign in and wait isn't as long. Food was good, not great. My NYC Chinese food is still the best. Just sayin.
author: Murielle C.

description: I ordered the bbq rice bowl noodle which is popular and it didn't disappoint I guess that's their number one weapon I had mine to go which was a good move since the restaurant was crowded
author: Bruce B.

description: The Kung Pao Chicken, while spicy like I asked for, was fatty and rubbery. Singapore noodles were decent, but tasted like a pre-mixed curry noodles Knorr seasoning packet. Wonton soup was on the watery side, and ok at best. The beef chow fun had very few pieces of beef in it, and the few that we could find were either fatty or burnt, while the noodles were flavorless and stuck together in a large lump. Finally, the Chinese donuts we ordered were cold and stale. Considering we came in as soon as the restaurant opened, this was completely unacceptable.
author: Michael O.

description: Yelpers did not let me down.  This place is probably the best Chinese food I have ever had.  And I eat Chinese food alot.  Had the beef and string beans.  The beef was amazingly tender.  Also had the shrimp with rice noodles.  They were delicious.   Highly recommend stopping at this place to eat.  Place is very busy all the time but worth any wait time.
author: Mark B.

description: Authentic Chinese food. Teeny tiny establishment. I was a bit bummed they sat us in a dingy little corner upstairs in a dancing, rocking, rickety table that never got fixed (we asked twice). Had to pretty much flag down the waitress for menus, water, plates, hot sauce, etc. What saves this places is its historical value (established in 1908, closed & reopened) and it is absolutely LEGIT Chinese food. I recommend getting any sorts of fried rice and the egg rolls for sure. Do visit this joint, but he prepared to rough it up a bit. Basically worth it for the food.
author: MariE A.

description: Here are my order comment. Wonton noodle soup: noodle soaked in water too long and lack of elasticity. Wonton tastes ok but not much flavor. BBQ pork noodle soup: noodle & pork tasted very bland. Porridge was ok but it was just a little bit ingredients inside. Overall, it's very disappointed lunch. It's just not the same Sam Woo likes it used to be. This was my last visit.
author: Nancy H.

description: Very good good and the service was great.  Chowfun, fried rice, veggies, all were cooked perfectly...
author: Obaid A.

description:
Sam Wo is a famous San Francisco institution known for an extremely rude waiter, Edsel Ford Fong that worked there back in the day. The restaurant needs no introduction and has been around for over 100 years. The old location required renovations and they closed down for a few years but they're back!

There was a wait on a Saturday night. It gets really busy after 8pm so make sure you arrive early unless you want to deal with a line that is out the door. There is a waitlist at the front for you to sign in if there's a line. It didn't take very long for us to get a table as it was still early in the evening. We ordered some famous dishes that have been highlighted in the reviews. Definitely get the BBQ pork rice rolls served with a side of hot mustard which will help clear your sinuses. Truly delicious on the first bite. The table behind us also ordered the rice rolls and their order was accidentally delivered to our table first. They apologized for the mix up and we ended up getting the order not long after. We also ordered the Mongolian beef, sweet and sour chicken, and stir fry broccoli with garlic. With all that food we needed something wash it down with. A bottle of Snow Maiden sake was served chilled. There was hints of honeydew, pumpkin, and radish in the flavored sake. 

There was no waiter around to berate you or complain about your tip. We didn't get rushed out nor did we get verbally abused. 

They take credit cards including AMEX, which is a rare find especially in Chinatown.
author: Tim G.

description: Great home cooked feel and taste. Quaint, nice staff and very good comfort food. The Chinese doughnut dipped in the preserved egg porridge was very good.
author: Douglas G.

description: This is a small and down to earth place with a history.  I tried a couple times to drop by after it re-opened but it always had a long waiting.  I came almost at 3 pm and found there was no line.  I ordered a simple dish-rice roll with BBQ.  First, it was not served not.  It was a surprise to me.  Second, it was not a lot of taste.  But the rice roll was smooth and filling.  It might be healthy as it is not oily and salty.
author: Flora Z.

description: Old school.  Cantonese. Comfort food. Been serving in SF for over 100 years. I used to come here years ago, so it brings back good memories. Had a Cantonese donut and Shrimp Chow Fun for lunch. Seems exactly as I remember.  Don't expect fancy fusion cuisine, just basic home-style cooking. Open till 3am on weekends. What's there not to like?
author: Carlos D.

description:
Went there for some food a couple of days ago. I was there around 22:00 pm. Service is great; friendly and fun ladies. The food is ok. After I ordered, it came in pretty fast. 

One main dish is enough for 2 average eaters I'd say. Portions are very royal.

A nice place to go if u wanna grab a quick bite.
author: Varun M.

description: Just left this restaurant today for a late lunch. I'm not sure where these positive reviews come. The egg rolls arrived sitting in a pool of oil and cold to the touch. Took one bite and my mouth was filled with cold oil. The sever kid said to let them sit a bit because that's how they are served.  Cold and oily? He should be embarrassed. The bbq pork roll tastes like a few days old chopped ham with cilantro. Not worth waiting for. Move along people. Had to asked twice for the egg rolls to be removed from my bill.
author: Larry H.

description: The food was amazing!  With all the restaurant competition in China Town, this place stands out.  Will definitely be returning next trip to The Bay City.
author: Steve R.

description: When you've been in business 100+ years, you've got to be doing something right. Sam Wo Restaurant is doing just that with their Chinese good eats. Great food, affordable pricing, and an iconic spot in San Francisco's Chinatown. BBQ Pork Noodle Roll is amazing and their House Fried Rice/Noodles are some best around. Hit this place up!
author: Chris K.

description:
I came here because my parents went to the restaurant (at their former location) a lot when they were dating. They told me about the infamous Edsel Ford Fong and how you had to go through the kitchen to get to the dining room on the second floor. I ate there once several years ago at their old location, and I wanted to check it out again while I was in town. I had no idea how famous or how old this place was until I Googled it to get directions.

The new restaurant is a little more organized than the old one, I feel, and from the memorabilia on the walls you can tell they really play up their historical significance, but at the end of the day, the food was cheap, filling, and good. I feel like even if some of the character of the old place might be gone, but it still manages to be everything someone would want from a late night eatery.
author: Charles D.

description:
Came here for takeout. I'm from an Asian heritage, so I was expecting the food to be at a pretty high standard. It met the expectation, what can I say? I got the Chow Mein with Beef and Greens ($8.95). For that price, I was served a huge portion of Chow Mein. I really liked how textured the noodles were, very soft but chewy. Also it grabbed onto the sauce pretty well. My only problem is that the beef was too chewy, not tender at all. Also the greens was a huge piece green onion, which I'm not sure how to eat. 

Overall, good place at good price, no complaining there. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing? Will come back and try again for sure.
author: Vivienne C.

description: Great Chinese food! Fast service, good portions, nice experience in the heart of Chinatown. You can even get a photo postcard when you leave.
author: Lauren J.

description: If you want a mix between Americanized Chinese with some traditional thrown in this is your place. Fried rice and chow main on point. Even had the option of duck! Tried the Chinese donut not my favorite. Tasted like a greasy fried dough ball. Maybe I was eating it wrong and it was meant to go with something? The bbq pork noodle roll was also good. Fast friendly service even with the wait you get in and out.
author: Stacey R.

description: Food was so so.  Unfriendly staff except for the manager.  I recommend the bbq pork roll, it's different from other Chinese restaurants.
author: Thanh H.

description:
Great food, with honest flavors. Had to wait in line for few minutes before getting a table but it was worth it. 

Combination Wonton Soup had several types of meat, with dumplings, and house-made broth. The broth was the best part of it, as it has the creamy taste that you get when you cook it for several hours. 

BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll were a perfect accompaniment for the soup, and the mustard sauce was so good that I had to ask for a refill.

I am coming back!
author: A G.

description:
A fantastic restaurant with tons of history!

The Fried rice, Chow Mein, and the BBQ Pork Noodle roll are all excellent.

Service is super fast and efficient.

There are lots of choices in Chinatown but this is one spot you should not miss. I will make an effort to return every time I am in the bay area.


Check 'em out!
author: Ron R.

description: Wait time was very quick we got seated in about 20 mins at around 1:00pm. Service was okay. You'll probably have to track down a waiter to get more water and/or the bill. Food was really good and hot. Wait for it to cool down a bit ^-^
author: Johnny P.

description: Border line 4.5.  Only because of the lack of seating.  But the tables turn over fairly quick.  We got there at 6.  Party of 2.  Waited for about 15 mins.  The food order went quick and I swear they knew what we wanted before we arrived - it came or quick!!!!  Tasty is an understatement.  Incredible flavors and the meal was stupid good!   I had Kung Po Chicken and Wonton soup.  5 stars for the food for sure.   Ambience is another reason I'd give it a 4.5.  Nothing special.  Just blah. But the food was a 10 out of 5.
author: Lee W.

description:
I've heard of this restaurant before and knew it was a classic favorite of others.  However, it didn't really meet my expectations or blow my mind at all.

The place looks modern and clean.  However, the tables and seats are literally back to back with one another.  I kept brushing up against the guy that sat behind me.  There was a TV screen showing the history of the restaurant and a lot seems to have changed.  The service was great though.  They were very friendly and recognized when we had finished our meals.

I got the BBQ Pork Wonton Noodle Soup and my friend got an egg scramble with shrimp.  My noodle soup was just OK.  I was expecting larger slices of BBQ pork, but instead got strips with barely any bbq parts.  The wonton, noodles, and broth were fine.  The dish was good enough to finish, but I left many pieces of BBQ pork behind.

The prices are decent here and they're open late.  I might come back to try the BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll, but this experience was just okay.
author: Stephanie Z.

description: So yummy definitely a must if you visit China town in San Francisco! My daughters girl scout troop came here for dinner, it was so good, and the staff was awesome with getting the food out fast! Everyone loved it!
author: Adrianne S.

description: Never went the tourist route before so I'd not experienced SF Chinatown before. Went in the middle of the day because we were in the area. Stools and low tables, well worn but mostly clean, didn't go upstairs to see the additional seating. Had the the Wonton beef Chuck noodle soup, duck noodles and fish fillet with bok choy over rice. Disappointed they didn't have roast duck on the menu but the menu was expansive. Beef Chuck, noodles and wonton we're really flavorful. Lots of condiment choices to spice up. Duck noodles were also good but a little to starchy. Fish fillet was a great rice dish. Waitress was responsive and just the right amount of sassy. Not fine dining but I would be here a lot if I lived closer.
author: Rob H.

description: Loved it here! We got the sweet and sour chicken, house fried rice, bbq pork chow mai fun and the bbq pork noodle roll. Everything tasted amazing and the staff was super nice. The prices are also really good everything we got totaled to under $40
author: Lena K.

description: Not sure why the hype.  Food seemed bland to us. Service - they seemed to want to just move people in and out. Won't be back.  If you feel you need to go,  snap the pic and move on.
author: Karen R.

description:
All I can say is eating Chinese food but not tasting the food! Only because they have a old brand called San Wo but the food is really not authentic and tasty. Walk in and get food at 2:00pm, very crowded but the waitress not really have experience handled maybe they are student. Just order the rice noodles soup and ice coffee and get out the restaurant at least 20 minutes. The rice noodles have no taste and it cheap quality food mixed. I am sure I can cook butter than his LOL.. The coffee! OMG it's horrible! I think even MCDONALDS coffee have better than that! 

So for two items cost almost $12 it was insane! Never ever go back again!!! Chinese food only for Tourists and American.
author: Kobee L.

description:
This is by far the worst overhyped Chinese restaurant I've been to. I looked at the reviews at this place hoping to have a great experience. I knew I should've turned back when their audio playback discussed how the restaurant shut down due to health safety. 

The wait to get a seat on a Friday at 2230 at night was probably the best part of the experience because I was really hungry! The worse part of the experience was when they decided to seat me three feet away from the restroom. Customers constantly stood behind me waiting for the restroom and this experience continued throughout the entire time I was there. 

I still decided to give this place a shot as I've been to whole in the wall joints that have horrible service and seating but great food. Unfortunately, this isn't one of those places. Based on other reviews and popular dishes that night, I decided to order the beef wonton noodle soup, a wonton soup (for my wife), and the Chinese doughnuts to share. As soon as I received my order I noticed it looked very bland. Upon the first few bites, I found the food very tasteless with no flavor that it almost made me feel nauseous. My wife and I immediately stop eating, paid for the meal and walked out of the restaurant.

I would never recommend this overhyped place to even my enemies (now that I will have some after this review).
author: Leonardo D.

description: Got terrible food poisoning here from raw undercooked chicken shortly after eating their food and not eating anything else prior. It was so bad I had to see a doctor and was prescribed medicines. Chronic vomiting and diarrhea. I used to think this restaurant was great and historic but I'm sorry I'll never ever come back here again.
author: Bert K.

description: Gluten free menu allowed me to have Chinese Food from an amazing restaurant! Good vibes, very casual hope in the wall.
author: Hannah H.

description:
This place is legend wait for it dary. It's been serving their delicious food for 107 years. The customer service here is spot on. Food is very delicious, but definitely had better. 
We ordered the rice rolls which was really good but the homemade hot mustard sauce was what made the dish 5 stars. Beef stew noodle was probably the best dish that we ordered in my opinion. We ordered jook as well but that didn't really stand out to me, maybe because nothing too special about jook. 

Overall it was a great experience and definitely going to come back here to try the rest of the items on their menu and their specialties items.
author: Christopher G.

description: One star... quite underwhelming. I expect this is rated well as a late night spot. Food was like warm, and underwhelming.
author: Maaiz K.

description:
Ordered Sam Wo on Postmates for lunch cause it was a cold day. I was craving for some good porridge and heard good review about this place.

I got the duck porridge and BBQ rice rolls. It was all delicious! The duck porridge had so much flavor and fatty duck in it. It was so good, I literally ate the whole thing :O the BBQ rice rolls, definitely lives  up to its hype. It was tasty, the rice rolls were chewy and soft and BBQ pork has tons of flavor. Most importantly it was so cheap, my total came out to be $12 :O!! Omg can't go wrong with Chinese food and I had leftovers! 

I have to definitely come back here and actually dine in and try their other dishes!
author: Natalie L.

description: My food was a little too salty but my friends dish was really good. I think if I had gotten something else I would've loved this place. Not too expensive though, and big portions!
author: Rachelle H.

description:
I ended up at Sam Wo as it is one of the few restaurants in Chinatown that is open late. During my first visit I decided to get the beef and wanton noodle soup ($8.99) to-go. After ordering to my surprise Sam Wo took payment via credit card and provided a receipt which is completely out of character when compared to its peers in Chinatown. After ordering it was a short 5 minute wait and I was on my way.

As expected they provided a single container with both the noodles and the broth. This is a problem as by the time you reach home the noodles completely absorb the broth and become soft. I decided to eat this as soon as I got home (which is not too far from Sam Wo). What the soup had going for it was the broth and the wantons. The broth was unlike the watery broth that you get in other Chinese places. It was like the thick broth that you get in good Ramen places. The wantons were also very good. They did seem to tear and split easily but they were good. Obviously what let this dish down were the noodles that were thin vermicelli type of noodles that I am not a very big fan off. The advantage of having thin noodles is that they don't soak up a lot of the broth and become soft.

During my second visit I was provided a menu which was so sticky that it would need to be burnt by people in hazmat suits. Anyway I ignored this and decided to get the same beef and wanton noodle soup to-go. I made a cardinal mistake of asking a question. Can I get the thick flat noodles instead of the standard noodles? Oh man. What a reaction. I was tag teamed by two grumpy servers who made me repeat this over and over again. Finally they scolded me for not knowing that I wanted "fun" noodles and that I should remember this the next time I make such a request anywhere. What? Where is this attitude coming from? Is it so difficult to substitute regular noodles with flat noodles without knowing the technical term for it? I've never faced this problem anywhere else. If there can be no substitution I am told No, but this kind of bad attitude I've never got. I wanted to ask them to give the noodles on the side but after the attitude that I went through to get a simple substitution done, I wisely decided against that. Anyway after ordering it was again a small 5 minutes wait and I was on my way.

This time the experience with the food was worse. The broth and wantons were good but the "fun" noodles had turned to mush. I should have stuck to the regular noodles, would have had a better dish and have avoided the attitude. So remember if you want noodles that can stand in for baby food please ask for "fun" noodles at Sam Wo.

Sam Wo falls into the places that I categorize as "entitled". These places feel that they have a right to give bad service just because they exist. Thank You but I'll pass.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Great food. Long line to get in. Fast service. Why is there a large pair of tongs in the bathroom???
author: Doug M.

description: I am originally from San Francisco but I now live in Dallas, TX and I always have to have Chinese food when I visit!!! This happened to be my last night in the city and everything else was closed and I found this little gem(no like really little) on Yelp!!! We arrived at about 11:45pm and left a little over an hour later and we were so satisfied!! The food was amazing and the service was great!!! The only thing I'd say is that is smelled really bad upstairs and it was so stuffy but overall a great experience!!!! I'll be back at my next visit!
author: Deboni B.

description:
Great hole in the wall chinese establishment.  It's probably more like 3.5 but it might need another trip to see if it's a true round up or round down.

DUCK FRIED RICE: a little oily but super flavorful and full of duck.  There are also chunks of fat and skin but what do you expect.  It was my favorite dish of the day.

CHICKEN CONGEE: super good and flavorful with tasty chicken.  You have to order the chinese donut to eat with it.  It still needed some hot sauce and mustard for me.

WON TON NOODLE SOUP: yum.  Flavorful wonton and soup.  Skinny noodles.  Not my favorite won tons but they were still meaty and tasty.  The broth is tasty but not overly flavorful; I wish the broth had more depth to it.

They DO take credit cards now!

Service isn't the best, but you don't come here for that, and don't ask for it.  Eat the food and be happy you have tasty food on the table.

I think we ordered 3 dishes for 2 of us and all-in it was about $30 total, which is pretty cheap for SF...the days of the $5 lunch are long gone.

Reminds me of a hole-in-the-wall street food version of SO.

There is seating downstairs and upstairs so if it looks full downstairs don't fret and see if they have space upstairs.
author: Traci H.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars for Sam Wo. Even my Chinese parents were pleased / did not criticize the food.

The restaurant seems really tiny when you walk in, but there's quite a bit of seating available upstairs.

What to get:

- Shrimp Fried Rice - Generous portions of shrimp, and pleasantly surprised that they did not overcook it. Rice has yummy fried rice aroma (pretty sure that's the MSG).
- Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings - Super tasty. It sucks that these aren't available on Caviar
- Wonton Noodle Soup
- Jook, if you're in the mood for some Chinese comfort food
- and Chow Fun, always a solid choice

Definitely not something you can get every week, since it's not too healthy, but it hits the spot when you're in the mood for Chinese or if your Chinese parents are visiting town.
author: Grace C.

description:
Sam Wo has been on my Yelp bucket list due to its long history. It is definitely a tourist trap. They sell all types of merchandise and play their DVD on their TV. I did like their interior design and the fact that they had hooks on the walls for hanging your things!

The BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Rolls are much too overhyped in my humble opinion. Everything was just bland and dry. The dipping sauce did not pair well with the roll; I think the chili sauce was the saving grace. The Beef Stew Noodle Soup had a chemical aftertaste. I'd like to believe it was just an off day for the soup. I did enjoy the Duck Chow Fun! This was perfectly seasoned and not overly greasy or salty. Plus, they give you large chunks of duck. I would come back for this when I'm in the area and need a quick bite!

Good luck finding street parking. You're better off paying for parking in the Portsmouth parking garage. You'll be in and out fairly quickly as their service is speedy and efficient, typical of Chinese restaurants. The place is worth checking out once due to its history, but I wouldn't go out of my way to dine here on a regular basis!
author: Kristi T.

description: Must try the special hot mustard sauce with an appetizer. The quantity of food was great. There can be quite a wait time but it's worth it. You can also takeout the food and eat in the traditional park just across the street.
author: Jibraan C.

description: This my is new place to come to when in SF drinking late at night I Came here twice with a group of friends after some late night drinking. Was a little buzzed both times so I can't recall what we ordered but it was good cause I did not do none of the ordering but I do know for sure that it was a decent price and the food is good for after drinking. Will be back next time I'm in the city drinking in this area.
author: Dennis T.

description:
This place has decent chinese food, but the wait was unbelievable. we waited almost 1.5 hrs to get a table for two around 9pm at night. yup. 

Anyway, it is definitely super hyped and I've had better Chinese food elsewhere in the bay/east coast/ abroad. The service is somewhat fast once you're seated. I liked their chow mein and spring rolls, but I've had better mongolian beef and beef broccoli elsewhere.
author: Sophie P.

description: Food was ok. Price reasonable. Restaurant is very small. Wait staff was nice but I felt really rushed to place the order so they can have the table to someone else.
author: Betty H.

description:
Came after watching an old Conan ep, that and a quick yelp search vaguely for 'Chinese food'. Maybe we didn't order the right stuff, but the food we ordered didn't taste that good. And, most of the people in the shop looked like tourists. 

We ordered Kung Pao Chicken and Mongolian Beef, which is only listed on their take out menu, but we ate it there. At ~$12 per plate, it's not exactly one dollar sign. That's about how much I'd pay at any other Chinese restaurant. The taste was also not that great. Feel like I could have gotten better elsewhere. Probably won't come back again, but it's an interesting little shop with a long history.
author: Cynthia X.

description: Came here late night after first Friday's. Open till 3 with really sweet servers. Only negative thing I have to say about it is that the msg in the fried rice literally gave me the worst headache.  Heads still hurting a day later. Way too much salt. Mongolian beef was yum though! Would go back late night but would want to try something different.
author: Ads C.

description: I saw this restaurant while in San Francisco yesterday and thought to try their food. What caught me was the "100 years" subtitle. Me and my family came right ween it opened and got seated at a table near the restroom, which was not really okay with me, but at least it didn't smell. We asked the lady serving us what she recommended since we're from Seattle and has never ate their food before. She recommended some good ones and we ordered. The BBQ Pork Noodle Roll was pretty good. I thought it was a good appetizer. We also ordered the House Chow Mein and the House Fried Rice, which I have to say were the best out of everything we ordered. We also ordered the House Chow Fun and the House Chow Mai Fun. They tasted good, but I liked the Chow Fun a bit more than the Chow Mai Fun. Anyway, the reason why I'm giving three stars is because the meal didn't really satisfy me. Yes, the food was good and I do recommend going here. But, it wasn't the best food I've ever had out of Seattle. It is a pretty small place and also has more tables upstairs. It was pretty interesting to find out that this restaurant once had the rudest waiter in the world though. Might come back here again, but won't guarantee it.
author: CoolDoge G.

description: It's been years since I was at the original Sam wo. I'm happy to say the new location has all the flavor and feeling of the old place! The dry mix pork noodle is a savory as I remember it from my younger days
author: Capt R.

description: Amazing late night chinese food, found a seat with no issue. Service was quick and the food was delicious. There was a documentary about the restaurant playing on the TV, which was quite interesting.
author: Nate C.

description: Must have in China town and they open late !! We ordered the Chinese donuts with pork and liver porridge  so good !
author: Jiechen S.

description: wow great chinese at VERY affordable prices.  Take a wok thru china town and finish up at sam wo
author: Doug G.

description:
The food is ok. There are better tasting restaurants in the area. I got the bbq pork noodle soup; the pork wasnt flavorful since it seems as if it was soaking in water before it was served. I've also had their beef tendon; not bad but not very flavorful. 

Its a good spot for tourists since its nice and clean with pretty good service.
author: Ernest M.

description: I was not feeling too well after the air trip. So I want rice porridge and found this place. It end up pretty well. The porridge did come in a big portion and comfort my stomach. The BBQ pork rice noodles roll is surprisingly good. Even though the menu is simple, they do the right thing! I would recommend this restaurant.
author: Shuang Q.

description: Good food, small and tight seating. Servings were nice size and staff is helpful. Great backstory on the history of this place too shown on the TV while dining.
author: Dan F.

description: Good spot for a bite in Chinatown. Very small, but we only had about a 15 minute wait for lunch on a weekend. Had the beef and bok choy chow mein. Pretty standard, but very good. Nice staff and speedy service.
author: Rob L.

description:
I love the fact that this self-professed "hole in the wall" has been around 100 years. In fact, this is the reason we were willing to wait around to grab a bite to eat. The decor is very much old, which I believe is the restaurant's intended feel. The service was so-so. I guess that's expected in a place that's always packed. Prices were decent. 
However, (to me) its all about the food. Sam Wo was really overall a let down particularly with the items containing meat. The wonton, beef and broccoli, and sesame chicken all left something to be desired. It was likely lower quality meat because some pieces were tough, others were fatty, and so forth. The rice was a little bland but acceptable. The spring rolls were good and the old-world feeling was memorable. If you're looking for top notch food, try elsewhere.
author: Oscar C.

description: Liked the food, service soso my only complaint is that they don't have smaller portions or combination plates for one person dining in. I'll probably go somewhere else when I visit SF in the future.
author: Klzlad D.

description:
This restaurant is aggressively mediocre. Most of the dishes were bland (the congee, chow fun, BBQ noodle rolls). I have been eating these dishes all my life and have experienced them in a variety of ways/preparations. 

While there, did not see any Asian customers, a indicator for who the restaurant is successful with. This might explain the inflated 4-5 star rating Sam Wo is getting. The place is small and you might have to wait to get a seat but why bother when the food is so bad? 

In short, if you have experience with Cantonese foods, avoid.
author: Zhiwan C.

description: We went to San Francisco and looked up the best Chinese food in Chinatown. Sam Wo was #2 and the food was delicious! We got house chow fun and house chow mein. Totally recommend it!!
author: S S.

description:
This was one of the most disgusting Chinese restaurants I've ever been to, it was dirty and the food tasted awful.
