I also hated one of the dishes, it tasted like it had gone bad and when I said something they just said sorry. I wasn't even asking for my money back I was trying to exchange the dish for another dish because I felt that this one might be rotten but they didn't let me do it. And thus was the manager too which was even more surprising.

You've gotta have good customer Service if you expect people to come back. Maybe if they were super apologetic and quickly exchanged the food and the next dish had nothing wrong with it I would be back. But never again!
author: Aram K.

description: So so food and the portions are too big. You can do better somewhere else in the neighborhood. If you like szichuan, try Z&Y
author: Mark K.

description:
I wasn't impressed by their food at all, even at low prices in SF's standard.  Good portion but the taste wasn't there. More of a comfort food-ish restaurant for local Chinese folks.  

They mostly serve noodles and fried rice...no gourmet dishes to be found here...

Not recommended.
author: Straight N.

description: Came near closing time and they were out of beef chow fun (just the noodle) so prepared the lo mien dish for me instead. It was delicious and the kitchen was quick to get the food out. Service was polite and they were hustling to get me to a table even though they were super busy.
author: Sarah T.

description: Great authentic food. We ordered the BBQ pork roll (great ) and the very good chow mein and fried rice.
author: Jimmy Z.

description:
When the original Sam Wo closed down.. I was a tad bit sad about it since I had gone here a few times with my husband. I also was already moved out of the city by the time the original Sam Wo closed so I thought i'd never be able to eat there again until they later opened this location.

I originally went to chinatown to try that new Chinalive thing. First.. didn't know its only opened for dinner. It also JUST HAPPENS to be closed on the Sunday I went there to try it. I ended up walking around and remembered Sam Wo had reopened elsewhere so Hubbie and I headed over to give this place a try.

The BBQ Pork Rolls were good. I don't like the sauce they serve with it but the rolls are definitely a must. Hubbie ordered... I think it was Egg & Beef over rice.... it did NOT look appealing at all. Super heavy and covered in gravy. He also said it wasn't the best and wasn't too happy with the dish. I ordered a wonton noodle soup. I didn't know how much of a difference it was from ordering the normal wonton noodle soup to the combo wonton noodle soup (actually can't remember what its called but there was a few different options of wonton soup). My soup came out very bland. I wasn't too pleased with my dish either. I was expecting a flavorful hearty bowl of wonton noodle soup. Our salt & pepper Chicken wings were just DRENCHED in salt. I wish they didn't cover it in salt because the chicken itself was actually quite juicy. But that salt just ruins everything. Most chinese restaurants that make this appetizer isn't as salty but here at Sam Wo....it made me feel like i just took a tablesoon of salt with a hint of chicken. The food here.. aside those rolls....really reminds me of those Chinese restaurants that don't make a lot of business type of comfort food. 

Honestly... if you come here to eat. JUST GET THE ROLLS. I don't really recommend getting anything else as the flavor and taste of the food has changed drastically NOT for the better. They are quite crowded here... I guess all the tourist and news about this place really helped this small tiny restaurant get tonssss of people in. Hubbie was even saying... you mainly see a lot of white people here and not too many Chinese people here. I think that says something if Chinese people don't eat here.
author: Linda L.

description: Late go to on my way home from work and gym. If you're in nob hill its convenient and an SF staple. Dine in, its better.
author: Rj F.

description: It was really good, Chinese food  isn't my favorite but this place really hits the spot! Their noddles with their sauce is like heaven. Not to mention their really friendly with helping people and their service. I would eat here again.
author: Karen F.

description:
THIS IS THE WORST RESTAURANT EVER! 
Their entire ratings are a fraud. Terrible customer service, PASSIVE AGGRESSIVE staff. 
Don't go unless you want to feel humiliated.
author: Jiabo F.

description: House chow fun hit the spot! Great customer service and delicious food! Just like back in the day.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Maria P.

description: This place has amazing food and fast service! My fav is the salt & pepper chicken wings and the chicken with string beans (amazing!) Def a must in SF!
author: Slop S.

description:
Open late night! Super easy to walk to from nob hill or north beach! Recommend for great service, low prices, tasty food, and good time. Try the bbq pork roll, it's like dim sum, sushi, and bbq pork all at once!

Love the hole in the wall feel, there is also seating upstairs though! Also, there was plenty of seating, even though nothing nearby was open!
author: Kimia M.

description:
Inexpensive, late-night dining in Chinatown.  Small space, but there wasn't a crazy line.  The *** BBQ Pork Curry Noodle Soup *** is delicious!  That alone warrants 5 stars.  Hard to find elsewhere so definitely try it here.  

Sam Wo has a long history in SF.  It's worth checking out if you've never been.
author: Jesstine G.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurants of San Francisco. I went with my family and all really enjoyed. We recommend the Wings, the fried broccoli and the duck noodles. Truly everything is great.
The tea is good too
author: Maria Alejandra B.

description: To me, this is not edible Chinese food... It's an abomination to Cantonese/ HK food. Got the rice roll with pork inside. The rice wrap was thick on cold. The pork inside is not the right type used in this type of dish. Also ordered the porridge. It's thick and the grain of the rice is too large.
author: Anthony W.

description: Found this place through Yelp after walking to Chinatown and my wife getting "hangry" as she calls it. Not an elaborately decorated place but has some history and great food at a reasonable price. I had the sweet and sour pork and my wife had the combo fried rice, with spring roll appetizer. All less than $10 each. All delicious. Seemed like a popular place with a lot of regulars despite being one of many options and not too elaborate. They show a video of the history which proved interesting as we enjoyed our meal.
author: Gary G.

description:
Sam Wo Fo Sho. 

We ordered the bbq rice rolls, chicken jook (aka rice congee), and duck dry mixed noodles. Enjoyed dem all, especially the noodles. The noodles looks pretty simple, with shredded lettuce atop. Yet, the noodles' sauce is flavorful and not too overpowering. The chicken jook was pretty plain, yet I appreciate that it wasn't infused with doses of MSG. Add some white pepper if you want more flavor. The popular bbq rice rolls were tasty. That mustard on the side is some wasabi hotness. 

Sam Wo is a clean, slightly modern looking hole-in-the-wall, as they reopened recently. It doesn't have that grungy feeling. Affordable prices, popular place, and friendly service. I'll come back. 

PS- This place is across from Portsmouth Square Park. That is where all the Goong Goong and Pau Pau's of Chinatown hang out. Local vibes for you. Come see dem grandpa's throw it down over cards. It's their turf.
author: Joanna L.

description: Best Chinese Food In SF Hands Down. Even After A 100 Year's The Ho Family Has Been Putting It Down. My Boyfriend's First Time & He Loved It. Definitely Will Be Back. The Price Is Definitely Right For The Quality & Quantity Of Food. This Is For Sure A Historical Monument For Chinatown & San Francisco.
author: Cristal P.

description:
Having lived in Asia for the past 20 years, we were very excited to try this one out. Unfortunately we don't get the hype. 

Ordered the roll, gotta say cha siew was great however the skin was way too thick. Porridge and noodle was okay (not mind blowing). I'm not sure if we came at the wrong time, ordered the wrong thing or maybe what they offer suits more to American tastebud?
author: Hester D.

description:
Was it worth the 30 minute wait? Sure, because the BBQ pork noodle rolls were so good!

TIP: the first thing you do when you enter this place is to WRITE YOUR NAME AND NUMBER OF YOUR PARTY DOWN ON THE CLIPBOARD! Don't just stand there expecting some hostess to greet you. We saw so many people just stand there and expect some magic to happen. No. Get to work. Do your deed. Your name will be called. Don't worry.

Plain wontown soup is just like the name. Plain. Soup is plain, so skip this dish. I will go with a jook if you want something soupy.

House fried rice was great! The portions are huge. Two girls who CAN EAT still had leftovers. It's a combination of beef, chicken, egg, and love.

Make sure you order the BBQ pork noodle rolls. You won't regret it!
author: Bin H.

description: Chicken and duck chow mein are delicious! We would order again. The spring rolls were too greasy. We just did take out so I can not comment on table service but the woman working take out was pleasant and efficient. Our order was prepared quickly.
author: Lisa D.

description:
the worst mediocre asian food i've ever tasted in my entire mediocre food tasting career

didn't come in w high expectations and was still disappointed

mapo tofu- a salt bomb

wonton mien- very bland space filler 

chow fun- what was this supposed to be????

nice people, terrible food
author: Amy C.

description:
Sam Wo is an institution.  Open for a 100 years (or something like that) and having the worlds most famous rude waiter (according to the menu), Sam Wo is a restaurant that received enormous press when it burned down and had a prolonged and well published effort to remodel and reopen. 

How come is it that I've never been? (And I've been going to Chinatown all my life) 

Admittedly, Sam Wo was our third stop for a late night snack (they're famously open until 4 am), but I wanted to check out what the fuss was. 

Luckily, we dropped by just as a seat opened but a line of tourists and regulars alike soon lined out the door.  My first bad sign: I didn't see a lot of Chinese people. 

The menu was a simple one and highlights include their chow fun, fish jook, and BBQ pork rice noodles.   Service was very friendly from both the cashier (owner?) and staff.  English is the language of choice.  Our order:

Fish jook - $7.50.  A large and generous bowl of jook with plentiful scallions and lots of minced ginger was ready very quickly and we took a sip.  Temperature was luke warm to cold.  My wife said it probably was served piping hot.  But they just delivered it! I reminded her.  Maybe it's the cold ginger and scallions.  As an SF native, she had more experience with Sam Wo and perhaps her nostalgia was impeding her judgment. 

I liked the chunks of quality fish but found even the jook average.  Not cooked long enough and no flavor in itself.  I poured on Chinese pepper and it was little better.  Pass. 

I thought perhaps that Sam Wo was the real deal but I'm much more fond of Sam Woo (from SoCal and Vegas).  Maybe there is a reason I've never been.  Give me Hing Lung for jook instead.  

I probably should come back to try more one dish but Chinese friends more familiar says it was an institution but more for longevity than anything else.  I'm good. 

Sam Wo sells merchandise including t-shirts, hot mustard sauce and I think accepts credit cards.  Too touristy for me.
author: Randy F.

description:
Sam Wo is a classic spot stacked in a San Francisco Style with all the charm of a family-style Chinese spot. There was very fast, no-frills service complete with a menu boasting standards from rice porridge to noodle soups.  The vegetables were super fresh and consequently helped to avoid the heavy feeling one can have after eating Chinese. The Hong Kong milk tea wasn't too sweet and a good partner to the meal. The noodle soup was perfectly portioned between noodle, broth, and vegetable. Tip: Take that soup home and add a fried egg. Bless up. 

Ordered: BBQ Pork Rice Roll, Stir-Fried String Beans, Chinese Broccoli in Garlic, Vegetable Dry Noodle, Vegetable Noodle Soup, Curry Chicken

Could have done without: Dry Noodle (instead try rice porridge)
author: Hope J.

description: It was okay. Came here for lunch today (by myself) and was quickly seated. Very very very tiny, but heard they have seating upstairs. I ordered the Beef Chow Fun, which was cold and lacking flavor. It was okay -- it got the job done (I was hungry and craving comfort food), but didn't even take the rest to-go because I didn't like the flavor too much. When digging through the noodles, I found a few spots of noodles that were perfectly white, meaning there was no sauce or anything. I will try this place again, but definitely not ordering the Chow Fun.
author: Zoe Y.

description: Great restaurant with friendly service, cozy atmosphere, and affordable food. Both dining rooms were clean.
author: Evan G.

description: Fantastic food, no frills ambience. There was a line when we arrived but we were seated fairly quickly. Ordered the pork bun rolls that they are known for, green beans, and shrimp chow fun. Chow fun wasn't bad, green beans and pork bun rolls really wowed me! Got in and out quickly with satisfactory service. I can see why this place have been in business for 100 years.
author: Hilda L.

description: Sam Wo has great reviews, was even advertised on I believe Conan O'Brian show. It's great for late night, it's a small hole in the wall, grungy yet that cute feel of a Chinatown restaurant. The food is okay, I ordered the kung pao chicken which was different from many I have had before, the fried rice is definitely not like the fried rice I've had, I wasn't a fan of it. The prices are decent, the wonton soup was good, so was the Chinese milk tea. I have mixed feelings about this late night joint
author: Joseph M.

description: Make sure to write your name on the waiting list. There is not a hostess.   Great food unique choices. Like the duck fried rice excellent. The oyster beef awesome. The crunchy spring rolls. Hot (temp) delicious. Fast and friendly service. I gave it a 4 simply because it's a hole in the wall and there were small things forgotten. However would visit again for sure!
author: Monique S.

description:
Always a nice surprise to find places like this in Chinatown.  Most are touristy and food subpar.  I didn't realize how long Sam Wo has been around until we came in and read it on their menu.  Definitely an institution after 100 years!     

Everything we ordered was good.  Not too greasy and salty.  My ultimate favorite is the raw fish salad.  So much happening in my mouth with so many flavors coming out.  Packed full of flavor and textures.
author: Naty D.

description:
Hands down my favorite Chinese restaurant in the entire bay area. AND THIS REVIEW IS COMING FROM A CHINESE PERSON!!

I can go on and on about how much I love and adore Sam Wos....

1. They've been around for over 100 years! Through hard work and delicious food they've stood the test of time.

2. They treat you like family. Service is great even though it's constantly busy and one of the waiters even asked if me and my friends had any other plans for the rest of the night - so friendly!

3. They're open late! Wednesday & Thursday they are open until 12AM and Friday & Saturday they are open until 3AM. Doesnt get better than that for your chinese food cravings at standard & reasonable prices.

4. Free tea on the house (as every Chinese place should offer) and the best tasting Chinese food without going to China. My friend and I shared the Ma Por Tofu rice plate & beef chow fun family style and my mouth is drooling just thinking about it. Yummy authentic deliciousness!!

 +1 bonus star for Conan filming a special at Sam Wos :) That's all they play on the TV facing the front if you're sitting in the back.
author: Jessie W.

description:
Don't be fooled, this isn't the same as Sam Woo in SoCal.

The food here is very mediocre. The stir fry noodle dishes here lack "wok hay" and are mushy and flavorless. Their rice porridge is the same. Wonton noodles are also mushy.

The only dish I'd recommend is the bbq pork rice roll with their mustard dipping sauce.

If you're craving Chinese food late at night, this is the place to go. But if there are other options open and nearby, I'd skip this place.
author: Shirley H.

description: I feel like another 5 stars review for them is redundant at this point but the food was just unreal. Don't forget to get the pork roll appetizer.
author: Larry H.

description:
Dinner review. 

Fried spring rolls - 3/5
Salt pepper wings - 4/5
Duck fried rice - 4/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
We came here for morning brunch on the last day of our staycation in SF.  It's the new location for Sam Wo since the original one closed down for health-code violations.  I would usually avoid places like this, however the restaurant is 100 years old and has attracted a cult following along with notoriety of having a legendary waiter who was "rudest in the world."  Now they sell T-Shirts and have an cleaner, updated location.  No grumpy curmudgeon waiters but young, charming waitresses.

Foodwise, I'm giving 3 stars based on our food selections:

Dry duck noodles were decent - slippery round noodles with shredded duck meat.  4 stars.

Fish Congee - I didn't try but my wife enjoyed it.  It looked thick and viscous.  

Combo Won Tons - I liked how they added shrimp, char siu, veggies, and beef into the broth.  The wontons themselves have chestnuts for crunch but are mostly ground pork.  Not bad. 3 stars.
author: Daniel C.

description: This place has some of the best shrimp fried rice I've ever had. My fiancée and I were walking around San Francisco and spotted this gem that had a bunch of reviews with 4 stars which was good enough for us to try. As soon as you walk in you put you write your name on a list and they will sit you and one of 8 or 9 little tables they have. The staff were sweet and recommended some good beer and of course food that all tasted great. Don't waste your time at places around Chinatown that have 2 or 3 stars......come here you won't be disappointed. Super affordable too I spent about 25 bucks for us both and it was only because I was drinking beer. Would've been less without it.
author: Robert G.

description:
Good for kids. Good place to go in Chinatown if you want clean and a place where you know the menu. Good wonton soup, although a bit bland. Fried rice is also a tasty dish for kids; egg rolls a bit too greasy. Atmosphere is Quaint and eclectic. Price is decent for soups and appetizers. 
     Easy to get to with cable car and one block from the bustle of Grant Avenue shops. I would go again and I recommend if you want to try Chinatown.
author: Caroline H.

description: This restaurant has been around for over a hundred years but has moved location. I love the new place, very clean, casual and hip. When we entered, we were greeted by the owner (didn't know he was the owner till we left) and he was absolutely friendly! We went for a midnight snack so we order the BBQ pork noodle soup (with egg noodles), salt and pepper chicken wings and the fried spring rolls. The pork noodle soup was good, nothing extraordinary but good enough for comfort food. The chicken wings were delicious and so were the fried spring rolls. The place is clean, affordable, food is good and service was excellent! Would definitely go back!
author: Karissa A.

description: I had the beef stew wonton soup, too greasy for my taste. The appetizer which was a pork roll and also the duck noodle were decent.You get what you pay for so do not have great expectations.
author: Cristian A.

description:
Much improved location.

Food is generally good, service fast and pleasant.

Open till 3 a.m. Fridays and Saturdays but get there by midnight well before the bar/club crowd start lining up.
author: Inigo M.

description:
The wonton noddle/BBQ soups were just OK. They were not horrible but they were not good either. 

They basically did not have any flavor. The broth and noddles were very bland. 

I unfortunately did not see the hype surrounding the pork rolls. The cilantro was the best part..

This review is just for the wonton noodle and wonton BBQ soup as well as the pork rolls. I will say that as we exited there were other entrees that looked good...maybe we just picked the wrong stuff?
author: Josephine S.

description:
Love this place!  Today I was walking home and decided to order their charsiu rolled noodles.  They have done a nice job remodeling but what I love is their menu is similar to what I ate growing up as a child.  Being closed for several years was missed as I always did a walk through Chinatown to get dinner.  So glad they are back.  They have extended hours on Friday and Saturday to 3am!!!

Very clean and friendly staff!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Quite possibly the worst rendition of this type of Chinese food I've ever had. The BBQ pork rolls were somewhat palatable, but the Beef Chow Fun was a mess - bitter burnt bits, completely overcooked and mushy noodles, and worst of all, weirdly flavorless. Not even underseasoned - it barely had any flavor at all (not sure how this is remotely possible with a dish that's flavored with soy sauce).

Please avoid this place, there are plenty of places to get this type of food with no wait and better execution.
author: Kevin L.

description: Disappointed. We went here due to the 4 stars and the long line. I ordered the pork liver & pork organ jook, plain jook, beef stew rice noodles soup and beef stew noodle soup. They are all BLAND. It's not like we haven't tasted authentic Chinese dish, both cheap and expensive, both local and in Hong Kong. It's literally no taste. It's like it's catered to geriatric patients with extreme hypertension, CHF, etc. that requires extremely minimal to no salt diet. Alas, a long day's tiring tour looking forward to good food just to end up beyond disappointment. Plus server said it's supposed to be salty and when we said the were bland, she said they serve it that way.... huh? Mine had to have so much salt and soy sauce just to be tolerably palatable. See my "before any seasoning" pic and after putting a gazillion soy sauce!
author: Maryanne Rachel C.

description:
Definitely a good, reasonably priced meal. Good service, nice sized portions. We had the green beans, tofu dish and veggie lo mein. Not a lot of differentiation compared to a take out Chinese place. 

Atmosphere is a bit dingy, but I think that's what the makes the place pretty cool. 

I'd go again but would probably look for another spot to try out before.

Added to my list of SF Chinese
author: Alexander C.

description:
Found Sam Wo randomly for a late night Chinese food run.  

What a great surprise.

Turns out this place has been open for over 100 years and as some of the hottest mustard, tastiest BBQ pork rolls, and delicious noodles in town.  

Highly recommended.
author: Ed L.

description:
Several years (two? one?) ago over lunch break a friend of mine and I went to Chinatown during our regular lunch walk. I saw a sign that says Sam Wo was closed due to building safety reason. Sam Wo was special to me. When I was just out of college, I liked to go clubbing on Saturday nights. There used to be this dance club atop of Westin St. Francis, called Oz. On Saturday evenings, it had a disproportionately large number of older white male population (30s-40s) to the female and younger Asian (early 20s) population. Every Saturday after the club was closed, my friends and I would come here, hungry and giddy, in stilettos and short skirts, almost always with some misc. white men in tow. We always sat upstairs, always ordered the same duck wonton noodle soup for everyone at the table, and always ordered them in Chinese. It was the best, cheapest food in town at 2:30 AM. 

There was something really surreal about this restaurant, it felt like it should be from an old movie, so Chinese, so Asian, so different than the rest of the city. We enjoyed shocking our white guests as much as we enjoyed the food. We repeated this routine week after week, for years on end. 

That memories gradually faded with the end of an era.

A few months back, I read on the paper that the restaurant had reopened and moved to a new location. It made me to want to return; if anything, I wanted to see if the food was really as good as I had remembered. 

Sam Wo has not really changed that much. They still have an upstairs and downstairs. They had old sign that says "open until 3 am." There was still a dumbwaiter system but newer than the old, and they seem to bring dishes by walking upstairs instead.

As I sat and waited for my duck wonton noodle soup (off the menu, just order that and they know because it was not on the menu 20+ years ago either), I posted a picture of the restaurant on FB. One of my girlfriends said, "What? Is it still there?" She remembered coming here in the 80s with her friends. Some old Chinese waiter would yell at them, and she, then a blonde blue eyed young girl born and raised in the Bay Area, always complied with his order out of fear. "The food was so good that I didn't care. Those are some of my best memories." She added.

Sam Wo is a 100 years old, according to its signage.  It serves authentic San Francisco Chinatown Cantonese food. I know it's a mouthful but it's super important to note that. You can't get this anywhere else, not in Canton province, not in Hong Kong, not in Macau, not EVEN on Clement or Irving or Noriega street. ONLY in San Francisco Chinatown. It's still super inexpensive. And, it seems that everyone has a story of their own with Sam Wo. 

It's a real San Francisco institution. And now it's reopened, I trust new memories will be created for generations to come.
author: Victoria E.

description:
This place is probably the OG of hole in the walls? I didn't know much about this place until my sister recommended it to me. We went there around 7pm, and it was pretty packed already. The place is REALLY tiny, however cozy? Not only do they have seating downstairs where you can see how they prepare their dishes, but also seating upstairs which is more modernized. We ordered their porridge, their famous bbq pork crepe rolls, and their chicken wings. I really enjoyed the crepe rolls, I've never had anything like it. If I could describe the taste, it would probably be like one big spring roll. My sister raves about the horseradish sauce, for me however, I don't like spicy. One dip of that and my nose was shocked, lol. I really like cilantro and the crepe had plenty, so thats probably why I liked it. Their fried chicken was also really good and fresh. It was super crispy and perfectly seasoned.

customer service wise, they're famous for their notorious rude server, but the ones we had were very friendly. they had a few slip-ups with the food orders but it wasn't a big deal. It's super busy there so they were running around. I'd probably come back again if I were craving the crepes, since it's pretty unique.
author: Lisa L.

description:
It's been 5 years since I visited Sam Wo. It was in the old location last time I was there. I was in town and decided to hit the new spot. I must say it was more than I expected. The old place was a dive but it was great food and service. Today they have the same great food, service AND a clean impressive location....They kept the same coziness with the upstairs seating and some small tables in the kitchen level.

Now to the food:  The bbcue pork roll appetizers were as good as I remember...FRESH AND TASTY...and don't forget to dip in the spicy mustard... Also had The pork fried rice, sesame chicken, vegetable chow mein, salt/pepper chicken and wonton noodle soup.  (Not just me, There were 5 of us)...Also a welcome treat, wait for it................
BEER!!!! A tsing Tao to enjoy with my meal...They have secured a liquor license so no more brown bagging it from the place across the street!!! 

All in all 5+ stars...I'm old school been a fan since the mid 90s when I lived here. I kinda didn't like the tv's and the commercials playing with celebs etc. it takes away from the local hideaway late nite spot I remember but that's the only negative I have .... still 5+ stars. Also can't end without a shout out to the staff, especially Howard who made us feel at home and had a great attitude and excellent customer service.  When I'm in town I will be back....
author: The F.

description: Best place for late night meal.. price,  Quality of food and service... Consistent taste ,flavor ,  been going there for many years...The porridge on a cold evening ,, totally hits the spot...
author: Jonathan L.

description: Good food....NOT GREAT, but good!  Service was just OK.  Very nice servers, but they tended to forget about our group of four for a short time.  I highly recommend sharing plates, as everything is so different.  If salt is not your thing, either don't eat here or beg them for low sodium dishes.  I was drinking water for hours after the meal!  Home of the World's Rudest Waiter, but he passed away many years ago....still a fun place to experience.
author: Gregg R.

description: So another Yelp recommendation for the win!! It's like 9:30pm and we don't want to be too far from our hotel, Yelp helps us find this dive. Open until 3am and it has great reviews. Sketch walking to it so late at night. However, the place is packed. I'm surprised how fast we got a table. But then we order and get our food pretty quick and then I understand; they are efficient, getting your order in quickly, cooked fast and then you enjoy the tasty! Win-Win-Win!! The food was not greasy, not overly salty and veggies were fresh a crunchy. It's been open for over 100 years and I can see why. They are friendly and welcoming. It's definitely a place I'd go to again and recommend to others!
author: Danielle P.

description:
On a random weeknight, my sister and I were determined to have dinner in the city. I escaped work a little early to beat the traffic but there was none, haha. I used to live in San Francisco and I go quite often so I knew my way around. 

Walking here from Union Square took no more than 15 minutes. No hills but you go up Powell then be prepared to burn calories from the incline. The restaurant opens at 6 for dinner service. We got there around 6:15. I am so glad we came when we did because not too long after, the restaurant was packed! 

Service was commendable. The gentleman spoke fluent English, was funny, welcoming, and knew the menu by heart. He convinced us to order the BBQ pork rice roll (banh cuon). This one is served w/ their spicy mustard (like horseradish) and I did not care for it (I used regular soy sauce) but seriously, after my initial bite, I kind of stayed silent for a few seconds because it was THAT good. The Chinese donut was fried perfectly and was a perfect addition to the chow fun. Though it was funny and cute that Gavin thought I ordered him an actual donut. The chow fun was delicious (dry-style). The wonton soup was good, I assume since my sister finished that w/o uttering a complaint. The Chinese chicken salad was huge! Definitely order this because it was filled w/ lots of chicken (super tender and juicy) and it was cheap! 

Not expensive but pricier than what I normally pay at a Chinese restaurant but I can say that I now know why this place gets packed and gets raved reviews. Man, I will order the entire menu next time!!!
author: Tram N.

description: We traveled to San Francisco from Providence RI which is devoid of good Chinese food. Took a cable car to China town. After about an hour of walking around, we were directed to Sam Wo's on Yelp. We entered at around 8 PM and were seated in 15 minutes. Very Quick service and good hot tea. We were sat upstairs, great atmosphere. Always refilling water and asking how things are going. We ordered Duck fried noodles,chicken chow mein, sesame chicken,and BBQ pork fried rice. The food was amazing, even the small appetizers and we were offered good portions for a group of 5. The servers are friendly and the food is the best Chinese we've had in a while; a must for dinner in China Town.
author: Colleen K.

description: The food was great, but the line was incredibly long. Additionally, the second floor had no air conditioner, and the service wasn't the greatest. Overall, I would maybe order takeout.
author: Carmen C.

description: One of the worst chinese food I've had. Only reason I gave a two star is because of the service and it's open late. We ordered the house fried rice and sweet and sour chicken. Man it did not look appetizing. Sweet and sour chicken came out looking pink... Fried rice looked very light and had no taste to it. Thank god they had soy sauce and hotsauce on the side. If you're drunk and need some greasy chinese food.. this is the place to be.
author: Vince L.

description: Came here because it seems to be a San Francisco Chinatown institution. There was a line out the door to get in for lunch, but it moves quickly. Highly recommend the beef wonton soup. Service is brusque but that's to eb expected at such a busy place. Definitely a must-visit in SF Chinatown. Also, check out Portsmouth Square across the street to see old school chinatown with all the men playing traditional Chinese gambling games.
author: Andrew D.

description: I don't see why this place has such a high ratings. The food tasted average and it didn't leave me wanting more. I had three dishes. The bbq pork chow mein was ok. The chow mein tasted like chow mein from any other Chinese place and the bbq pork didn't add anything to the dish. The second dish was the bbq pork wonton soup and it tasted like average wonton soup with bbq pork. Again it felt like they made a big batch of soup and added the toppings to whatever dish you get. Im sure if i order any other wonton soup or chow mein they would taste very similar. The last dish was the bbq pork rice noddles and this was unique but flavor wise it didn't blow me away. Overall the prices are fair but for what you get it should be.
author: Anatoly K.

description:
Unfortunately the hype of Sam Wo didn't really meet my expectations. While it was lauded as amazing Chinese food, I thought it tasted like typical American-Chinese food for the most part. 

The Kung Pao chicken, chow Mein noodles, and egg scrambled rice were rather pedestrian compared to what the lengthy wait might suggest they would taste like. (By the way make sure to put your name down on the list inside, don't just stand in the line as it will take much longer). 

By no means was the food bad, but it was just average compared to what I was expecting. However, one dish that I did really enjoy was the BBQ pork noodle roll, which I would recommend trying.
author: Alok N.

description: Amazing authentic Chinese food. We got the pork noodle rolls, dim sum, lo mein, orange chicken, crispy beef and salt and pepper chicken wings. The noodle rolls were amazing fresh pork and a thick noodle wrap all the other dishes were good accept for the S&P chicken wings. When they say SALT and pepper chicken wings they mean it. More like a kidney stone or a artery blockage ready to happen. But other wise pretty decent Chinese food not the best I've had but still worth going to with your family and friends for a late dinner or a night on the town.
author: Oatmeal J.

description: This place is just mediocre. The chun fun is too thick and doesn't have a smooth texture. The wonton noodle soup didn't have the right bounciness of noodle texture. The wonton soup flavor wasn't authentic.  The porridge was not too bad.
author: Jimmy I.

description: I'll give 4/5 stars for the salt and pepper fried chicken just FYI it's super salty. Like they pack on the seasoning but I did have to eat a bunch of rice with each bite just to counter out the salt intake but it was super good still. Went here on a holiday for Labor Day and the wait was 5 mins and was seated almost instantly! There's no air conditioning so just a heads up it's a little on the warmer side inside.
author: Valerie D.

description: Bit of a wait to get in but they turn tables quick. BBQ noodle roll was good, not great. Hot mustard totally brought it to life, a necessity for all that cold noodle. Sesame chicken was the best I've ever had. Overall a good cheap Chinatown experience. If I lived here I'd be back.
author: Ross P.

description:
A go-to restaurant in Chinatown. Good stuff. Every time I'm in SF I find my way here. It's off of the more touristy Chinatown streets. 

Ask the waiter/waitress for tips. They seem happy to customize.
author: Matthew F.

description: Delicious food and great personal! I ordered shrimp fried rice and it was very tasty and big portion - so I took a part home!
author: Evgeniya M.

description:
I had the Kung Pow Chicken and holy cow it was good. This place has a history here in San Fran as a staple for people visiting. The wonton soup bowl (plain) is HUGE. Make sure when you get there, you sign up on their list. Ignore the line!!! People start waiting in line for no reason and don't put Thierry name on the list by the front desk. We walked in and there were 20 people in line. Skipped the entire line. 

In fact I told 20+ people to sign up on the list when we left and they all grumbled.
author: Aaron W.

description: Wow sooo good!!! Husband and I were visiting San Fran and wanted authentic Chinese Food at a not so fancy restaurant! More like mom and pop shop where it's fresh! Oh my this was good!!!!!!!! Soooo fresh, tasty and great service!! This is not a tourist attraction which is what we wanted. Just good food!!! Highly recommend!!!
author: Marcelle R.

description: Saw a lot of reviews on yelp and wanted to give a try. Ordered a beef chowfun. It was a bit bland and not as tasty as I thought. Very little beef. A good portion of noodles. I won't be ordering this again but may try a rice dish though. Good customer service and very nice folks.
author: Mike T.

description: I miss Hong Kong, and hands down this place feels authentic and their wonton noodles are bomb! Price is decent too.
author: Natalie P.

description: As a chinese,why i can not order in chinese?by the way,i did not see any perticular good food.
author: Kai Z.

description:
I missed the original Sam Wo buzz, so attended the reopened restaurant with fresh eyes.  It's got a pretty simple menu with an obvious focus on congee.  I went on the early side (...because I basically only had coffee for breakfast) so had no problem getting a seat.  But the first customer to have to wait was at about 12:05PM.  Then by the time I left around 12:30PM, there was a huge line out the door.  Pretty busy for a Monday right after a holiday weekend!

BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll: The real super star of the meal.  BBQ Pork, like the kind you see hanging in shop windows around Chinatown.  A little cilantro.  Wrapped in a thick and soft rice noodle.  With some house-made hot mustard for dipping.  So many awesome flavors and textures going on.  One of the best appetizers I've had in Chinatown!

Duck Jook: A bit bland, but that's basically what congee/jook is.  The duck had the texture of boiled chicken rather then more tantalizing Peking duck.  Not much else besides some scallions on top.  Good for a cold day and/or when you're nursing a cold.

Chinese Donut: Forget coffee, this really helps jazz up the jook.  Soak a pre-cut piece and then scoop of a spoonful of donut and jook.  The deep fried goodness does wonders to the experience.  It's no mystery why this is such a popular pairing.
author: Adam B.

description:
As far as quick hole in the wall Chinese food goes, this one is the best! Best sesame chicken I've ever had. 

Visiting from out of town and staying nearby, I used Yelp for a recommendation and it did not disappoint! Delicious, fast, friendly, and a generous pour of the house Cabernet. I definitely recommend.
author: Heather S.

description:
After a rough day at work, sometimes you just need your culture's comfort food. Problem is, what if your Asian mom doesn't live in SF? Sam Wo to the rescue!

My ultimate comfort food (besides mashed potatoes!) is preserved egg and pork jook / porridge. This place does a good job with giving you enough preserved egg and pork, and also doesn't add too much seasoning beyond the ingredients. I wish they'd add some green onion too. The BBQ pork rice rolls are definitely fresh (you can tell because the wrap is super soft), but the wrap is probably a bit thick for my liking. You can also order bowls of beef tendon here (both curry and original flavors!)-- ughhh such deliciousness. The beef and string bean stir fry I got once was also alright by Chinese standards. 100% authentic Cantonese food for sure-- I'm Cantonese, trust me. I always lol at the people who eat at authentic Chinese spots and are angry that they don't have soy sauce covered everything or demand another region's cuisine (ex: the guy on who complained that the chicken was not spicy and had no chilies). Dude, this is Cantonese food, it's never spicy and never has chilies.
 
As for service, this place is at times surprisingly non-Chinese; I've tried to order takeout in Cantonese and had to switch to English because the server only spoke English, and the shop is kept quite clean and actually somewhat decorated (which is super weird for Chinese shops). They accept credit cards!

--

Edit: I came back recently for some comfort noms. The thousand year old egg in the porridge was kinda sour, which I've encountered before, but sorta made the porridge less enjoyable. The curry was less pungent than I remember, but I still loved both the melt in your mouth and chewy pieces of tendon.
author: Nicole H.

description: No wait on a Monday for lunch, lunch menu is different from dinner menu which was a little disappointing although the food we got tasted very fresh and homemade.
author: Tony D.

description:
Sam Wo, I still can't get over that your business is over a hundred years strong... Your delicious food working the camera for me on social media almost got me kicked out my house. In fact, my mother threatened me not to come back home unless I brought back some of your delicious Chinese food, but it's all good... I told my mother we'll be back to try some of your delicious food again when we go back to SF Chinatown over Christmas break!

Location:

Sam Wo is right along the Clay St. along SF Chinatown. It can be tricky to find because of the steep hill parking and other surrounding businesses in the area, but once you find that hole-in-a-wall restaurant, it will be worth all the parking drama and h-angry waiting!

Ambiance/ Set-Up:

The ambiance and set-up is down-to-earth and comfy for vertically challenged individuals like myself. I wanted to snap a picture of my tall friend while he was walking the steps with the sign "Watch your step" in the background, but I guess I was too late for that... The restaurant had a lot of comfy wooden chairs and booths plus the environment was intimate yet noisy. It almost reminded me of stepping into one of my Chinese friend's home and eating some of his delicious food!

Food:

Ughhh.. The food was to die for!! There was one item on the menu I did not like! Everything was cooked well with the perfect crisp and sauce. Nothing was too salty or horribly oily to handle. Everything about it was O.M.G. DELICIOUS! Words can't explain how much I love their food, but I guess you'll have to be there to believe how awesome their food tastes.

Customer Service:

They're the nicest group of Asians I've met so far in SF Chinatown. No one was rude and they did a great job accommodating our needs and concerns. I got top notch service from both Julie and Howard! It was pretty awesome how honest they were as to how much food we should buy to feed five hungry people!

Overall:

Despite the horrible parking and all things negative, I wouldn't mind coming back here again for the comforting Chinese food and the superior customer service!
author: Aubrey D.

description:
You can definitely find better (and probably cheaper) Chinese food in Chinatown. This place is crawling with tourists and non-Asian people,which is a red flag when you're trying to find authentic food IMO. I'm Chinese and have tasted everything in-between Panda Express to high end Chinese food. This place would be one step up from Panda Express for me (and I only eat Panda when I'm super desperate for "Chinese" food). Some of the dishes they serve are authentic and some is definitely questionable. It's pretty obvious they are catering to tourists and Americans. The decor in this place is on the nicer side when compared to other Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. 

I would not recommend this place if you want good Chinese food. I'd walk a few blocks down to R&G Lounge, which also caters to tourists and is famous for their food, but actually serves delicious and more authentic Chinese food.
author: Megan L.

description:
salt and pepper chicken wings. that is all. 

Came as a group of 3 (very hungry boys), and promptly ordered:
- 3 rice noodles rolls (2 duck 1 shrimp): excellent. great texture, very filling + mustard sauce is to die for
- salt and pepper wings: originally got one order, but destroyed in under 30 seconds and promptly ordered three (3!) more orders. easily some of the best wings I've had bar none - light, flavorful and crispy coating & juicy, fresh chicken
- duck dry mixed noodle: came rly rly late but also really good

Parking is a pain bc Chinatown/SF, the restaurant itself has also been recently remodeled and is almost as beautiful as the food. Also cool bc it's the oldest restaurant in Chinatown @ 100 years young, which makes the super low prices and incredible food all the more impressive.
author: Naayl K.

description:
Woohoo, Sam Wo reopens!

I have craved for their bbq spring rolls with hot sauce on the side that compliments with it (if you can take the heat) and finally get to fulfill that craving yet again!  I was surprised that they decided to re-establish Sam Wo and surely welcome it back!

Set at a different location, the layout still retains its theme as a narrow, hole in the wall spot!  The delivery of orders when ready, is old school style with the up and down mini elevator-like for entrees to be mobile.  It is a 2 floor area after all, so navigating with dishes may be quite crammed and mishaps may occur. 

The staff is attentive and nice.  

Their dishes are made cafe style and quickly served up.  Their duck fried rice was atypical and most of their entrees are wok, stir-fried.  

Now that they accept credit cards and have modernized decor, I like the fusion of traditional dining merged with tech vibe going on.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Wandering China Town and looking for a place to stop we found this through Yelp. Cute dingy hideaway with awesome food. Had the house chow fen and broccoli with oyster sauce. Noodles were fresh and veggies cooked perfectly.
author: Lisa C.

description: The food here is not heavy but it doesn't leave you hungry after a few hours of eating. The BBQ chicken was delicious as well as the chow mein and the sesame chicken. The sesame chicken was more like little pieces of fried skin than chicken and I would of rather have had a bit more chicken to it but it was still good. I didn't like the BBQ rolls maybe I'm not used to the steam bun taste but my brother and husband liked it.
author: Ari Y.

description: Least favorite of all we ate. The BBQ pork roll was one of my wife's favorite things we had in town this a 3 star rather than lower. Everything else was rather bland. Beef and broccoli, sesame chicken and wonton soup. None were terrible just rather bland.
author: Chad E.

description: garbage service and ridiculous favoritism, bottom line: these owners are racist as I've ever seen
author: Ethan C.

description: Pretty good and very affordable. Food came out quickly and we were pleased overall with the quality and taste. If I'm in the neighborhood again I'd definitely make the trip back.
author: James D.

description:
Recently visited SF on 8/27/17. It had been awhile and the wife had never visited.
After arriving we were hungry and looking for some lunch. She located Sam Wo and we gave it a try. We walked so did not have to deal with parking. It is small and was busy during our visit.
Typical sign in board and we were seated upstairs within a few minutes. Service was quick and friendly. We looked over the menu and ordered spring rolls, house chow fun and shrimp egg fried rice. This was plenty for two people. Food came out quickly and was very good. We enjoyed it and would recommend.
author: Dan P.

description:
It's back.. sort of. Surely you remember Conan O'Brien's commercial for the old Sam Wo's about eight years ago (video: http://bit.ly/1kBvmLI). I ate there back then, and I have to admit the hilarious faux-ad was pretty accurate in its skewering (review: http://bit.ly/1XWoOG8). Yet, when it closed three years ago due to owner David Ho's inability to bring it up to code, I felt a slight twitch in my stomach. Perhaps it was acid reflux in memoriam. That was mean as Sam Wo, as dilapidated as it was and as indifferent as their servers were, still served decent, middle-of-the-road Chinese food, take it or leave it. Jamie W. and I decided to give the new place a try.

It's at a different address on Clay Street opposite Portsmouth Square where a group of mostly women dance in unison to the beat of Chinese pop music. This was where Anna Bakery used to be because I remember how hard their almond sugar cookies used to get. We walked in and didn't enter the kitchen like I used to at the old place. The kitchen is toward the side behind glass like a normal restaurant (photo: http://bit.ly/1LYUZzr). The immersive greasy spoon vibe was gone and so was the dumbwaiter. I don't mean a dumb waiter, I mean the pulley-operated elevator that transported the food to the second floor..

There are still two floors, and the tables still have the formica tops and backless stools. Don't get too comfortable, but the restroom looks new. Enjoy that while it lasts. The menu is all laminated now and filled with familiar dishes. We decided to start with the $6.95 Wonton Soup with BBQ Pork, and we both were able to get two small bowlfuls out of it. It was pretty good with the broth clearer than we expected and a lot of wontons (photo: http://bit.ly/1ME20Tn). More vegetables could have helped for contrast, but this is Sam Wo's, not Eric's, so get over it. Then we had the $8.50 Chow Fun with Duck (photo: http://bit.ly/1MPBzR4).

Again it was no-frills with just bean sprouts and a few chopped scallions added in. We were pretty convinced that we got chicken instead of duck until I overheard the server at another table explaining how they don't roast duck here. So OK it could have been duck. We ended our meal with one of their premium dishes, the $10.25 Sesame Chicken (photo: http://bit.ly/20D5ujD). Because Jamie has been on a General Tso's tear lately, he figured that would be within proximity of it. It was, maybe a little too crunchy (i.e., overcooked) and the portion wasn't near Henry's Hunan sizes. All in all, it was not a disappointing experience but if you're looking for the cranky, greasy "charm" of the original, let it go.

FOOD - 3 stars...decent Chinese dishes unadorned with spices or hearty vegetables, not much different than the dishes of yore
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...it's clean and still crowded,..no health hazards to be seen so far
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...no crotchety old waiters like Edsel, just young servers who were surprisingly attentive
TOTAL - 3 stars...Sam Wo, we hardly recognized ya
author: Ed U.

description:
While I never had the chance of visiting the original restaurant, I have been to the new incarnation three times already.  I expected cheap, but was really surprised at how good everything was.  They did a great job with remodel of whatever used to inhabit the location, and service is friendly.  I now know where to head for an after-hours meal.  

BBQ pork rice rolls
Fish jook 
Wonton soup

The duck dry mixed noodles would be better with skin off, but that has been the only misstep, thus far.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday night.

Pros:
Atmosphere, really 'old school'
Chow fun, Chinese broccoli

Cons:
The food is average Chinese fare
Long wait, one of those sign up sheet deals
Sweet and sour pork
author: Simon C.

description: Coming in with a family of 4 on a late Saturday morning, we were immediately seated. The venue was relatively small but I think there is an upstairs as well. The server carefully took our orders and within 10-15 minutes our food was ready and all came at once! Big portions for a great price. I ordered the BBQ Pork Wonton Soup (flavorful bbq pork btw) and it sure filled me up for the rest of the day! Definitely come eat here if you need energy to jump from shop to shop in Chinatown for the day.
author: Melanie C.

description:
I have been going to the old Sam Wo's with my father for late night snack since the early 50's. We knew Edsel in his prime. I think they went to the same school and my father dated his sister. Now I am much older. I was sad to see the old Sam Wo close and I lined up to eat for the last day. When I discovered Sam Wo reopened I had to give the place a try.

The new place was located at a different place.
The waiters were younger females.
The prices were much higher.

My three favorite signature dishes were:
The fish jook
The BBQ Pork Noodle Roll.
The raw fish salad.
They were not as good as the old Sam Wo so I was disappointed
author: Eric L.

description: pretty sure "sam wo" is the chinese translation for "red bull" bc this place gives you wiiiiiiiiiiings. rltktho CHICKEN WINGS were the highlight of our 12ish person afterparty plus PORK ORGANS for only me lol. the rest was a mishmash compared to those two.
author: Dan B.

description:
The hubs, Wee one and I wandered into Sam Wo yesterday in search of a late lunch. I have to say that after sitting down and looking around at the very spartan interior, I had very, VERY low expectations. 

I ordered the Ma Po Tofu, the Hubs had shrimp fried rice, the Wee one got a big bowl of wanton soup with noodles, and we split an order of spring rolls. Nothing was fancy, but everything was delicious. 

The spring rolls were crisp and yummy (I wish we ordered a double helping they were so good). My kid's soup was LOADED with delicious wontons and tons of fresh eggy noodles. My Ma Po tofu was delicious and came stir fried with Chinese pickled vegetables (an unexpected but yummy addition). The Hubs fried rice was one of the better versions I've seen in a while and loaded up with lots of big fat shrimp. All the portions were large, and the flavors were spot on.

The next time I'm in China Town, I will be having lunch at San Wo again.
author: Julie T.

description: Visiting and came here.  Was pretty darn good for simple inexpensive Chinese food.  Would come back.
author: Phat B.

description: Great place to get food after a night out drinking. Their chow fun is greasy and amazingg. Their porridge is tasty, too. Staff is really nice and have high tolerance for intoxicated people hahah. Prices are reasonable. I come here to buy chow fun for potlucks, too, cause they give hella per serving and I only need two orders hahah. Always a hit.
author: Betty W.

description:
Got the wonton BBQ pork soup was very bland.  Tastes like water with noodles.  Howard the waiter gave me beef broth to compensate the taste.  Still didn't work after mixing the broth. 

My daughter ordered shrimp egg over rice. She got the order where egg was still runny.  Howard took it back and when she got it back the oil was so much soaking the rice.  So we returned it back. Gave us new rice.  

Chicken wings - not all the way cooked.  Salmonella yikkessss.
author: Dennis R.

description: Same taste as the original Sam Wo.  Friendly staff.  Opens late for the night life people.  Food is very comforting and reasonably priced.  Highly recommend coming here.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
Had to come here on my trip to SF based on the reviews. We waited 20 minutes to get seated. There was the chaos typical of busy chinatown restaurants but the servers were nice.

The pork rice rolls are a must-get. I haven't seen them anywhere else and they are delicious here! We got a few dishes to share. My favorite was the shrimp and egg over rice. They make the egg a bit runny so it melts into the rice. The chow mien was pretty good, but too oily for my taste.
author: Lingyi P.

description: This place represents Chinese food at its best.  The value is off the charts and I'm feel compelled to right more reviews in yelp because yelp helped me find this place.
author: Romeo RJ A.

description:
Five minutes from my desk to amazing noodles. Credit cards welcomed. 

The first visit was on a Monday at 11:15. I was asked to find my way upstairs and when at 11:25 I hadn't been given a menu I came to Yelp and found a picture of the menu. 

Lucky, I was able to wrangle a waiter my way and ordered Chicken Chow Main. 

The thing I look forward to is the noodles slightly burnt because the wok is so incredibly hot. Something that can't be accomplished in most homes. Look for the celery to be slightly burnt on the edges but not too sweaty. Excellent.  

When I left at 11:45 there was a huge line leading out of the restaurant and down the hill.

Note to self: Get here at 11:01!
author: Justin S.

description:
This must be a tourist trap. If the majority of people in the restaurant are non-Asian, you should know....or maybe I just ordered the wrong thing? 

I had this craving for bbq pork noodle soup. Let's just say I could make a better bowl. The pork was dry and tasted like it was sitting out for days. It was dyed an artificial pink color. The worse part was the broth. Murky. Could've opened a can of Swanson and that would've been better. Completely tasteless bowl, I had to add soy sauce and white pepper. 

Two stars though for the super friendly waitress.
author: Jen P.

description:
Hit the new location Sat. night solo as it was the only place open within walking distance.  Never knew the legends about this place.  Service was great.  Food was great.  Saved my evening.  

Wife saw my pic and wanted to again for lunch the next day.  Owner that was there at 2AM and presumably closed it down at 3AM, was there about 11:15 in the morning, back hard at work.  No wonder it's a success.
author: Wayne L.

description:
This review is based on only one dish. I ordered the Kung Pao chicken. It was not authentic at all. Not spicy, no ginger, no scallion, no chilies. Just not what I was expecting. In fact the dish seemed to be made from a black bean paste, not the right flavor base.

The staff were very nice. That is a positive. But the food was disappointing. Unfortunately I don't think that I shall be going back.
author: Timir D.

description:
We came here a few times last week during our yearly visit to SF. The food and service were both very good. One night we came around 11pm (glad to see they are open late to 3am). We ordered pork & preserved egg porridge, BBQ pork noodle soup, stewed beef won ton noodle soup, egg rolls and fried cruellers to put in the porridge. Everything was served promptly and were tasty.

Our server Howard was very friendly and helpful. Since we told him that we were foodies, he wrote a list of different cuisine restaurants that he recommended. I mean, what server does this? What a cool guy!

Sam Wo's has an upstairs dining room as well as downstairs. It was clean as well as the restrooms. We will definitely be back!
author: Zoey W.

description: Delicious but be ready to be modest in your expectations.   I think Sam Wo can credibly boast as one of the oldest Chinese food restaurants in the city, but at another original location.  Having said that, one does not get to be old without a little decay around the edges.  The food however distracts from the setting; you may have to wipe your own table down, and you might have a little left over food at your feet.  The food is delicious and presented amply (translation: come hungry!).  The chow mein was very, very good.  The fried rice, delicious!  So reasonable, too.  No dim sum (even though that was what hubby was looking for when we searched on Yelp for local food) is served here, but it doesn't matter.  Lots of yummy other stuff, just be so hungry that you are not in that picky mood you sometimes get (am I projecting?)
author: Darby W.

description: The food was delicious and environment was great. Loved the experience and the yelp reviews did not disappoint! What a great hole in the wall
author: Amberly C.

description: Stopped in here based on the great reviews and busy storefront. Ingredients seemed quality but completely lacked in taste and flavor. Service was OK. Would not return.
author: Tim S.

description: I had forgotten the size of American size portions even in a Chinese resturant in the states. Having arriving from Hong Kong (I'm from the States but lived in Hong Kong for many years)  a few days ago I looked down at the plate & wondered how many people this lunch was for?  It was tasty & $8.75 on the menu / $11 cash out of pocket - cheap for SF. So I decide to eat it all. Lovely but I was fat for the entire sleepy afternoon. It was string beans & beef on rice.
author: Leung T.

description: Nice service, but good lord, terrible food. Everything was so oily, but that awful taste of just flavorless fat.
author: Cassady S.

description: Historic, "Hole in the wall" in Chinatown. Good food, clean, authentic. I love seeing the kitchen as I walk to my table. We sat on the second floor after climbing very steep, narrow stairs, it really gave us the feeling of old Chinatown!
author: Stephanie L.

description: I took my students on a field trip! Sam Ho helped us give the kids a great Chinese cuisine experience!! Thank you so much, the students loved the food! See you again!!
author: Chad T.

description: I would give no stars if I could. The waiter seemed grumpy when we asked for disposable chopsticks, and there was hair in the food. The food was not very good quality, and there were flies all over the place. Overall, this place is not very clean and doesn't have good food. It was not worth it, and I will never come here again and recommend others to do the same. I'd rather go anywhere, as long as it's not here.  Should have went to the Subway next door, much cleaner and more delicious.
author: David G.

description:
I went to college in the Bay Area, but I live in Alaska now. I was really excited for good Chinese food and found this on Yelp.

The food was bland and they were busy, so the staff wasn't attentive. The food all came out at different times and they gave our fried rice to another table.

I'm still disappointed because I was so excited for Chinese food and I'm baffled as to how this has such a high rating.
author: Kirsten F.

description:
TL;DR - Home-y comfort food that is as far away from healthy and organic as possible. (But still delicious and reels me back time after time)

I always get the bbq rice roll, preserved egg and pork porridge, duck dry noodles and the combination chow fun.

Get it. Trust me. Carb load and don't think about the food coma.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Pork Noodle Roll is one of the best items in Chinatown. They do fried rice and chicken really well, noodles and beef dishes not so much. They're open till 3 am on the weekends for your drunk cravings
author: Kevin J.

description: Love the BBQ noodle rolls. Other dishes are hit or miss on flavor. I mainly come for the rolls w the crazy hot Chinese mustard sauce.
author: Liz N.

description:
I was expecting more from this place. I had some clues before I sat down but I went with it since it had 4 stars on yelp. The first clue was the tepid looking BBQ pork they were using to put in their dishes. Then as I was walking to my table I saw some chow fun on someone's plate that looked like it was microwaved versus that fresh out of a wok look. I still sat down to eat thinking how can they screw up congee. It was watery, the rice was under cooked as in they were almost whole pieces rather than cooked down to a thick consistency. 

This is obviously a tourist trap and the age of the restaurant doesn't correlate to the quality of he food. The servers were nice enough but the food was pretty bad.
author: David N.

description: Sam Wo is a MUST when in Chinatown in San Francisco. While on a retreat with my colleagues, we decided to stop here based on all the positive feedback. And let me tell you, it was the best Chinese food I've had ever! Amazing customer service and everything tasted so fresh and authentic: we even got a visit from a few dragon friends! The house chow fun was my favorite along with the spring rolls. Do yourself a favor and stop here!
author: Chris R.

description: I had to create an account just so I can warn the rest of humanity about this place. My friends and I were looking for a late night meal and saw that this place had 4 stars. HOW DOES THIS PLACE HAVE 4 STARS? The table that we were seated at wasn't wiped. Calling the food here mediocre is giving it too much credit. Got the bbq pork rolls due to all the yelp reviews, they were cold, bland and poorly formed. The "charsiu" is the fake red dyed pork. The beef wonton noodle soup had wontons that had no flavor. House special chow mein tasted like licking a brick of salt. The beef stew dried noodles were edible, but was not really enjoyable. Even our glass of water was a disappointment when it came to us with flakes of paper floating in it. This is a tourist trap with flashy hollywood faces to distract diners from the otherwise inedible food.
author: Stephen L.

description: The word overrated is an understatement for Sam Wo. Besides the long wait, the restaurant has zero customer service. The waiters are not familiar with the menu and the contents of the meals. The food is of poor quality; using any and all scraps of the chicken. We ordered Chinese donut which was not cooked properly & needed some sort of dipping sauce, the Sesame Chicken which was covered in sauce to conceal the scraps of chicken and the chow fun noodles with chicken which had no flavor, had a burnt smell and a few shreds of chicken. When asking for plates, they dropped off wet plates that we had to dry ourselves. If I could give this place a zero I would. Don't waste your time or your money & don't fall for the reviews. Anyone who has anything positive to say about this place has obviously never eaten quality, tasty and authentic Chinese cuisine. Garbage!
author: Arthur M.

description:
Total garbage. Not sure what the deal is with all these positive reviews. The food here is mediocre at best, greasy and tasteless and way, way overpriced for what you get. A $2 frozen meal heated and served on a plate for $12+. Even their "famed" appetizer left a lot to be desired. The hype is truly mind boggling, truly. The people posting good reviews must be fake, or the restaurant pays Yelp to bury the negatives, which is what I imagine will end up happening to this review. 

Do not go here. DO NOT.
author: Rob S.

description: The most impressive quality of this restaurant is how fast they can bring out food. My party's order came out within 8 minutes of sitting down. However, the food lacked any means of quality or thought. The duck lo mein had little bits of duck in it.
author: Brian N.

description:
Stopped by here during my trip to SF, and I'm so glad I did! We were buying some souvenirs and it was nearby - so why not? 

We had a group of 9, and they were able to accommodate us right away. They led us up to the second floor, which we pretty much had to ourselves! We even had one person that stayed upstairs the whole time in case we needed anything. While it looks pretty small from the front, the second floor is spacious. 

As for the food, my cousins and I shared: 
- Tomato Beef Chow Mein: so good! Unexpectedly sweet AND savory. It reminded me of a Filipino spaghetti (which is sweeter than normal). There was more noodle than beef, but I am totally okay with that  
- Salt and Pepper Chicken (7 to an order): this was a more subtle salt and pepper taste, though I did get some bites that did have a lot of pepper on it. These are not your average Chinese food wings - I think they double fried it so that it gets an extra crispy skin 
- Beef Noodle Rolls: so good! Our order came with 20 pieces. More cilantro than I would've liked, but these are tasty especially with some sauce on the side
- Chinese doughnuts: basically fried dough that's not too sweet. Not quite the dessert I was looking for, but it is good as something neutral to give you a break from other flavors
author: Michelle B.

description: We were out in San Fran for a school conference and were craving a Chinatown spot late at night - so glad San Wo was open! The owner (I forgot her name, sorry!) was SO nice and fun, staying to chat with us after our meal. She was very attentive and patient with some newer servers, completely understanding after an incorrect dish was brought out. She and the servers were very helpful in helping our Muslim friends pick out delicious non-pork dishes. The food was delicious - I had the Duck Chow Mai Fun with rice noodles (!!) and the BBQ Rice Noodle Roll (they're not messing around with that hot mustard, be warned). Not only is Sam Wo amazing for a late-night spot, but it's just overall an amazing Chinese restaurant.
author: Zac S.

description: Awesome service and the food was great.  We got there right as they opened, so no wait for a table on the first floor.  We had the BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll which was so much better than either of us had expected and we devoured it.
author: Matt H.

description: When restaurant wrote authentic Chinese place, I would never believe them. This is the place for the great taste of Cantonese history in the west coast!
author: YuChang L.

description: Amazing food plus the service was great ! However didn't like how they bring you the food at different times and the restaurant it self was small.
author: Julie H.

description: Came in around 2pm on a Saturday and got seated upstairs, which was extremely hot. We waited approximately 40 minutes for our food because the waitress forgot to put our order in or something. I wanted to like this place since the food was pretty good. We ordered fried rice, won ton, pork roll, and another rice dish. Also, we got milk tea which was just decent. My friend was still finishing up her food, meanwhile the same waitress kept pushing us to pay (it was uncomfortable). I understand it was because we had some friends leave early since they had places to be and we weren't expecting to be waiting so long for food. People who came in after us even got their orders. Then, after staring us down and continuously coming back to check if we paid yet, she started pointing at the bill really rudely (tap tap tap super hard). Like I said I understand if she was just trying to make sure we were going to pay, but my friend was literally still finishing up her meal! Overall, I did not like the service (the way she kept looking at us and speaking in Chinese when we were just asking about our order, which she never responded). I understood everything she said, but the way she handled the situation was terrible.
author: Maggie W.

description: Sam Wo catered a small office lunch for us today and it was AMAZING. Jane went above and beyond in helping us fit our budget and when we picked everything up, we had SO MUCH MORE FOOD than we expected or even ordered. Everything tasted great, and we will now have leftovers for days. We would definitely choose Sam Wo again in the future!
author: Penny D.

description:
good food overall, large portion with low prices (but they are raising the prices from July 2018).
the noodle is typical southern style so if you are looking for spicy and sour noodles like the northern style, this is not the good choice.
author: Daniel Z.

description: There's only two words I can describe this place. It's "Dank and authentic". Offer Cheap and amazing Chinese American dishes, I've had in San Francisco. I highly recommend my friends to come here!
author: Ivan Y.

description:
This food was so very delicious! The service was fast and very friendly. We were second in line (it opened at 6:00pm) and the place filled up quickly!

We had bbq wonton soup (a little under seasoned but fresh and high quality), duck fried rice (so great!), beef chow fun (great noodles--smoky flavor), BBQ noodle roll (yum!), chicken with green beans (excellent), and BBQ pork with egg over rice (back page--my husband enjoyed this so much!!). 

After the first couple of dishes, we were so excited that we didn't take anymore photos; we just ate! Excellent food! Very friendly people!
author: J Michelle L.

description:
Great place that serves cheap Chinese food in SF Chinatown. I like to come here during my lunch break with my co-workers since they are good, quick, and cheap. 

Food - what we ordered: 
1. BBQ Pork Fried Rice - My absolute favorite dish. The pork is nicely flavored and the rice is perfectly golden/pan fried. 
2. Chinese Porridge with Century Old Egg - First time having the egg. It was dark and chewy. Probably would not order again, since the texture and taste just tasted odd. I like the salted eggs more with my porridge. Also tip, when ordering porridge.. I like to get a side of the Chinese long donut. It''s really good with the porridge 
3. Combination Chow Fun - Would not order again. The chow fun was pretty oily and was noodle heavy. They did not include much meat or veggie. 
4. Hong Kong style Milk Tea - Did not include boba. HK milk tea are known to be super strong. It didn't have much milk as expected in a typical milk tea drink. 
5. Beef Won Ton Soup - the beef did not taste like beef, it looked very odd. Won tons were pretty average. 

Service
1. Servers are usually Chinese workers
2. Quick to give you a menu and place your order.
3. Food comes out around 10 mins 

Ambience/Seating 
1. They have more seating upstairs 
2. Downstairs has the milk tea station and where you can order togo 
3. relatively cramped seating 
4. They have TV screens on replay of videos where Sam Woo was featured on the news. 

Overall, my go to item would be the fried rice for lunch. 

Amy
author: Amy N.

description: This was our worst San Francisco experience. We wanted something different and something good. Looked up some suggestions on yelp, and came across this place. The prices were good, the pictures looked good; but everything was far from it. The entire family was sick after eating here.
author: Miguel D.

description:
This is my second time eating here, and it was just as enjoyable as the first. Wait staff is friendly and food is delicious. 

Our server had broken English and was difficult to understand, and had a hard time understanding us at times. For instance she didn't know what peas were when my friend asked for none in her rice. But she never got frustrated, was continuously friendly, and got our orders perfectly right. 

This is definitely a good stop to make in China town! Expect a short wait, and there is a sign up sheet to get on the wait list when you walk in, which we didn't see at first.
author: Anna C.

description: It is my favorite by far. Nice staff and great simple Chinese food. Real people. I love  it.
author: Brent S.

description:
Fun spot in China Town with a pretty cool history. 
The service was good, the food was authentic and the environment was really dynamic.
My coworker has been going here for many years as a family tradition and recommended I check them out. The whole experience was really good. 
Check out the park across the way too, spend a little time and absorb the environment.
Im looking forward to my next trip to the bay area and my next trip to Sam Wo,
author: Robert B.

description: Really enjoyed the BBQ pork roll and think it's a great deal at $5. The horseradish sauce they served it with was way too strong (but you would maybe like it if you like horseradish?). The sweet and sour chicken was delicious with crisp vegetables and great flavor, however, there were lots of tiny pieces of chicken which kind of seemed like scraps? Fast service and the bathroom was spacious and clean.
author: Sarah J.

description: The food isn't bad, but not so great to warrant its popularity.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
dropped into San Wo for deja wu reasons. Sam Wo and Clown Alley were my to go eateries after having a few drinks in the area..

menu probably the same. didn't ordered the usual duck chow fun.

eats: beef stew won ton soup(6.5)
-9ih big won tons filled with porkmeat and hint of waterchestnut
no shrimp like the olde days
-broth overwhelme by beef stew taste
-beef stew very tender, even the fat!
*taste definitely different from the olde days, 

take outs:
-did see Edsul a few times
never saw him entertaining tourists much.
little interaction with him beyond him telling me where to sit.
author: Victor G.

description:
It was my first time back to Sam Wo since their revamp and it was surreal. It felt the same but it looked very different but not different.. They still have the upstairs dining room but additional downstairs now which is cool. 

We chose upstairs because it was supposed to be warmer than downstairs. Service was right away super friendly and welcoming. The complete opposite of the world's most rude waiter (which they are famous for). The place had up a lot of old signs and pictures of the old Sam Wo which i thought was cute. 

It looked like every table had the bbq pork rice roll so of course we had to get that. And it was a cold night out so I wanted some soup so we ordered a bowl of won ton soup. Food came out hot and fast which was appreciated. The bbq pork rice roll came with a side of chinese hot mustard (yum!). The dish was great because who doesn't look chinese bbq pork + rice noodle? It also had some leafy bits and some cold other bits in side which complimented the hot bbq pork and noodle in every bite. I'd def come back for it. 

The won ton soup was good but nothing to come back for. I'll definitely have to come back for a plate of noodles and friendly service. It did look like the place is a sit, get food quick, eat, and leave type of a place so I wouldn't recommend it for those who want to do any leisurely dining. It was also crowded with tourists mostly families with kids which in case that's not your thing. 

Sidenote they take credit cards, and they don't serve beer or wine.
author: Veronica L.

description:
My mom suggested we come here for a late bite, since she had visited the restaurant in the 80's and was waited on by the infamous Edsel Ford Fong. From what she told me the place has definitely changed since then (including a change in location), but you can tell there's definitely some history here. 

We ordered the Fried Spring Rolls, Kung Pao chicken and House Chow Mein. The Fried Spring Rolls were delicious and piping hot. The Chow Mein had shrimp and pork and I definitely enjoyed it, however, the Kung Pao chicken was not very impressive.
