It didn't come out with rice (although they did end up offering us rice later), and contained much more vegetables and sauce than chicken. All in all, a good spot to grab some quick Chinese food, but I have definitely had better (for cheaper). I think you're probably paying for the name/history more than anything.
author: Clara T.

description: I have been to Chinatown multiple times and have never had food this good. The Fish Jook is a traditional fish porridge and is to die for. The kids had BBQ Wonton and Egg and Beef over rice and really liked it. If you like real, not American, Chinese, give it a try. I will definitely be back to try other dishes.
author: D D.

description: Pretty decent Cantonese Food. The BBQ fried rice was tasty enough. What they call the "Beef Chow Fun" was also good. The waiter (whom was very helpful and friendly) recommended their signature dish - pork inside thick noodles. A Broccoli dish was also tasty and not too oily like other places. Not the most amazing meal but decent. The place is clean.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Got lucky and stumbled across this place on a weekend trip to the city. IT IS AMAZING. Great food and super friendly staff. 
  We tried three dishes: The Dry Mixed Noodles (chicken), the Duck chow mein, and the shrimp chow fun. All three were excellent, but the Dry Mixed Noodles might be my new favorite Chinese dish. I think my description could do it no justice, but it was so good we were all fighting over it.
  The staff was great, I had two kids with me, and they were not sure what to order. The waiter was polite, patient and very helpful; answering all of their questions about the menu.
  This restaurant has earned my continued patronage. NO trip to San Francisco will be complete without a stop at Sam Wo. 
  I mean, I even bought a t-shirt.
author: Jason C.

description:
Falls short of the hyped "100 years cooking!"

You would think that the claim, seen in several places throughout, would inspire confidence and eager tastebuds. But this has to be one of the least satisfying meals I've had in my last two weeks of traveling - eating nearly every meal out at a restaurant. 

We ordered four items: wonton soup, BBQ noodle roll, house fried rice, and broccoli with oyster sauce. None of these dishes stood out in taste except the fried rice, which had some questionable meat pieces mixed in. 

I found myself forced to continue eating just so I would feel so bad for wasting money. 

I would not recommend this place to anyone looking for a good meal, and especially anyone looking for a decent Chinese restaurant. Close your eyes, point in a random direction, and you'll probably find a better choice 50 yards away!
author: Mikeson K.

description: Their famous pork rolls are weird but tasty. Had the duck fried rice which was okay - not much duck. The house chow fun was delicious. The portions are big and the prices are reasonable. The service is excellent too.
author: Kay I.

description:
Why would you come to any Chinese restaurant, let alone this one.  Aside from snobby reviews about food comparisons to their favorite spot in New York or LA; or 5 star reviews from people who love everything about a place after eating there once.

I feel compelled to convince some new people to the area that it is ok not to go to the place with 3k reviews or skip Chinatown all together because it is over whelming.

HOW does one pick Chinese food and land here.

1. You tried to go to R&G and there was a wait; you walked back a block and were to hungry to cross the street.

2. You have a picky eater in the group and the real good spots don't have menus that set them at ease, it happens but let's be inclusive.

3. 300 reviews, 4 stars and a reoccurring picture of a tasty dim sum looking treat without having to deal with a dim sum restaurant.

This place is great, comfy and people are very friendly.  The food was good, but Chinese like wine tastes different to everyone and rarely will one place make all happy....yet our picky eater left full and pleased.

4 stars because it is the first time eating here and one should not give 5 stars after eating maybe one or two dishes at a place.

Big Bonus: Don't recall seeing General Tso's chicken at the top of the menu...it can be good but it does not need to be everywhere.

Try it, enjoy it and look for another place to try around another corner!
author: Richard W.

description: Just the best. There is even not an arguement. Even Conan O'brien doesnt even have a problem with it, and he's ginger.
author: Ricky M.

description: So overrated, their chow mien was very dry and bland. I don't get the hype. Maybe it's just me.
author: Sergio R.

description: First time here in San Fran. Got in late and was looking for a good spot to eat. The hotel recommended R&G lounge, but it was closing in 20 minutes. Found Sam Wo not too far away and placed a to go order. The food was ready in legit 10 minutes. Their salt and pepper chicken is to die for! The flavor is perfect. Not just the skin is flavored, but the meat was tender and flavorful as well. We also got the mixed vegetable fried rice. The rice was not really fried, but the flavor was amazing. It was pretty much steamed to perfection, not fried at all. Although I was looking forward to fried rice, I appreciated the flavor still being great. We also ordered the beef and broccoli, but can't say that we were fans. Let's just say the chicken was so good, we ordered it again the next day. Although the wait was a bit long, it was worth it. Make it your business to check this place out if you're in town!
author: Chelsey R.

description: Best place to get the bbq noodle roll. This place is always crowded with a line out the door. I always call for pick up. The workers are fast and friendly. The restaurant is very small not many tables so the wait time might be a while.
author: Tracy S.

description: Whoa on Sam Wo...it has a reputation for great food but I didn't get any when we went. It was fun to go to a famous spot but once we ate the food none of it was great. The noodle roll was sticky and just ok. The noodles were stuck together...the beef was fatty and the Chinese broccoli was bitter. We chose this for our Thanksgiving dinner retreat. Poor choice. Won't go back. The waiters were nice but that's it. Tong Fong Low in Oroville, Ca is older and has food 100 Times better.
author: Anna H.

description:
I recommend going early to beat the crowd and receive the best service. Server was incredibly attentive when we first arrived, but it was difficult to get water once the dinner rush started. As a while, the servers were very kind and helpful. 

We ordered:
- BBQ pork roll. Different, but definitely worth a try. Their pork was excellent - not overlooked like most. Very tender and flavorful. 
- Spring rolls. Ok. Very crispy, which is a must for me, but left me wishing for a protein like shrimp or pork inside. 
- Chinese donut. Not my favorite. Bland and cold - wouldn't order again 
- Two types of Chow fun. Both were excellent. Noodles were a bit greasy, but that's to be expected with an oily sauce. Super tender as were the beef, pork, and shrimp. 
- Chicken Chop Suey. Not good. In their defense, this wasn't on the menu, but we requested that they add chicken to their vegetable chop suey. Chicken was fatty and bland. Not like the sueys were used to - more like chicken and vegetables in brown sauce. 

Overall, it's a must stop. If it's been around 100 years, they must be doing something right!
author: Jennifer M.

description: This rating is not just about the food!  I have been going to Sam Wo's since high school so it holds special memories for me~even with the move. I love the bbq pork roll appetizer. It's a meal in itself. Other dishes are also tasty. Sam Wo's has become somewhat of an institution as it has been around a very long time. You get decent value for the low prices and I just enjoy the entire experience!!!  You don't necessarily go for the great service or the best Chinese food. But one thing I know, I'll be back when I'm in town!
author: Kathleen O.

description:
We were greeted and thought, this place seems friendly. Everything was going good until halfway through our meal, my sister-in-law bit into a small piece of glass! She thinks it came from the "House Fried Rice" but isn't 100% sure as we shared our 4 dishes and had a portion of each dish in our plates. We notified our waitress (an older lady) to which she referred to the younger lady cleaning the tables. She took the spoon with the piece of glass downstairs and returned with an apology. She asked if we still wanted the fried rice and we said no.

When we got our check, the older lady had charged us for the fried rice but gave us a 10% discount. Are you f*** kidding me? That glass made a small cut in my sister-in-law's mouth and you only give a 10% discount? That's barely getting the tax off. We told her that our fried rice was taken away, so we shouldn't have to pay for it. The cashiers downstairs finally took off the order of fried rice but also took off the 10% discount. This was such BS. We should have taken photos of the glass and forgot to because we were so upset. 

I highly DO NOT recommend this place.
author: Bao C.

description:
Sam Wo is back in full effect and I'M ECSTATIC!

I finally came here a few weeks ago, and the new location is nooooice. Although it's definitely more Americanized, they somehow kept the same feel and aura of the old location on the second floor. Made me warm and fuzzy inside. THE FEELS. So many memories at the old location!

Modern, but thankfully, still good ol' Chinatown pricing.. slightly higher than what I remembered (inflation, y'all) but the portions are still generous.

*MUST ORDER* BBQ RICE NOODLE ROLL: $5 AND STILL BOMB AF. Cha siu and cilantro wrapped in a sikly rice noodle and dipped in a liquidy spicy mustard sauce. Dip sparingly as it's like wasabi where it'll give you that same clearing sensation through your nose.

*GOOD* GREEN BEANS: $8.50: heaping plate of green beans and enough to feed 3-4 people.. I'm used to this cooked more Northern style where it's more dry/fried - this was more of a stir fry with black bean sauce, still good though. Dat gravy would be good with rice!

*YUMMEH* COMBINATION WONTON SOUP: $8. I actually never ordered wonton here before but my coworker said this was her go-to, so I trusted her. I thought $8 was kinda pricey but there's AT LEAST 6 large wontons in there along with some pork and cha siu. The wontons could be improved if there was more shrimp, but it's good the way it is, and fair for the price.

*MUST ORDER* DUCK DRY MIX NOODLES $7: Now THIS was really the gift that kept on giving because damn, I don't know how we just kept pulling noodles outta this bowl. Honestly, the duck in this isn't that great, but I was eating it more for the noodles. Silky lo mein noodles lightly dressed with some kind of SUPER ADDICTING sauce. Flavorful even though the noodle color looked kinda plain. Room temperature though, keep in mind.

Other must orders, from past experience:
*MUST ORDER*Jook with Chinese donut (any, my fav is the one with pork and preserved egg)
*MUST ORDER* Chow Mein with tomato & beef
author: Emily C.

description: Friendly, very fast service - and by luck, we were seated immediately. Not long after we arrived a small line had formed. For the price, the dishes were as expected - though they didn't amaze in terms of taste or texture. I'd visit again, though perhaps find out which dishes are their best. We had the house fried rice, Mongolian beef, and chicken chow mien. All in all, a good budget Chinese restaurant with a century of history.
author: Andy R.

description:
I honestly thought our experience was just okay. We've certainly had better chinese food, and my bf said it was very american style chinese food. 

Parking/Location: 
Right across from the parking garage and across the street from where all the elderly play games together. 

Service: 
Meh. I mean they were nicer because we spoke cantonese but our waitress was just okay. Typical service we'd expect. 

Food: 
We ordered the famous bbq pork rice noodle rolls and got some basic fried rice with duck. They're known for the rolls, which I appreciated for what they were, but I absolutely hate cilantro. My friend loves it, but I can't stomach the smell or taste of it, so the rolls weren't as appreciated by me.  The rice was okay, a big portion for two but nothing amazing to write home about. Just a very basic dish that one can make. 

Overall, I'm not really sure what the hype is for this place? A pretty tight packed restaurant with  average food in my opinion. Prices are okay, but I don't know if I'd personally be back to visit. I feel like we can find much better quality food at other restaurants.
author: Jay K.

description: Cheap, satisfying food. Great hours and great people. The most salient thing about this restaurant is the friendliness and the history of the people and the food. I was visiting from out of town, and I learned right away how much a part of the community Sam Wo is, which is pretty cool. I ordered the bbq pork wonton noodle soup and ma por tofu. But omg the chili paste sitting at the table is so good, and it was really good with the tofu. The wonton noodle soup had a LOT of noodles and wontons - many places serve more broth than noodles. Great place to eat in the area because there aren't a lot of other Chinese restaurants within 2-3 blocks. They serve reasonable portions so don't expect huge sizes, and I imagine it might get cold in the winter since they don't have a second set of doors to keep the heat from escaping.
author: Hong L.

description: The service here was great. The food here was great. What more is there to say. It was good pricing and great appetizers. Will definitely return when I come back to Dan Francisco!!!!
author: Kyle L.

description: Not worth the wait. Totally disappointed in the food!! I had high expectations of this place & was completely let down. The food was BLAND & very AVERAGE at best. The hubby had beef stew & rice & actually didn't finish it which is a first for him! It had a ton of fat in it & was not the beat tasting. I had opted for a noodle dish with chicken (can't remember the name right now) & kept pouring sou sauce on it trying to give it flavor. Total fail! Will not be going back.
author: Annette S.

description: The rice roll and salt & pepper chicken wings are awesome! I like the wonton with beef stew as well!!!
author: Andre D.

description: They open at 6pm for dinner, so there may be a line out the door waiting for it to open. There was still plenty of seating though. We ordered the chicken chow mein, bbq rice noodle roll, and the duck jook (congee/rice porridge). I will say that it's been a long time since I've had a satisfying bowl of congee and this hit the spot. Would definitely recommend. Well-priced and good food, and cheerful service.
author: Annie L.

description: Do not come. Not worth the wait nor the price. Go to different place.  If you are hungry and this is the only place open, dont go in.
author: Bryan K.

description: Not the warmest or fuzziest spot, but the food was worth it for my BF.  He is bummed that there isnt a Sam Wo in LA.
author: Beatriz R.

description: Sooooo good!! One of my favorite parts of visiting San Francisco!! We had Shrimp Fried rice, spring rolls, donuts, and beef and broccoli. My husband and I were very satisfied! Chinese food hasn't  been the same since!
author: Aliyah B.

description: I went to this place for breakfast, I loved the congee and the egg tart. It's a kinda place that has pretty much everything and doesn't disappoint you.
author: Yan H.

description: Beef chow fun literally has no flavor. Sweet and sour pork is extremely fried.  If you don't got any taste buds, this place is for you. Nothing special here
author: Matthew P.

description: The chow fun on the menu says wide flat rice noodles, and the picture next to the description is wide flat rice noodles. What was delivered was stringy long noodles (similar to angel hair), which is absolutely not what we ordered. False advertising.
author: Sabra M.

description: What is the hype about this restaurant I've been to other restaurant is better than this one at the old location this  restaurant with stink I am from Hong Kong so I know what real good Chinese food taste like
author: David C.

description: Always a good choice in Chinatown! Miss the old restaurant where you walk through the kitchen but nonetheless food is great!
author: Katie A.

description: I saw this place was four stars so I thought I'd try it and grab take out for dinner. We were so disappointed. This may be the worst Chinese food I've ever had. The sesame chicken was all breading, barely any chicken. The photos below show the breading left over after my husband attempted to peel it off in search of chicken. Several pieces didn't have ANY chicken in them. Also, the chicken we did find was cheap dark meat.
author: K W.

description: For straight forward, great value, tasty food. I took my family here today and my very fussy boys said it was the best thing they'd eaten in ages! It loses one mark for the decor, which could do with a bit of a lift, but who cares....the food is fab!
author: Maggie S.

description:
I was pretty happy when I found out that Sam Wo opened in the old Anna's Bakery. I didn't really like Anna's Bakery...

I love tomato beef chow mein and Sam Wo makes it really good. They put big pieces of tomatoes and beef in the dish and the portion is pretty big! 

Their duck chow fun is pretty generous sized too. There are lots of duck pieces and that's awesome! It tastes really good too. 

I haven't dine in yet but I've always called in to pick up my lunch to go. The lady who answers the call is always super sweet sounding. 

I've had their popular cha sui rolls twice and for some reason I do not like it.... I don't like how the rolls are cold... If the rolls were hot, I'll probably enjoy it! 

I'll definitely want to try other dishes on their menu!
author: Alice X.

description: Service was fast but food quality could have been better. We order garkic beef and nudon noodles. To very exited about food taste.
author: Adrian S.

description: This was a wonderful place to eat.  We didn't have to wait for a table.  We thought the restaurant was full but they have a larger area upstairs with larger tables that were perfect for our family of 5.  The food was served quickly and they serve it when it is ready.  Our 4 dishes came out at different times but we were sharing all of the food so it worked out great.  Our kids even enjoyed it and that's saying a lot for our picky eaters.  As we were leaving, there was a line out the door so I'm glad we arrived when we did.
author: Mandy Q.

description: Chicken Chow Mein was SALTY, and the chicken had chewy pieces. Not very impressed. Wife liked the chicken fried rice, but it wasn't anything special either. Average food at best. The place was busy from the minute it opened so maybe I ordered the wrong dish. Or, maybe it's more hype than anything.
author: Augustus G.

description: Love Sam Wo for that late night craving! Perfect place to hit up after a night of bar hopping through North Beach and Chinatown. Love the whole menu but the BBQ pork Chow Mein is my go to. They serve Lucky Buddha too!
author: Patrique R.

description: My wife and I went to Sam Wo's for the first time. We arrived just before 7 and walked straight to a table. We ordered more food than two people should ever eat. We ordered Mongolian beef, sweet and sour pork, house Chow mein, and the combination wonton soup. The food came quickly and was delicious. It was so good, we ate it all.  We rolled out of there completely satisfied. Next time we are in town, we will be back.
author: Adam Q.

description:
First time in the new shop. Went to the old shop few years ago that had been closed down now. 
Arrived at about 2100 on a Saturday evening. Very efficient service, didn't take long for me to get seated
The fried egg with charsiu rice I ordered was awesome. The touch of oyster sauce made the dish more tasty. I ordered a garlic broccoli on the side, which was good too. 
Great service from the team! I enjoyed the Sam wo experience !
author: Matthew E.

description:
I wanted to like their food but was disappointed in their bar-b-que noodle roll. It was bland and needed more egg and cilentro. I am remembering the noodle roll from the original Sam Wo of long ago.  The duck fried rice had too many chunks fat pieces in it that was not edible and bad for one's health...too greasy.  It could have been improved with some chopped cilentro and green onions.  In the past I had their beef stew noodles which was okay but not
memorable.  This was my 2nd try and I'm afraid it left me wanting something more tasty.
author: ES W.

description: Stopped by Sam Wo's for takeout. I had the scrambled eggs with shrimp, the broccoli sautéed with garlic and the crispy chicken wings. Service was quick as the food was ready in 15 minutes from call to pickup. The shrimp and eggs dish had great flavor like a homemade feel. The broccoli with garlic was tasty as well considering they used American style broccoli as opposed to the Chinese style I was expecting. The wings were only so so and seemed warmed over. All in all I would order from here for takeout again as they do a very solid job with the dishes.
author: Marcus W.

description:
Highlights
- Delicious, fast, and cheap new lunch spot discovery
- Chicken and string beans over rice: large portion size, abundant amount of flavor with black bean say and garlic, and included onions as well as carrots with string beans.
- Don't be deceived by the limited seating availability, there were non-stop patrons walking in and they have additional seating upstairs
- Service was quick and efficient. The waiter was really friendly, I guess I wasn't lucky enough to encounter the infamous rude waiter that day. :)

Improvements
- Avoid sitting at the table on the ground level right next to the bathroom. Too close for my dining comfort.

Tips
- Order through the Yelp app for pickup if you don't have time
- I've seen their food offered on Uber Eats delivery
- Located in Chinatown, park in the garage nearby or good luck finding a spot on the street
author: Tracy T.

description: Ordered shrimp with egg. The sauce was salty for me so tell them to easy on the sauce if you like the flavor just right. The service was good.
author: B C.

description:
I've been going here since I was a kid, and my parents and grandparents always ate here. It's an SF Chinatown staple. I have been back twice since it reopened, and the new location feels a lot less cramped than the old hole-in-the-wall space they had before. It still retains the same vibe as the old place, but you no longer have to walk through the kitchen in order to get to the seats. I definitely recommend sitting upstairs, because it's nice and roomy up there and being up on the sort-of balcony gives you a unique experience that you don't get from other restaurants.

As for the food, I have never been disappointed by the dishes here. I definitely recommend the rice noodle rolls with pork as an appetizer. They also have excellent tomato beef chow mein and chow fun, with real tomatoes in it. (The tomato beef chow fun is not specifically on the menu, but you can ask for it). They also have a really good green bean dish with black bean sauce. 

The service in the old days was a lot different than it is now. The place was once legendary for having disagreeable, cranky waiters and waitresses, but now everyone working there is very polite, and service was quick. It gets pretty busy here on the weekends, but I've never had to wait for a table.
author: Molly M.

description: While visiting in Chinatown, my family wanted some authentic Chinese food. So we decided to visit Sam Wo and we are extremely glad we did. We came into the restaurant with 20 minutes to go and most places we go to would give dirty looks but the servers in the restaurants did not. We wanted to order quickly so they took our orders and the food came out within five minutes (great when you have little kids). At the same time, I was a little worried that it came out that fast because I didn't think it would be fresh. Not only was it fresh, it was delicious! Some of the best Chinese food I have ever had and a price that won't break the bank.
author: Terence W.

description:
What a gem for Chinatown! We were stunned by the friendly service, clean and welcoming atmosphere, and the yummy food. 

Happened to come by right before 6,when they open, and saw a line had already formed. They were full pretty soon after so, as my husband said, don't get there late or you'll sit at table 8! (Silly, but true...it's the table right near the bathroom and people opted to wait for another rather than sit there.)

We it ordered: 
-BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll: Great suggestion by many of the other reviews. The pork was tender and great with the mustard sauce. 
-Duck chow fun: I'd opt for something else next time. There wasn't much duck and it wasn't very tender. The overall dish was plain in flavor too.
-String beans with chicken: This was really good and was chosen based on Howard's suggestion. The chicken was so tender and delicious. 

Plus, the service was exceptional. Howard is the friendliest guy, quickly offering us hot tea and asking us about ourselves. The rest of the staff were quick and courteous too. This coupled with low prices and excellent quality made this place worth every penny.
author: Susan G.

description:
It was up a narrow staircase ... piled unceremoniously up top low tables that came to my tongue one of my favorite meals in china town to date. 

Sam Wo will be on my list of loves - and I will remember these unpretentious handmade noodles and duck for many years. 

Thank you Sam Wo.
author: Eric T.

description: For all the hype I expected better. The fried rolls were good but the sweet and sour chicken was tiny pieces of chicken mostly breading. Very crowded and slow service.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Perhaps it's a stroke of luck that I didn't write a review about the original location as my draft had a one star rating.  At that time, I thought the owners were running the business to the ground in a literal sense.
Several years later, the restaurant resurrected in a new location about two blocks away.  My memories are numerous especially during their heyday in the '70's and '80's.  This was often my after school meal and my family became regulars who brought thermoses and mini buckets to get their vaunted jook, wonton with and without noodles, and Chinese donut... well, it's actually a baguette shaped deep fried bread that is the perfect pairing with porridge; the Chinese words translate to "oil fried ghost" in Cantonese.  There was a crew of around four or five men who manned this place in those days, three in the kitchen while one or two worked the front of the house, if you could call it that.  Since most of my food was takeout, I did not encounter the famed Edsel Fong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edsel_Ford_Fong) until my high school years.  He manned both the 2nd and 3rd floors for many years and became more famous than the food coming out of this Chinatown institution.  When the dance and club scene was along Broadway on the outer edge of the neighborhood, many intoxicated and sober partygoers would venture for late night meals and since this place opened until 2 am on weekends, a cult following grew.  For a summary of the reasons for Edsel's 'fame', just read the link above.  
Well, the kitchen staff slowed passed over time and none of the next generation had interest in assuming seven day, twelve hour work shifts so the business was eventually sold after Edsel passed too.  Many believe the Edsel was the actual eccentric owner of the business and the rudeness and flirtatious behavior was merely a part of his act. 
Over time, as with most places in the neighborhood, the food quality and dining demographics changed to be a more budget conscious one.  The mainstays that stayed on the menu were their raw fish salad (steelhead) and BBQ port rice roll aks "guen fun" (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=y1Gyl-FRdOBcowzhlAAzHg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  
After a long and rocky hiatus, the business owners reopened and saved many relics like the signs to harken back memories of those times.  I recently placed a takeout order through Eat24 for two orders of the rice rolls, asking them in the special instructions section to pack them in separate containers as this was our pre-Warrior game meal on a recent weeknight.  Paid by credit card, the transaction went smooth and easy until I opened my bag at the Oracle parking lot and saw only one box.  Luckily, this was not a major issue since we just munched on the pieces like we would if eating sushi.  The flavor and textures were pretty much spot on, though it seemed a bit light on the cilantro.  The food ranks 3.5 stars, but I am docking them for the box issue, especially since there is a specific special instructions form to complete prior to sending the order.
Will stop in and try the food one of these afternoons, but I will definitely temper my expectations.  In my mind, it'll never be the same.
author: Mike C.

description: An Institution. I've only been here a couple times but it's been great. Need to come back! Certainly not a fancy dining experience but it's good it's tasty it's clean it's legendary.
author: Matthew E.

description: Mister Chao still loves Sam Wo.  Mister Chao thinks the BBQ Rolls with Mustard are divine and simply put, you can't beat the value of food for the money.  Mister Chao recommends you come here.
author: Mister Chao ..

description: We found this place on Yelp during our vacation. It was delicious and unique. They had a video playing in the restaurant with its history which was unique. Would definitely recommend and go back when we are in San Francisco again!
author: Sloane S.

description: Decent food, they got me in and out quickly. Wait staff was nice, prices were decent. I'll go back next time I'm in the bay
author: Nicole L.

description:
Interesting place that has a deep history, despite that it began in a different location. Generally, tons of Chinese-American food, but a few "genuine" Chinese dishes, including tendon-y beef stew; we also had the duck fried rice, which was plentiful and delicious.

This place seems super touristy (not too many Chinese people within, though my party was an exception), but is open late, and reasonably inexpensive. Might go again to try a few more things, if I'm in the area.
author: Shendi X.

description: Absolutely terrible. Food was extremely bland. They gave me the wrong item for one of the things for take-out... I wouldn't recommend this place even if you were desperate.
author: Mia S.

description:
I finally had the chance to come to the new Sam Woo. Parking here can be a challenge, you're better off parking in the garage. Came here during lunch time, there were a waitlist to dine in. After waiting for 15mins we finally were seated. 
The location is pretty small much like the old sam woo. But the waitress was really friendly when taking our order. We ordered the famous pork noodle roll and the porridge. Also chow mein with veggies and the scramble egg over rice. So when the pork noodle came that was delicious 5/5 stars. But the rest wasn't so great. The scramble egg plate had a long hair in the eggs. Thats disgusting! And the egg porridge was bland with no taste, had to add salt for more flavor. Overall the new restaurant didn't impress me at all.
author: Curry S.

description:
This is the new and improved Sam Wo, in a different location!  (I think it's where Anna Bakery used to be, or at least next to it.) What's odd is that the staircase feels about the same as the former location's--narrow and low overhang.  But this place is so new and clean looking now!

Food = great! 

We had beef stew noodle soup, tomato beef chow mein, tomato beef chow fun (2x), duck chow fun (x), beef chow fun, dry duck noodle, scrambled egg and beef with rice, scrambled egg and shrimp with rice, beef with mixed vegetables and rice, BBQ pork fried rice, gai lan, egg rolls (4x), and chicken wings (2x).  Everything was piping hot, delicious and great portions.  Can't complain about any of it. (We did order chow mee fun, and they brought us a ton of chow fun, but it wasn't the end of the world.)  

Service = friendly. They were attentive. 

Seating = mostly 2-tops and 4-tops, downstairs and upstairs. And we were lucky enough to have a reservation!  And they pushed together 4 tables to accommodate our party of 10 adults plus two kids.

Prices = cheap to moderate. You can get away with under $10.00 per person, but you'll want to order more. 

Thanks for accommodating my surprise birthday party for party of 10 plus two kids.  And for being so nice about refrigerating the cake and serving the cake.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Hubby really wanted to try Sam Wo since it reopened but not in the same location.  We came with BFF and her hubby.
The waitress suggested the BBQ pork noodle roll, came with mustard sauce.  I didn't like the roll.  Would be better to get the steamed beef, shrimp or pork rolls served at dim sum restaurants. This was a thicker flat sheet of rice noodle, rolled inside with chopped BBQ pork, sliced into 1 inch or more chunks and served cold. 

We also shared a bowl of pork/thousand yr. old egg congee.  It was good.
The tomato beef chow mein was OK but I thought it was a tad too sweet. 
Not sure I'd make a point to come here for dinner but hiubby says he would.
author: Ry T.

description: The food was outstanding, and the price was great - lower than expected.  It is obviously a local hangout, and we were the only non-Asians. They have large tables in the lower level so you end up sharing a table with others.  Our table mates didn't speak English, but were friendly.  The server wanted to make sure the order was correct and showed us her written order - written in Chinese! Couldn't comment on that! We had good size portions and enjoyed every bite!
author: Andrea E.

description:
This place was great!  The food and service were standouts, and the setting is simple and clean. My husband tells me it has changed a fair amount since he was last here 5+ years ago. 

Our family enjoyed the following dishes:
1) Curry chicken with rice (tasty)
2) chicken wings (delicious)
3) broccoli and chicken over rice (very flavorful)
4) string beans (great)
5) chow fun with shrimp (the weak link - this dish was bland and disappointing, but tasted good with some hot chili sauce on it)

The service was great!  They accommodated my mom's special dietary requirements (she had steamed veggies, scrambled eggs, and rice), and were very friendly and helpful.

We sat upstairs in a setting that was simple but pleasant.  

Overall, an awesome spot for Chinese food in Chinatown!
author: Barnali D.

description: Good food and good price. Best part is theyre open late so perfect to hit up after going to town.
author: Nick J.

description: The pork rice noodle roll/wrap was amazing! The mustard cuts through the sinuses like none other! The Ma Por tofu was the most delicious tofu plate I have ever eaten. We washed it all down with some Veggie Chow Fun. My lady had a Tsingtao and I just had one of the most pleasurable meals I've ever eaten. The atmosphere and lady running the joint were insanely charming.
author: Dahveed P.

description: I just had wonton soup at this cozy restaurant, it was ok,  i really needed something warm into my stomach however i would have expected a little bit more taste.  I travel to china a lot and i always order this type of soup when in china,  there was a big difference in tastyness to wanton soup served in chinese restaurants in china.  Price was quite reasonable. Service was very good , attentive and friendly.  Would try the other disses next time I am in San Francisco,  and will probably put more stars when I try the rest of the menu.
author: S A.

description:
This place has been on my bucket list for the longest time! Came up to SF for Chinese New Year and I knew I had to get some Sam Wo for the first time. I came around 3:30pm worried there was going to be a wait, to my surprise no wait, maybe because they were going to close soon. I came in and the staff were very welcoming. I sat down looked at the menu. My eyes wondered over the "dry mix noodle" section. I asked the waitress in Chinese what the dishes were. She said they were "Lo mein". Very interesting how they call It dry mix noodle. I ordered the duck dry mix noodle since on Yelp and Instagram it was the most common item that popped up. In a matter of 5 mins after ordering my mix noodle came! 

The Lo mein is defiantly something you would not find in the San Gabriel Valley. The noodles came in a bowl and had green onions and lettuce on top! That's right ice berg lettuce! I quickly mixed it up to find the sauce and duck meat on the bottom. I took one bite and I was in heaven! The flavor of the gravy sauce with the noodles and duck were amazing! The green onions and lettuce were actually really good with the dish! I quickly gobbled it up and paid.

Sam Wo was so good I took my friends the next day for dinner! We ordered the tomato beef chow mein, wonton noodle soup, and Sichuan beef? I forgot haha. The dishes were great and tasted like classic old school Chinatown cooking. My all time favorite is still the duck dry mix noodle! (Duck Lo mein)! 

If you're in San Franciscos Chinatown, come here!
author: Alex D.

description: Yes this place is 4 stars when it comes to the taste of their food. We ordered shrimp fried rice, shrimp chow fun, pepper salt chicken wings, and beef with string beans. Rice noodles is their specialty and yes it is!  Everything was very tasty and each dish had its own distinct flavors. The dining area is a bit cramp just don't bring more than 5 adults or 4 adults and 2 kids. They have a larger seating area upstairs. The staff are friendly and very helpful. We were in a time crunch and they had us seated in a reasonable amount of time and had us eating within 10 minutes of sitting down.  The only downside that I can come up with is that their portion size is on the smaller end but this means I didn't have that much to take home. I highly recommended this place for the location, being right across from a main parking garage for Chinatown, and for their delicious food.
author: Christina R.

description: We were in SF and was looking for a great Chinese food place. So many to choose from but after reading the reviews, we decided on Sam Wo. Not familiar with SF, didn't realize this place has been here for so long. It is a small galley place but also has tables upstairs. The line was long but the wait wasn't too bad considering the size of the place. If you are in a hurry, I would suggest take out. We ordered the chow fun noodles and it was good. We also ordered the pork roll and it was amazing, come to find out it is one of the most popular on the menu. We will definitely come back when we are back in SF.
author: Kristi P.

description:
Solid 4 star restaurant.

Service: not great, waiter was irritated on little things, like can I have more tea please, or can I get a side of sauce please? So overall service was not great. 4/10 stars for service.

Price: lunch, prices were very good. Under $10 for a meal for lunch. Definitely doable. An appetizer, taxes, and my rice pork dish was $14!! :-)

Quantity: large plate of food! Deff great amount for what you pay for. I didn't finish everything... Lol so full.

Quality: I would say very good. We all loved our food, and we shared too, it was very good.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Sam Wo is back and it is amazing. So much cleaner and so friendly.

If you really need to see how atrocious and "authentic" it used to be, don't take my word for it, take Conan O'Brien and Martha Stewart's word for it: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Es0-GnG8qGs"

I've had the various Chinese dishes here like chow fun, sweet and sour this and that, but really you need to come here for the BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll. The prices are fantastically cheap, and the roll is so so good. I think the rest of the dishes are blander and saltier than I expected (more mainstream)., but hey I really appreciate the quality and value of food you get here with the ability to just pick up and go.

Definitely check it out for a unique SF Chinatown experience, you won't find street parking, but the Portsmouth Square garage is nearby and so is the park with all the mah jong and tai chi that you could ask for.
author: Joseph L.

description:
After a very long wait on New Years Day, we finally got a table for two. There is a list if all the tables are full and you can choose to wait for a table upstairs (we didn't but we wondered if it was nicer up there). The ambience on the first floor was fluorescent but we were way too hungry to wait. 

We got the BBQ Pork Noodle Rolls. The pork inside was delicious but I did not expect the noodles to be uncooked so I would've enjoyed it better if it was a warm fried dish rather than a cold one. Still good. Got it with the house mustard sauce as another Yelper recommend. That was spicy! It hit our throats like knives! It was a bitter spicy rather than a hot spicy so we decided to forgo the sauce and eat the rolls by themselves. 

For our main dishes we order chow fun with mixed vegetables and Mongolian beef. Both were delicious and big servings. We had to take half of the food home for leftovers. 

Overall the meal came out to be ~ $25 which is fairly good. They take card!
author: Jess D.

description:
A must while visiting San Fran is to get some really good take out.  I have nothing to compare, whether it is authentic or not, but if my buds and stomach agree, that's all right by me!  We rode the cable car down and hopped off near Chinatown.  Of course, we consulted the fine reviewers of Yelp to help direct us where to go.  The fist place was top rated, however they were capitalizing off of that.  Their prices were wayyyy too much.  Chow mien was like $20...pass! Back to Yelp.  Luckily, there was a nifty whole in the wall right around the corner. 

When walking up to this place, I thought we would have to go downstairs, and honestly, it looked a little sketch.  But my friend saw the entrance was same level. Whew! 

We walk in to tight quarters.  If you don't like your backside being grazed while ordering, because the space between register and table is so tight, this place may not be for you. It was still cute though. Plus, there are tables upstairs to dine at.

I placed my order, which was way less than $25.  The wait time was standard.  They were pretty busy though, so I was actually surprised.  We took our food then Ubered? back to our Air BnB.  Unwrapped everything and chowed. down.  I ordered chow fun, and did I have fun chowing on that! The noodles had just the right crunch to them.  I also ordered egg rolls.  I would advise any who order to take them out of the box, as they will sit in the oil.  I didn't realize until I took a bite, but mine were heavily saturated in oil. But I still ate it.  The  room was silent because we were enjoying our food so much. Very thankful to have stopped at this place.
author: Demetria W.

description: Just wanted to go to a quiet place to eat. But disrespectful adults being super loud and when I wanted to go down stairs they need to make unnecessary compliment calling other customer bitches and making other foul compliments. The waiters there was no help at all but saying to call the cops instead of telling the loud customers to quite down. To future customer Sam Wo has been reopened again because they're previous restaurant is unsanitary. Many customers would find bugs and other disgusting things in their food. But for a fact San Wo been open for a long time in San Francisco but as a food critic Sam Wo does not have good food.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Great place for authentic Chinese food.  Fresh and fast service. Good portions and reasonable prices. I really enjoyed the hot tea. A must if you are in Chinatown.
author: Kat L.

description: Delicious! Like eating at home! The food is very tasty, not too salty and fresh! Small place with larger tables upstairs. Great service and FAST! Closes early though so hurry!
author: Michelle D.

description: Quick and friendly serivce, great food. Highly recommend. The wings for appetizer we're great!
author: Ben B.

description:
Next time you grave for greasy fried chicken or meaty taco after a night of partying, try the porridge with Chinese donuts and the Dry Duck Noodle at Sam Wo. That being said, food is still spectacular when eaten sober and given how inexpensive this place is, it's definitely worth visiting. 

One star off is due to the dissonance between 2 different visits under different level of drunkness.
author: Nina T.

description: It really is authentic Cantonese food. It's either bland or full of flavor, but that's a good thing. I ordered the Pork and Preserved Egg Jook (Rice Porridge) and it was actually pretty good for my liking. It was a bit bland but you can always season it. The jajangmien(?) was not what we expected it to be but it was still a unique flavor. Sweet and Sour Pork was okay. Good flavor but not as much as you want. Wonton noodle soup was also okay. Wontons were delicious but I don't know about the broth. Mongolian beef had a strong flavor punch to it if you like salty. Other than the iffiness with the food, the restaurant is really nice and cozy. Friendly service. I especially loved the newspaper articles in the bathroom, really cute.
author: Annameuy S.

description:
Although this place seem like a really bust down place from the outside. But omg was the inside nice, and the food is freaking amazing!!!! They've been opened for more than 100 years now, and I see why they're still in business. 

Must try: sweet and sour chicken.
author: Duc H.

description:
Thank you for opening once again! We tried the same items weve had before at the old place; bbq pork rice noodle roll, chow fun, won ton soup, and vegetable shrimp over rice. the food still taste the same as it was before, delicious.

The only thing that has changed is the place. It lacks the raggedy look and their prices went up a bit.
author: Nino J V.

description:
Lunch at 12:30 on a Saturday, for 2 people:
- not crowded at all, got a seat right away
- looks to be a local hang-out, thank goodness

Eats:
- chicken and string beans with white rice: easy, quick, like my mom's cooking. Good mix of chicken and string beans in black bean sauce.
- pork and thousand year old egg porridge: thick porridge, just how I like it! A bit bland (the porridge part) but had plenty of fixins' (pork and egg). This NEVER HAPPENS! What a delight!
- total bill was $18.

Cleanliness: they reopened I think in 2015, so pretty clean through and through.

Improvement: maybe they can refill water a bit more. But we understand there was just 1 waiter and he was pretty busy.

Return trip: for sure! Simple, no pretentious hipsters here, just real local food.
author: Mary H.

description: Excellent service,  i guess they are trying to make up for their history of having the world's rudest waiter. Average food, but worth checking out for its historical status.
author: Jess C.

description: Go to late night spot when I am drunk in San Francisco. Delicious Chinese food with just the right amount of grease that I need to sop up some of the booze and mitigate the damage I will endure in the morning. The chow fun, duck fried rice, and pork rolls are all winners. The wonton noodle soups is a great bang for your buck and is jammed full of noodles, wontons, and at least a half a pig worth of BBQ pork.
author: dan c.

description:
Sam Wo was regular, irregular and cheap
Regular: because the good food wasn't delicious, just good.
Irregular: because we ordered several dishes and some of them were not that good.
Cheap: well I don't need to explain that one right?
So I guess there would be other better options in Chinatown
author: Neb K.

description: I absolutely love the rice noodles! It's 100% handmade and super smooth. I haven't eaten such good rice noodles in so long! We came in for dinner and had to wait for 20 minutes since they were so busy. Apparently, this restaurant has been opened for more than 100 years, was closed and just recently re-opened. Their egg noodles were good too, my sisters loved it. The restaurant is conveniently located in Chinatown so it's a good resting point.
author: Tran N.

description: Great to visit an old friend! I've been eating at this place since about 1991, guess that still makes me a newbee all things considered. Though closed a few years back for health code violations, this new and clean spot definitely will last another 100 years. They've tastefully used the same old marble tables and are serving the same yummy oolong tea they've served for eons. The wontons are the same too, arguable some of my favorite in the city. The place is decorated with some old memorabilia from the last incarnation, but luckily none of the vermin were spared! My waitress was too nice... perhaps they save the rude waiters for the 2am drunk night crew. All in all, it's great to be back in touch with this old friend and I look forward to returning again and again. Congrats folks!
author: Brian J.

description: Food was average, not bad If your close by but we definitely had better Chinese food elsewhere during our stay. Place is very small, luckily it was only the 2 of us, big parties 4 or more had a hard time getting a table, some passed it up due to the wait/availability of a table.
author: Josh M.

description: Delicious! Runny eggs and beef was great! Sweet and sour chicken was awesome! Chicken dry noodles were very flavorful! Only complaint was that the chow fun could have used a little salt and they needed to refill out water. Definitely worth it! Yum!
author: Amanda T.

description: This place is a true gem! Its cheap for sf standards and portions are large. Food is as good as it gets, total hole is the wall. Two stories of seating so while there is almost always a line waiting to be seated, it goes quick.
author: FastFijian S.

description:
Sam Wo is back!  Imagine my surprise when I happened upon Sam Wo today while I was hunting for a place for lunch in Chinatown.  It turns out that today is their first day open after their old location closed over 3 years ago.  Brings back such fond memories!

Don't expect rude staff, greasy food, or a grimy atmosphere.  The new Sam Wo is bright & clean with fresh, delicious food!  I have to admit I was kind of hoping to be berated by the little old waitress from years ago, but she was nowhere to be found.  I'll just have to remember the good ol' days when we would go to Sam Wo for cheap food, BYOB, dingy dining room, & ridiculously rude staff.  Until the bill came, then it was "Thank you very much!!" with a huge smile.  It turns out you can get all that at numerous restaurants in Chinatown, so go to the new Sam Wo for the friendly staff & yummy Chinese food.
author: Erin S.

description:
I got their BBQ Pork Rice Roll out of curiosity because I have heard Sam Wo was a Chinatown staple back in the days and they just reopened. I stopped by around 12:40PM and the wait was quite long for take long. I had to come back in 20 minutes to pick up my simple order. 

However, the staff was super nice and apologetic. The rice roll turns out to be quite delicious. I saw lots of people order their chow fun dishes and they look good and come in big portion. 

I will love to try their congee and Beef Chow Fun next time!
author: Athena C.

description:
I'm sooooo happy Sam Wo is back! No, it's not the same, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. That charming, dingy, three-story hole in the wall has been replaced by a clean, brightly lit two-story diner a few blocks away. The owners have obviously taken great care in preserving the past with the menu, historic signs and photos, and the lovely old marble-top tables -- spiffed up with red paint -- while bringing the restaurant up to modern standards. Best of all, they even installed a dumb waiter! That damn near brought tears to my eyes.

On Saturday night of their soft launch, fans lined up out the door. The upstairs isn't open yet and the menu is temporarily limited -- but many favorites are on there, including the uniquely fabulous pork rice noodle roll. Prices may have gone up by a buck or so, but they're still cheap as hell. The famously cranky wait staff has been replaced by a bunch of really nice, if slightly befuddled people. (They were very busy; I don't blame them.) 

I'll still miss the derelict charm of the old Sam Wo's, but life is change, and the goodness of the new incarnation definitely helps ease the transition. And now I no longer have to worry that my guests might get food poisoning when I take them to my favorite Chinatown restaurant. (Yeah, that happened.) Here's to another 100 years of Sam Wo!
author: P S.

description: Needed a late night meal and this place is open late so it was perfect. Food was delicious and reasonably priced, and the waiter/worker there was friendly and had a good sense of humor. This is a good stop for those late night food runs.
author: Annie W.

description:
Finally got to eat at the Sam Wo redux and we are super pleased.  We met our kids here the other night for dinner and it was a joy to eat here.  The new place is on Clay Street-  They have a video screen out front which shows a short video of the history of Sam Wo and its a great way to share this special spot with folks.  

The food is good.  But really the best part of our night was our waiter HOWARD.  He is the epitome of a kind person and excellent customer service employee.  He is personable, outgoing and a long time member of the Sam Wo fan club.  

We ordered the BBQ Pork Rolls to start and continued with Tomato Cha Su Chow mein, Kung Pao Shrimp, Cruncy delicious string beans, Gai lan stir fried in Garlic and oil and a Chicken with Fun noodles.  It was delivered really quickly even thought it was super busy and it was hot and delicious!
author: Erin S.

description: Delish Chinese food-what a find-thank you Yelp!!!  I am a native San Franciscan and can't believe I have never eaten at this gem.  It was so worth the wait.  Authentic tasty dishes-loved the Kung Pao, The Mongolian beef, the chicken fried rice as well as the pork chow main.  We will be back to munch away soon.  Our server was friendly and genuine-we ate upstairs.
author: Nancy M.

description: Aside from the bad food and bad service, they didn't have soap in the restroom. So unless the workers have a separate restroom to themselves, you get the idea...
author: Annie L.

description:
WORST SERVICE EVER! GO SOMEWHERE ELSE
I have been a regular at this restaurant since they reopen..their food is nice..service usually is okay..its Chinatown afterall..what do you expect right?
 so today I went to pick up my togo..when I got there I found out they got my order wrong..the ABC lady..the younger waitress did not apologize instead she gave me nasty attitudes and told me I should be more clear next time bc ppl usually dont order this.
really?wtf?
will not be back!
author: Jessie L.

description: I love Sam Wo Restaurant. This place is authentic, clean and the waiter is awesome. It takes no time to get your food after you order- so if you have a short lunch timeframe, this place is quick and easy. The food is delicious and well prepared- wonton soup and chicken broccoli are my favorite. The price is reasonable and not expensive at all.
author: Mary D.

description: This was the worst food experience I've had in San Francisco Chinatown. The wonton noodle was soggy and had no taste. The jook was very bland.  The service is ok but don't ask too many question.  The hk milk tea was the only good thing I had there.  Definitely not recommended
author: Alex C.

description: Just finished a fantastic dinner, at Sam Wo. This food is-by far-the best Chinese food I've ever had. Service  was great. We will definitely be back when we visit the area.
author: Karen K.

description: Old school Amaricanized Chinese food at it's finest. It's not what you would find in a real Hong Kong style Cantonese restaurant bit it's not bastardized food with cheap ingredients. They don't skimp on the meat nor is it enhamced with MSG or tenderizers.  Good luck getting a seat quickly as this place is no secret to tourists and locals alike.
author: MARKET W.

description:
At the risk of revealing my real age, I started going to Sam Wo more than 50 years ago,

It was a great place to eat late night. Open until 3 am, with no fried food after 1:30. 

Sam wo was the home of the surly, loud Edsel Ford Fung, renown as the world's rudest waiter. It was all an act of course. Eddie fed many a hungery hippie who found himself out of money.

Tomato Pork Chow Mein was $1.75 a plate. Rice noodle roll was $1,00.

Sam wo closed on Washington St. A few years ago and has reopened in a new space a block away.

The stools and marble tables are still there as is the dumb waiter and the buzzer. Except it is now a OSHA safe and apptoved ELECTRIC DUMB WAITER WITH DOORS as opposed to yhe old shaft with a rope to shout the orders down to the kitchen and haul the dishes up to the 2nd fLOOR THAT edsel ruled supreme.

Ceramic tea pots have been replaced with stainless, they sell soda bnow, take credit xards, serve water, and sell souvenir t-shirts and bottled mustard.

So I ordered my old usual tomato pork chow mein now priced at a bargain $8.95.

The recipies are the same but the taste, while good, was a little off. Noodles were gumy and not as crispie or flavorful as I remember them.

On my way out I noticed why. Boxes of packaged won ton noodles, obviously made by machines in a factory.

At the original Sam Wo they made the noodles in house, by hand. There is a difference.

So while I wish I could rate higher because I cried when the original closed, the new version is not as good due to buying processed foods with perservatives added.

But as they say, you can never go back.

So if you never ate at the orginal, you'll probably like the food and the price is certainly right.

The spirit of Edsel still permeates the place.
author: Norm G.

description:
Sam Wo is one of the best restaurants in Chinatown. Although it is a touristy restaurant it's still a great restaurant. We had the bbq pork roll (just as good in person as we saw on reviews), chow fun (which was amazing and very authentic, highly recommend). I'm knocking off a point because one of the members of our group got bbq pork curry noodles, which tasted like ramen noodles within a small spicy soup bowl, and it definitely was the wrong thing to order.
Otherwise, great environment to eat in, good for families and tourists and whoever! This is the restaurant in Chinatown SF you must go to.
author: David A.

description: Best in the city, hands down. The bbq rice rolls are the go to! Small old world S.F. type location. Favorite dim sum in the city.
author: Sean A.

description:
A place for the Guailo in terms of taste.

Service was good and staff friendly and fast.
author: M. K.

description:
This place was great! Wanted fried rice before I left San Francisco and it was the only place open. Glad it was because the food was great! Service was excellent and friendly. We ordered a few different items and everything was delicious!!! The gentleman taking care of service upstairs was very friendly, asking people where they were visiting from.
Will be back on my next SF visit!
author: Jacqueline F.

description: Visiting the city for the first time, wanted good food where the locals go. Not disappointed.
author: Jacky A.

description:
like many others, i've never heard of the old Sam Wo's. heard a lot of celebration noises when they had their grand opening and finally decided to pop in today. came around 11:15 am and it was already starting to get packed. they ended up seating us upstairs. both floors don't have much tables so be sure to come early or you'll for sure have to wait a bit. 

food: we ordered the beef stew dry mixed noodles, bbq pork rice noodle rolls, pork and preserved pork jook, and some chinese donuts. NO REGRETS. the bbq pork rice noodles are so delicious; chasu and cilantro stuffed inside soft rice noodles. the chinese donuts are a little bland but once you eat it with the jook it's like heaven. jook could use just a pinch more salt but mix some white pepper in there and you are golden. they don't skimp out on the preserved egg either, i got some major big chunks in my jook. the beef stew noodles were so tasty and filling. the beef is tender and comes in big chunks as well. everything tasted so homemade and didn't wasn't too oily. 

looking forward to coming back to try everything on their menu woohoo!

ps they accept card, unlike most places in chinatown woohoo!
author: Ava F.

description: Awesome Chinese Food!! Best Chinese food I had!! Highly recommended. The place is a little tight for the amount of people they serve.
author: Logan H.

description: Waking through Chinatown and found this place.  Very casual and unassuming but line was out the door!  It was quick. Got seated and had hot tea. Then ordered chicken chow fun, beef broccoli, sweet and sour chicken, and chicken and bok choy. Everything was amazing!  Good quantity, and prices were reasonable!  Excellent service too.
author: A S.

description:
Was craving some warm soupy noodles and decided to venture out here to Sam Wo on a weekday for lunch. Service was prompt and I was seated immediately. 

I ordered the beef stew/wonton with hor fun and the beef stew was very tender and flavorful. Wonton was also filled with pork and bits of shrimp. My issue was the hor fun and the broth itself. I understand these hk style soup noodles often use the standard broth but something went terribly wrong with this one. It was flavorless. I took the first sip and I thought, no way. Sam Wo has been around for 100 years how could they mess up on the broth?!

2nd sip. Sad face. The hor fun was overcooked and was mushy in the bowl. The broth was probably the most bland thing. If it's a good noodle soup, having a decent broth is crucial! 

Perhaps I came on a really off day, but I would recommend getting their porridge instead as that's their stable.
author: Sarah I.

description:
I confess, I had not been to the old Sam Wo in decades.  I held it as a fond memory, especially those in which we, the patrons, crossed paths and swords with Edsel Ford Fong. It was a place to be experienced.   I felt sadness that the venerable old joint closed. When the old Anna Bakery closed without any notice, one wondered what would take it's place, if anything.  Happily, Sam Wo has risen like a phoenix and moved into the space.  They salvaged some old signage from the old place and moved into the crisp and clean space.  There is an upstairs (where we ate today) and a sign in sheet down on level one (make sure you sign in or you won't get a table).  21 tables, the place is small, but does not feel too terribly cramped.  They've just opened, so you need to give the staff a break, service is not spotty, they're simply busy and getting the hang of things.  Service was very friendly!

Food, well, #1 for me, the cold rice rolls with bbq pork.   OMG, those are delicious!  OMG the Sam Wo mustard!  Why they have little packets of "chinese mustard" on the table is an insult to the little dish of spicy gold they serve with the rice roll.  It has a nice kick, really nice fresh wasabi like kick!

My companion had the beef stew soup with rice noodles and said it was very good.  I ordered bbq pork and won ton soup.    Mine was delicious.  Mind, they are not huge bowls of soup like you'd see in a pho place.  That being said, we shared the rice roll (which was huge) and were both very satisfied and full upon leaving.  

There is a huge to-go business for them, which might slow some table orders down.  We waited to have our order taken, but, the food arrived pretty fast.

The decor has some lovely nostalgic items, like some of the old panels from the old place with the well worn signs.  Lost of photos of people with Edsel Ford Fong, so it's nice they are embracing the history of the place.  Only sadness was the non-use of the dumbwaiter they installed.  The waitstaff carried trays up and down the stairs.  I give them kudos for that and not spilling!

My lunch companion and I both said we will make a return trip.  Today was the first soup day of the season.  We made it a good one.
author: Donna H.

description:
We went to this restaurant based on the excellent reviews and we ordered the following: 
BBQ pork rice noodle rolls
Pork & preserved egg congee
Shrimp chow mein
Salt & pepper chicken wings
We were a party of 5 and one couple owns a restaurant.
The congee and chow mein was not steaming hot.
The congee was not cooked long enough.
The portion for the chow mein was too small
for the price.
The other two items definitely were not excellent.
We do NOT recommend!
author: Calvin G.

description:
Sweet and sour pork best I've ever had.  Fresh, crispy veggies. Tangy sweet sauce. Tasty fried spring rolls.  Light on the oil. Fast, friendly service.  Heart of Chinatown.   Reasonable prices.
Classic hole in the wall.
author: Robert S.

description: Sam Wo doesn't need me to sing it's praises, but I will! I love this place and I will keep dreaming of the day I can return.  First timer? Howard will talk you through any questions you might have. Try the pork noodle roll, it's the bees knees. I ordered the Mongolian Beef with a side of steamed white rice.  My hubby ordered the Chicken Chow Fun. All of it was flavorful and delicious!
author: Priscilla R.

description: Get the BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll!!! Totally worth it and very tasty. So don't feel bad if there's a long ass line or wait time for it. You won't regret the wait. They stay open late so whether you're an early bird or a night owl, they are open.
author: Martine D.

description: 3 words-cold noodle rolls! I have never seen them at any other Chinese spot. They're too die for! Who doesn't love cold noodles with cilantro and delicious pork!!!!!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Food is ok, but definitely not worth the wait. Service is not good either and the venue needs some cleaning.
author: George M.

description: First restaurant I ate at when I moved here from LA, this is what you call authentic Chinese food, I love their wontons, rice rolls, and you gotta walk through the kitchen to get to the restaurant lols
author: Teena K.

description:
It was my first time back in 20+ years. I've been waiting for the re-opening to take my bf there. 
We went before the street fair today and kind of forgot the Chinese New Year parade is today, so thought it would be a real hassle to get there from the peninsula. Not a problem since we arrived several hours before it started. The garage is right across the street. It was full when we got there but they have you wait at the gate until a space opens up, then let you in.
We ordered the egg rolls, salt & pepper chicken wings, beef stew and combo wonton soup. Everything was good, portions are large and the service is great. The stew has a lot of connective tissue and fat, which is the usual way it's served, so if you've never had it, be warned it's not like American beef stew. My bf loved it.
We'll be back if we're in the area.
author: Denise M.

description: One of the best services I ever have in Chinatown.  Food is above average. The scrambled egg rice plates are nicely done.
author: Aaron L.

description: I remember reading about this place and it's notorious rude waiter when I was young. An odd bit of local color. These days it's a reliable spot for large, tasty portions. Good service. Not too pricy.
author: Patrick S.

description:
My brother-in-law mentioned, "did you know Sam Wo opened a new location in Chinatown?"  What! you're kidding me right?  No.  It's true.  Fantastic!  

I'm back, baby.  Yes, went the next day (Saturday).  Waited outside till they opened at 11 a.m.  Ordered my BBQ pork rice noodle roll and duck chow fun.  Just like I remember.  I even bought a t-shirt ($25).  

The staff is also a lot nicer, though that did not stop me from going to the previous place.  

Parking is tough (try Portsmouth Garage across the street).  Good luck.  But absolutely a must visit if you are in the area.  I go anytime I'm close.
author: Axs S.

description: Amazing house noodle and the bbq pork noodle roll was to die for. I'd eat that every day if I live here.
author: Jasmine A.

description: I went with my family. The service was friendly but the food tasted more like fast food than real fresh food. It is rather inexpensive which is nice and very simply laid out.
author: Christy C.

description:
BAD SERVICE.  Only treat white people and tourists nice, treats locals as trash.

We signed in to wait for a table for 2 upstairs. After a short while, they gave us the table in front of the restroom downstairs. We then reminded them of our request ands we waited a little more for a table upstairs.  By the time we are about to get our table, there's a party of 10 arrived. When another wait is getting our table ready, this waitress (the short-hair one} told the waiter not to give us the table upstairs to make room for that fucking party of 10 instead.

We did't even get water (that we have requested) until we were finished when we get our check.  But they treat white people like god.
author: Fred L.

description: Came for some no frills Chinese comfort food on a cold rainy day and Sam Wo delivered. I got the wok scrambled eggs with bbq. It was like an omelet stuffed with bbq pork served on a bowl of rice with oyster sauce drizzled on it. Simple yet filling. My friend got the vegetarian chow fun and really enjoyed it as well. Like I said, nothing fancy. Don't expect ethnic authenticity and stick to the basics.
author: Jean K.

description: Arrived in San Francisco and we wanted good authentic Chinese food.  Thank God for Yelp as Yelpers directed us to Sam Wo restaurant in Chinatown. They were right on!  Small unassuming place with great fragrances and where locals eat. No fancy decor just good food, sorry Great food!  Having grown up in NYC I appreciate good Chinese food.  Staff were super friendly and helpful. My wife had chicken fried rice which they also include shrimp and some pork. Not very greasy, not very salty. Just right taste.  I had curry chicken with white rice and appreciated a spicy good tasting dish that did not kill my taste buds.. Tea was also good. Utensils along with chop sticks provided at each table. Watched a video about Mr Wu and his resturant and also how he was featured on one of the late night talk shows (Conan O'Brien). Highly recommend this place for the authentic Chinese food experience not a fancy schamsi tourist trap rip off
author: Louis A.

description:
Sam Wo is back! The decor and cleanliness is different (much nicer), but the food, family, and service is the same as always. The menu is relatively simple home Chinese cooking sorts of dishes, but they're done really, really well. We had the

- BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll - a Sam Wo classic that is still really good
- Chicken Jook - not as flavorful as I would have hoped, but the consistency was good
- House Chow Fun - texture and flavorful was good. I might try the beef chow fun next time as a classic, but no complains
- Fried Rice with duck - also good. Would probably try a different meat in it next time

And of course, it's cheap. Although I typically am adventurous and like to try new restaurants, I feel no need to eat anywhere except at Sam Wo whenever I am in SF chinatown.
author: Kevin L.

description: Our server, Howard was THE BEST. We Came in on Fri night at 9:30pm with a group of four. We ordered bbq rolls, beef chow fun, shrimp and green beans and ma pao tofu. The best part of our visit was our attentive and friendly server Howard. He worked so hard to make sure everything was ok. He was the only waiter for the upstairs room and it was not easy for him. I give him props for his service.
author: Amy L.

description: I visited that spot first time, i found remarkable but second time they had meat in my food when i strictly order vegetarian food even though they made mistake i have them another chance, requested to be carefull but same mistake. Their manager offered me discount but when i saw my bill no discount and no apology. If you are vegetarian please do not go. They took my plate back so that i cant take photo either. Sorry i had to put that review coz this time i couldnt stop myself.
author: Lakshdeep S.

description: If you're looking for fine dining this isn't the place. You're not going to find ambience and you're not going to find awesome service, but what you will find is exceptional authentic Chinese food ,cheap ,plentiful and open till 4 AM.
author: Sean B.

description:
Good wonton noodle soup. Kung Pao Shrimp is another staple there but comes with more onions than shrimp.
Take-out order was ready in 15 minutes
author: Ren O.

description: Great food, fast service, good service! Highly recommend. Only downgrade is crowded and no A/C
author: Santiago R.

description: Amazing Chinese food! Get there early or you'll have to wait in line, but trust me it's worth the wait!
author: Allison S.

description: All 4 dishes we received were totally inedible and flavorless. Best thing to order is white rice. Cannot believe how people rated this place so high. They must never have had Chinese food before.
author: Anila N.

description:
My beau and I decided to dine in China Town after seeing a movie on 12/25/2016.  Rather than preselecting the place, we decided to see where chance took us.  The gamble paid off!!!  As we were walking by Sam Wo, I noticed their sign that said "Cooking for 100 Years!"  A quick check here on Yelp, and I saw 4 stars after over more than 300 reviews, and I know how much more like people are to Yelp a bad experience.

We were welcomed in, seated promptly, and well served, despite the busy Christmas rush.  We sat at a table on the ground floor, though there was obviously some seating upstairs (very narrow stair up, it appears, so be aware).  The server was a pleasant young lady, willing to give her suggestions and answer questions.  We started with the beef noodle roll appetizer, then had Duck chow fun and scrambled egg over rice with shrimp (you can get it wet if you ask, which I highly recommend).  Everything was delicious and served promptly, but there was plenty of time between the two courses.  I also had hot milk tea for the first time and was pleasantly surprised.

I don't get up to SF very often, but the next time I'm in China Town, Sam Wo is on my list for dining.
author: Tim B.

description:
Rude waitress. Very bad service. 
Food is okay, not really special. 
I called ice water and milk tea. But I got a half glass of water with no ice. The same with milk tea. There was no ice at all. 
Waitress handed the bill and asked for tip right  away. She even rudely ran after me on my way out to ask for the tip though I left it on the table.
author: Polaris N.

description:
Thank you Sam Wo for a tasty late night meal...two nights in a row  We were visiting from L.A. and this was a spot I wanted to try and glad we did! Yummy shrimp chow fun, fried rice, chinese broccoli and sweet and sour pork. The last item we tried was the beef curry. While the base was good all the chunks of meat were very fatty. This was disappointing since we love curry. Maybe they'll read this and make the necessary changes as who wants to eat chunks of fat! 
The staff was super friendly too! When we are next back in town we will make sure to stop by to enjoy a meal!
author: Christa W.

description: Stopped here for a late lunch on a weekend. As we walked in, we were seated right away and service was fast and friendly throughout. We settled on hot tea, oolong, and iced waters. We shared our orders of their BBQ pork noodle roll, Chinese broccoli, veggie eggrolls, and shrimp chow mein. My favorite of the dishes were the chow mein and bbq pork roll. The chow mein plate was plentiful and the flavors were bursting with every bite. Usually don't order this dish so was pleasantly surprised when it exceeded my expectations. Secondly, I enjoyed the taste of the BBQ pork noodle roll but the rice roll was a bit too thick for my liking. The other dishes were average. When I re-visit, I would definitely order the chow mein again.
author: Shong H.

description: Not sure what the big hoopla about this place is. I went here for lunch with a coworker, and probably ordered the wrong things. He got a soup, and I got the egg over rice with bbq pork which wasn't very good. The oyster sauce wasn't very good with the egg, and it wasn't very flavorful. I had to add tons and tons of hot sauce to make it better. The good thing about this place is that it's fast, and serves a lot of traditional chinese dishes if you're into that. I wouldn't come back.
author: Olivia C.

description: Recommend their fish jook, bbq pork rice noodle rolls, dumplings and milk tea.  Very friendly services.  Don't forget to sign-in for seating.
author: K C.

description: This is a historic hole in the wall. The menu seems extra authentic because it has chop suey. I ate the fried chicken wings, which were delicious. I also had the wonton soup, but I thought I could taste the tap water. The soup was hot and the service fast. The prices are good and I like the marble tabletops. It is especially well set up for groups of four. If you have a larger group there is additional seating available upstairs.
author: Karen H.

description: This place has a 100 yrs history of serving food. Food was delicious and service was very quick. The servers were very friendly. Overall had a very good experience.
author: Oindrilla D.

description: Very affordable Chinese food with big portions! The place is very warm because of its design. It's a small family restaurant but I recommend to go check it out! Their BBQ pork noodle roll has to be the best dish on their menu!
author: Tony W.

description:
I found the original Sam Wo's back in the early 1990's with a couple of buddies on a day trip to San Francisco.  We were starving for good chinese food and our only item on the checklist as we strolled through Chinatown was that we had to walk through the kitchen to get from the front door to the seating area.  We saw Sam Wo's and knew it was the place!  We even encountered some of the rudest service ever!  :)

Flash forward 25 years and I was in San Francisco recently and in the mood for Sam Wo's.  Sadly, a Google search revealed the original restaurant was gone, but like a phoenix, Sam Wo's arose in a new location.

Same great food, but much cleaner and more friendly service now.  Definitely worth a visit!
author: Chris P.

description: We ate here while on vacation in SF. We wanted to eat at a well known Chinese place and this had good name recognition. I have never eaten at the old location and we got a little bit of history from our Lyft driver on the way over. It's your typical small, Chinatown restaurant - no frills. There are only a few tables downstairs and more room upstairs. We were told to go upstairs and found a roomy "booth."
