The waiter upstairs was super friendly and asked us where we were from, what places we've seen in the city, etc. We had wonton soup (generously sized dumplings), combo fried rice (with BBQ pork), beef with string beans, and chicken chow mein. All were extremely tasty and satisfying. We were offered some hot tea also, which made our experience complete. I recommend this place if you're in town. It does the job of "I had good Chinese food in Chinatown" quite well.
author: AP C.

description: Very good service. Otherwise, dreadful. The limited menu options and quality of the dishes left me scratching my head. I felt like we had wandered into a 1950s small-town version of a Chinese restaurant in which the chef had never heard of actual Chinese cuisine (or, for that matter, even Americanized Chinese cuisine). San Francisco is supposed to represent the pinnacle of Chinese cuisine; this place doesn't seem to have gotten the memo. Disappointing and to be avoided.
author: Roger K.

description: This is the famous one...Edsel is laughing at you. Grab a t shirt and those Google techies will have no idea that you are really cool and not a wannabie.
author: Curtis P.

description: Excellent food! I looked this place up on yelp as I was walking through Chinatown and I really wanted to eat some tasty Chinese food. Great flavors and definitely great service. The food was also brought out to the table (party of 10 might I add) rather quickly! I love restaurants that fit the "hole in the wall" description, and this restaurant does just that. It's very cozy! The only reason I give it a 4 out of 5 is because a part of me wishes that more effort would have been put into the presentation of the food. Other than that, GREAT culinary experience. I would highly recommend if you're in Chinatown in the Bay Area.
author: Samantha M.

description: Its great! I ordered the roll and fried rice noodle. I loved all of them. But there are little space to accommodate many people. You have to wait if you come here at hot time.
author: Min B.

description: Gave this place a try because of the Yelp reviews! It was really great food!  Best fried rice I've ever had!  The service was a little iffy which is why the four stars! The hot tea they brought was nice, but they didn't seem to know what I was asking when I asked for sweetener.  I guess it is San Francisco where people are more health conscious, but tea without sweetener is wretched! I did finally get some sugar.
author: Melissa W.

description: Good food, friendly service. Come early if you don't want to wait. There is an upstairs seating area so check that out. House Chow Fun was delicious
author: Mindy B.

description: I love that they're open late. I don't actually love their food anymore. Old location, while divier, also had better food. This place is more updated but we ordered wonton soup, tomato beef chow mein, bbq pork rice noodles, and beef and egg over rice and the soup was bland, chow mein was super salty, noodles were bland, and beef was just ok. Won't be back.
author: Kris F.

description: Food was excellent!  Wish we'd known we could eat upstairs.  Howard greeted us and made us feel right at home...it was heartwarming to see his little nephew calling him Uncle Howard and feeling so at home in what is obviously a family business.  We tried new things we'd never Warren and enjoyed everything we are.
author: Cathy S.

description:
My family and I recently tried Sam Wo Restaurant, and our experience was somewhat mixed. 

The good:
- Our waiter was super nice and jolly. He was very accommodating and kind.
- The vegetarian options we ordered were great, especially the Mapo Tofu and the braised green beans.

The bad:
- Unfortunately the chicken dishes were not of high quality. There were odd jelly-like chunks of chicken in these dishes and very fatty pieces of chicken included. 

The decent:
- The beef dishes ordered were okay. Nothing stellar but nothing amazing either.
author: Dalia Y.

description: The food was okay, the place was nice. Good to eat something passing by in the area. Don't expect too much.
author: Nicolás A.

description: Love this place they honestly have the best noodle rolls with hot mustard sauce!! I came here straight from Fremont just to get lunch!! Best service and very friendly!! Definitely recommend anyone who wants to eat authentic Chinese food!!
author: Trung T.

description: I had a great experience here! Wait staff was really nice and there's one really cute server, Jonathan, who was extremely accommodating to our needs. The food was super yummy (just like Jonathan) and portions were generous. I'd come back without hesitation!
author: Kristina L.

description:
Over rated. 
Quality of food is just average where there are many similar food places close by we tried had better food. I am not sure if the wait persons mind going up and down to mezzanine hundreds of time with the steep steps where a second level of dining room is at. Steamed Chinese broccoli was overly boiled, wonton noodles are so so.
author: Monarch T.

description: My friend and I -poor college students-were starving. And this place was simply amazing!!!!
author: Luz R.

description: Love to their food. I been coming here since their last location. Their pork rolls are the best
author: Armando G.

description: Fantastic Chinese food, the dry duck noodles are a new favorite of mine. And if you decide to get the bbq roll, definitely ask for the mustard.
author: Ricky C.

description: We were a bit disappointed with our visit. There was no wait, and we had prompt service. However, the food just wasn't that flavorful. The pork won ton soup was really bland, we hardly at any of it. The chicken chow mein was much better, but I expected better food in China Town.
author: Liz M.

description: 3.5 out of 5 is what we rate this place. We ordered Chinese donuts, spring rolls, pork chow mein , and Mongolian beef. The only issue we had was the Mongolian beef could of been spicier and less salty. Otherwise it was a good visit. Also FYI, a Chinese donut isn't a sweet donut, it's literally bread... mer
author: Pooja L.

description: Just make sure you order the BBQ Rice Noodle Rolls! They are amazing and full of flavor. They're inexpensive and won't break the bank, so come try some for yourself!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Nauseous and disgusted is what I felt leaving Sam Wo. The food was bland and the noodles were way too over cooked! Char siu was discolored and very disgusting overall. Don't ask any questions or you'll get serious attitude. One of the older ladies rushed us to finish our meals; her policy is sit down, order right away, eat, pay, and get out. The only thing that was a little bit decent was the Hong Kong style milk tea, but even that couldn't cover up the sogginess of the noodles. After 100 years of cooking shouldn't they have learned to cook proper noodles!!!
author: Amy N.

description:
Nostalgic factor 5 stars.
Food is ok here. I ate dry duck noodle and pork rice noodle rolls.
Pork Rice Noodle Rolls fairs better in my book. It has good flavor and the pork is not dry. The hot mustard pairs well with the rolls.

Dry duck noodle: What can I say about this one.... Hmmm OK; I am a self proclaim noodle addict and connoisseur. So I am going to be very tough on this one!
The noodle and taste has a good concept how it should taste, however the execution is lacking. 
First of all, I am expecting the noodle to be a little bit chewier and a little al dente. The sauce ( although taste wise is good, it doesn't have the bite flavor factor for that particular style of noodle )
Second, the chili sauce: A good foundation of noodle shop is chili sauce that works well together with the noodle dish. This store clearly doesn't care to make themselves, and taste like regular sriracha sauce from ranch 99 :(
The duck meat and the small soup is good!

If they fix the noodle to be more fresh, chewier and al dente, with a stronger noodle sauce and proper chili sauce, it can make a deadly combo.
author: Dan A.

description: Food is delicious. The Chow Mein YUM! We ordered it with Black Bean sauce. (Not on the menu, husband ordered it) The service was great! Wish I knew his name, he had long hair in a pony tail. He was very nice and friendly! Definitely coming back when I visit San Francisco!
author: Christina M.

description: It was alright. Below average. Had the congee, beef chow ho fun, and the BBQ pork roll. It was at least authentic (was a bit worried due to the high amount of tourists in the place), just mediocre. Probably won't return, but if I did might give their fried rice or rice plates a chance. Hard pass on their congee and ho fun.
author: Steph A.

description:
There is no better place to complement your visit to Chinatown than the Sam Wo Restaurant. Not only does it offer a variety of staple dishes (with a hint of delectable Sam Wo flavor added), but it is the only restaurant to offer the renowned Barbeque Pork Rice Noodles.Not to mention that the service is unrivaled in the area. 

I would recommend this restaurant to any pleasure seeking tongue.
author: Paul H.

description: It is  a clean place and service is good. The taste is not the same, little bit blank. Portion is large. Overall, it is an average in China Town.
author: kin l.

description:
Excellent food, prices and service. 
The Chinese style iced tea is awesome. The fried rice is like you find in New York. 
It's been around over 100 years which really speaks to the popularity and quality of the food. 
With a thousand Chinese restaurants in the area, it can be difficult to choose. A tour guide years ago told me about this place and I'm so glad he did.
author: Denice B.

description:
- THE FOOD
I was super excited to try Sam Wo after hearing about how it has 100+ years of history and so many positive things. I went with the safe route and ordered a fish jook to go. To start off, it was $10 for a bowl of jook!?! At many other restaurants, you can easily order jook and a side dish or two for $10. The fish was pretty old tasting and seemed like scraps since everything was really shredded. The jook was way too sweet!! Definitely needed more salt and it just didn't feel comforting although it is supposedly comfort food. They also had way too much ginger in there. With every bite, I had a mouthful of ginger strips.
author: Cindy C.

description: Whoa! Open late and not that long of a wait! I came here after midnight hoping the line would shorten but it was still busy! The food was delicious and made fresh to order. The portion of was good for 2 to 3 people to share. The price was inexpensive and the wait for the food definitely was not long. The chicken wings is my favorite-a must try!
author: Paula B.

description:
Great customer service!! Younger girl, never caught her name. She mentioned you usually works the night shift. Her suggestions were all tasty and she checked in on us (party of 6) just enough. My absolute favorite dish was the BBQ pork roll. Delish! Wish I was back in SF to have a couple more. A couple other favorites were the scrambled egg with BBQ pork on top of rice & the Chinese donuts. 
The seating upstairs is very spacious and cute.
author: tanya g.

description: BBQ pork rolls are a must have. House chow mein is also great. Coming from northern New England, this is food that isn't represented up by us all that well. Can't wait to return.
author: Ed D.

description:
"You know you're livin, when it's all a blur"

If you've never had a drunken night in Sam Wo, then you've not been doing San Francisco right. Though, it's in a new location and looks nicer than it did before, they still keep up the tradition of being a late night eatery, but looks like they dropped the mean waiter. I've never been here sober but putting that aside, the food is tasty especially for a late night option, there's something just so satisfying about a pile of chinese food to mop up the booze.

I've been here many times but some of my favorite items have been the bbq pork rice noodle roll, salt and pepper chicken wings, chow mein with duck, shrimp fried rice, and their beef stew.

I'm keeping this review short as so much is already said about Sam Wo, but in my opinion you really can't go wrong here. Good food, items you wont find on other menus, good price, open late, accepts drunks (maybe because we order more when we are), and a staple to not just Chinatown but the San Francisco Experience.
author: Duggan B.

description: Great food! Cold noodle rolls are the best thing ever! Staff is friendly. It's SF Chinatown so the seating is tight.  Always our go-to restaurant'
author: Amanda J.

description: Open late,clean,attentive,food came quick,and was hot got beef chow mein spicy,sweet and sour chicken,BBQ fried rice,and salt and pepper chicken wings,all were very good not to greasy full of flavor,staff  is really nice and I'm lit
author: Fidel A.

description: Pork Noodle rolls is the best!!!! Great Dive type restaurant. Service is ok I would go again. Chow Mein was great. They give large servings for what you pay
author: Timothy G.

description: Very clean restaurant, but food wasn't too authentic. I ordered the BBQ pork wondon noodle soup and house (combo) chow mein. Both dishes had egg noodles. Not too salty, but not too much flavor on the dishes either. Even the broth in the wonton soup was bland. Very friendly wait staff though!
author: Jon P.

description: Came here after reading about this legendary place at the Eat Chinatown Photo Exhibit. Beef stew rice noodle soup had generous portions of tender beef and tendon -- probably the best in terms of flavor and value in the Bay Area. The soup was nice and clear, and I could taste the star anise and dried orange peels used to add depth and flavor. This is the real deal! A must order, imo. The salt and pepper chicken wings were pretty crunchy and cooked just right. Get it as appetizer; the green onions and peppers used to season the chicken wings were excellent. For a nice and cozy date/catch-up with friends, eat upstairs.
author: Linny P.

description: A simple place to get in & out. Prices are reasonable but then portions are small.  There are many many places around with food that is much more authentic and better, and better service. This place has been around for 1 year, not 100 years as advertised
author: Joey S.

description: The place was packed for lunch on a Sunday, yet the service was pretty good - except one of our 4 orders was the wrong item...ordered a Singapore chow-fun and got a duck something-or-other.  Maybe this was just a language problem between our Czech-speaking guest and the staff.  The other items were all OK: 2 chicken chow-fun plates and 1 chicken chow-mein.  The chow-fun was pretty good and I'd order it again...but I wasn't blown away, and it just can't compare to my "favorite" dishes and places.  With the high rankings I was somehow expecting more.  I was border-line rating "meh" and "A-OK" so gave the benefit of the doubt.
author: Mark S.

description: Friendly waiters. Quite a lot fish in fish jook, and complimentary parsley is provided. Chinese broccoli is fresh, too.
author: Yikai L.

description:
2 stars for the services.

Foods are not suitable for traditional Chinese people. Foods in this restaurant are basically made in new American way.

Not recommend for traditional Chinese people.
author: Karen W.

description: my first time in san francisco, i really wanted to try good authentic Chinese food instead of the whitewashed food i usually eat. this place delivered. i went for plain wonton soup because i was scared but GOOD GOD it was delicious. the service, while slightly rushed was very helpful and nice. 10/10.
author: Madison M.

description: Ugh! On vacation and wanted Cantonese food from Chinatown. Checked Yelp and went to Sam Wo based on reviews. Sorry.. not to my liking. The place was dirty and my dinner was full of gristle, way too many onions and zero flavor. We were seated upstairs and it was alarming to me that if there was an emergency there was no way out.
author: Lisa T.

description: Words cannot truly express how horrid the meal was...Mongolian Beef, how can you mess it up? Hmm make a cornstarch based sauce, add bell peppers and carrots and too much sugar... Don't add any green onion, or flash fried dry rice noodles, not nearly the right ratio of yellow onion or garlic. It was a hot mess and it sent it right back. My daughter's combination wonton soup came out first and she was practically done before I get t my meal... There was no order to when things came out, several people were waiting...and waiting...I should have followed my instincts and walked out. I ate a cold soggy appetizer that was supposed to be the house specialty... Guess what, the Mongolian beef was listed as the house specialty too...
author: Kim T.

description:
So I have eaten here for 4 nights in a row, you figure, yes I am in the neighborhood. This is a clean and friendly staff, most of the nights the line is trailing out of the restaurant. It is a good clean Chinese restaurant.

Tried - pork and aged egg jook -really good.Jook is one of my favorite nourishing dishes and they got it right.

Rice noodles are really good. Had their special beef and rice noodle soup, ate to the last drop :).

Had a regular spring beans, rice noodles with chicken, shrimp fried rice and broccoli with chicken, pretty good and all my friends and family liked it. All for 44$ for 4 people with taxes. 

If you are in the area, do visit. Have fun, let me know how you like this place.

Forgot, the waiter gave me a free root beer on the third day seeing me, love this place :), great service for a Chinese place.
author: Shivaji D.

description: great prices, great food, huge portion! Going back next time i'm in town. Def get the house fried rice and beef chow fun.
author: Shay S.

description:
House Chow Mein - good
House Fried Rice - good
Chicken and String beans - good
author: NY Y.

description:
This place is super nostalgic as I remember coming here at its old location. 
My boyfriend and j were seated right away as we came when it opened for dinner. Service was quick and friendly. Wish the chairs had a back to it..found myself slouching which is not good for the back, especially if seniors come eat here. 
Food was quick to come out of the kitchen. 
I had to try the bbq rice noodle roll as I remember it was something I loved many years ago here. However, I was disappointed at this one because it was pretty dry and didn't have much flavor. I've had better elsewhere. It came with a side of horseradish dip which was unexpected and interesting.
The rest of the food was delicious! Ordered the tomato beef chow mein- super flavorful but a tad too sweet for my taste. I think I would go for a chow fun (flat rice noodle dish next time)
The sweet and sour pork were finger licking good! It had a good crisp, meat was tender, and sauce was addicting. 
The string beans and chicken was also a hit..would definitely get that again next time. 
I was one happy customer. :)
author: Anna L.

description: We had never been here before so we thought we would try it out. We ordered our food, didn't really have prices. I ordered a 6piece pot stickers and some Chicken chowmein... total came out to $22!!! We waited 30 minutes for takeout and my cousins meal was drpping sauce inside the bag!! Very messy!! They didn't enjoy the flavors of the food at all. Very bland. My noodles tasted too much like vegetables and were very thin and dry.  My chicken had no flavor either. Left me not wanting to give new places a try :(:(:(
author: Dalia M.

description: I called at 7:33 to place a take out order. They said 15 mins. I arrived at 8:21 to pick it up. They were disorganized and said it was currently processing, which didn't make sense given the 15 minute estimate. At 8:30 they almost gave me someone else's order. When I asked what happened to mine they said they probably just forgot to enter it into the system. I had to catch the bus to make it back home so I walked out empty handed and with time wasted. Would not recommend for take-out.
author: Erin P.

description: First time to Chinatown and I relied on Yelp (4 stars). Honestly, it was not good! Ordered house chow fun, Mongolian beef, and sesame chicken.  There was NO chicken in the fried chicken, called Sesame Chicken. Chow fun had a little bok choy. We wanted to like it!
author: Rachel S.

description: The service is friendly and the new location is clean. I like the upstairs. The food is just as I expected. Chinese greasy spoon fare. Get your noodle fix here.
author: Cynthia G.

description: This place has two floors. The waiter was very friendly. I ordered the pork and preserved egg jook. The jook was hot, however, there was barely any pork. The Chinese donuts were the most disappointing part. They were stale and thus not crispy at all.
author: James S.

description: Supposed to be featured on Conan o'Brien. But tbh, food taste is just average. Theres better chinese noodle and congee houses.
author: Baillie Z.

description: Awesome food!  Glad I followed the advice of a friend and checked this place out.  I will definitely go back next time I'm in SF!
author: Liz R.

description: as a tourist to the biggest chinatown in the United States, it was hard for me to pick out genuine good quality food over the tourist favorites. based off of at least 5 recommendations whenever we talked to people around the city, we chose Sam Wo for dinner and sadly, it was mediocre at best. to be completely fair, a lot of people in the reviews on yelp (made the mistake of reading reviews AFTER eating there) were saying that the old Sam Wo before it closed down and re-opened was better & cheaper. what we experienced a few weeks ago was bland in flavor and texture. both my friend and i started with the bbq pork wonton noodle soup which honestly just tasted like salty water. the same dish at my favorite Chinese restaurant in Austin, TX is 10X better. i was so disappointed in that, i went ahead and ordered the beef chow fun to go. that was better, a little more flavor but not by much. i added so much sauce and flavor on my own to get it to taste somewhat special. in all, i refuse to believe this is the best chinatown has to offer. maybe we ordered the wrong thing? maybe it's supposed to taste like that and all of the food i've had growing up isn't authentic flavors? i'm not sure, but either way it was disappointing.
author: Lilly S.

description:
We had the chicken chow fun with vegetables it was good. Also had the egg and bbq pork. 

Good service. Price was reasonable and servings large. Clean too. 

Try the pork rolls. They look good.
author: Michael V.

description: We have been here 2x this week and service has been impeccable second time around! Howard , Our server Is soo professional, always checks in on our needs & he does it with a smile. We had the fried chicken, egg with shrimp over rice & beef chow mien! A great place to eat in the heart of Chinatown on clay st. They are open for late night dinning. The restaurant is clean. Parking garage is just across the street which I highly recommend as trying to find parking in the area is a challenge.  We will definitely be back soon!
author: Ruth M.

description: I would definitely coming back for more!!! The stewed beef rice and the chicken wings and the combination wanton!!! Alll just deliciously good!!!
author: Jocelin L.

description: Woahhhh. Came here again. Got the bbq rice roll and this time said yes please, to getting a small container of hot mustard. Even if you don't like hot mustard (I don't really), try THEIR hot mustard. It is amazing.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Terrible food,  guessing they got their friends to write the reviews. I would give it zero stars if possible. 

Chicken and broccoli was just broccoli and was bland and just boring. The sesame chicken as just nasty and was thrown away as soon as we all tried it. The spring rolls were greasy and tasteless and rounded off some of the worse Chinese food I've ever had.
author: Mike K.

description: 番茄牛肉炒面 Tomato Beef Chow Mein。was a bit watery and portion was smaller than most places.
author: Will L.

description: Excellent food. My husband and i split the wonton soup, duck noodle dish and fun dun dish. We were full. Good size dishes.
author: Mary C.

description: Came into a packed house on a Friday night with my husband and two friends. We didn't have to wait long for a table even though the place is really small offering maybe ten tables total. We all shared the BBQ pork rice noodle roll, chow mein with duck, chicken with string beans and Chinese doughnuts. Everything tasted great and they serve tea as you sit down to have your meal. It was enough food to feed four of us with each of us getting a bowl of rice. My only wish was the doughnuts were fresh but we came later in the evening so no worries as they still tasted great. I think this place is a great spot for authentic Chinese food without being too foreign or crazy with the menu. Wouldn't recommend for large groups.
author: Heather F.

description:
It was okay
Won ton.  Yum
Service.  Awesome
Remodeled.  Yes
Chow fun.  More yum
Tea.  Hot
A must to visit
author: Liane J.

description: Friendly and helpful waitress. Good prices. I had the dry chicken noodle bowl. Never had this anywhere before, very flavorful and two servings worth for me. There aren't extra veggies, mostly noodles, chicken, lettuce, gland green onion, but tastes great. Newly renovated as well.
author: Sadie G.

description: Was a regular at the old location and this was my first visit since the reopen. The rice noodle rolls are still amazing, chow fun excellent, won tons melt in your mouth delicious. The only differences are the place is clean, birds are no longer flying around the kitchen and the servers are young and polite. It took some getting used to but the food made me feel right at home!
author: les e.

description:
Did you know it's impossible to find BBQ pork rice noodle rolls anywhere else? I am so glad Sam Wo reopened!! Yes, the prices went way up, but at least the location is clean (for now) and again, nowhere else sells BBQ pork rice noodle rolls! 

BBQ pork rice rolls - $4.95 - 4/5 - I can eat several of these things! Make sure you ask for the homemade mustard - it's much more horseradishy than those packets that most people are used to. One roll has about 8 pieces. 

Duck Dry Mixed Noodle - $6.59 - 3.5/5 - These were much more flavorful than I expected and the noodles were homemade. I just didn't really care about the duck. I was expecting roasted duck but it was shredded pieces and lacked some flavor. Next time I think I would be much happier with BBQ pork. 

Tomato Beef Chow Fun - 3/5 - This wasn't on the menu, but I asked if they would make it since they make the same dish with chow mein. It was very saucy, but a little too much on the sweet side. I liked how it had a lot of tomato flavor though. 

The location is pretty nice for Chinatown but the upstairs can get stuffy if too many people are up there. I am rounding up because if anything, I will be coming back to get the BBQ pork rice noodle rolls and mustard sauce! 

Tip: They are closed between 4-6pm on the days that they are open.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
Our favorite restaurant happened to be closed the day we took 20 kids to San Francisco

 I looked them up on Yelp and the read the reviews I picked up the phone and call them and I said there's 20 of us can you seat us and they said not right now but if you give us half an hour we will get take care of you. 

When we got there we only had to wait a few minutes and then give us the entire upstairs 

Many of the kids have never had Chinese food in Chinatown before and so we ordered a series of appetizers; barbecue pork rice noodles, rolls... we ordered some stir fry rice we ordered a few of the entries the kung pao chicken the chicken with broccoli the sesame chicken the sweet and sour pork and a couple other rice plates the food came out and it was really really good the kids ate it all up and everybody left very full and very satisfied 

The service was friendly it was fast and I was surprised how quickly they could accommodate us for such a large party I would definitely come here again in a pinch thanks again for the great service and the price very reasonable.
author: Nick P.

description:
Some of the friendliest service I've ever experienced. I can't properly explain how nice the staff were at this place, but I rarely find this genuine kindness elsewhere.

They'll make a Mongolian Shrimp dish if you ask and that was one of my favorite things we ordered. The food was delicious and we were eating until the last drop. 

Ambiance was cute though I wish they weren't so busy that Friday night so we could sit upstairs instead. Oh well, that means I'll just have to go again! :)
author: Husna H.

description:
The first problem was a Chinese Restaurant in Chinatown and the waitress does not speak Chinese. Asked for Beef Chow Fun and she brought Shrimp Chow Fun. Said we ordered Beef Chow Fun, so she brought it back. Few minutes later she brought over another plate and said Beef Chow Fun and placed it on the table. I looked at it and said this is not beef, my wife said it was duck but it was just duck skin and fat. Told the waitress and she said she'll bring it back. We decided to try it and get out. Food portion was small but that's ok because it did not taste good. 

Can't not understand how someone can serve a dish by name and not even look at it to see that it was wrong. Sorry, I had good memories of Sam Wo but that restaurant is clearly gone. BTW, the waitress never said sorry.
author: Laurence C.

description: Excellent Chinese fast food in Chinatown!!! FAMOUS BBQ Pork Rice Noddle Roll or Gwuen Fun!
author: Carlos S.

description:
Literally everything's great on the menu. Even though the dishes on the menu is like almost every other place in Chinatown, the food here is super fresh, flavorful and not oily. You finish eating and don't feel too guilty. 

Make sure you get the BBQ rice rolls. The roll itself is chewy and the pork is fragrant.
author: Jenny J.

description: Food was great! A bit of a wait at 2 am but it was worth it! The food was so good. We tried 5 or 6 dishes including broccoli beef, duck fried rice, and Mongolian chicken and everything was delicious!
author: James P.

description: I dont know how this place got four star on yelp. Their food was bland. I ordered the jook and needed to add soy sauce, which is a big no no. The chinese donut was cold and not fresh. Avoid this place if you can.
author: Hung L.

description:
2 1/2 star!  (NOTE: I'm posting 3 stars instead of 2, because I'd like to give them the benefit of the doubt!) This seems to be an authentic Cantonese style restaurant.
 
I was in a training class and a classmate suggested we go here, as Chinatown was only a block away, we walked of course. She raved about this place, and heard that it had re-opened, and she was VERY excited, so I said sure! When we first walked in I wasn't sure if it was a sit-down restaurant or take-out only.. But they immediately invited us in to sit. It's a small narrow restaurant and didn't look as clean as I would have liked. They took us to the second floor, up steep and crackly wooden steps and my immediate thought was, oh no, where did this girl bring me. (I was worried!) The second floor was actually pleasant, looked cleaner and newly renovated/decorated than the first floor, so I was a bit relieved. Smaller, but much brighter than the first floor. There was a hostess/waiter and water station there as well, which for me, for some reason was comforting to see. 
The table had small stools as chairs, I have never seen that before, it wasn't as uncomfortable as I thought. I would have liked to hang my purse on the back of a chair, instead of the floor, but I had no choice.  (Floor it is!) :/ 
We ordered an appetizer, the BBQ pork rice roll, it looked like a sushi roll, it came with a spicy mustard, which tasted similar to wasabi. I wasn't in love with the dish, but my friend insisted on it being the BEST thing in the menu and we had to order it. Meh.. Not a fan! It didn't taste like much, it wasn't bad at all, but it was kinda bland if you ask me.. my friend loved it. I did however see others eating it as well, so it definitely seems to be a favorite amongst guests. My friend ordered the beef chowfun and I ordered chicken with green beans, it came with white rice. (They didn't offer me brown rice, not sure if it was even an option). :( It was lightly sautéed with a black bean sauce, I thought the chicken (a generous amount) was mostly the fatty pieces of the chicken with cartilage still on it.. I really had a hard time chewing and I kept spitting out the hard to chew chunks, I know, kinda gross! The flavors were nice, though. 
Prices were great, we walked out paying $23 for the 2 of us, not too shabby and service was good too, they were very nice and responsive, it did take about 15 to receive our food! 
Honestly, my friend ranted about this place, but I really wasn't impressed. It's in a congested area, not so sure how easy parking would be, there is a garage nearby, however. 

Although, I didn't mind it, but I really wasn't a fan of the food. Keep in mind, my expectations were set high as my friend really amped up the place. 
Sorry, but I won't be back!
author: Anie L.

description: i clearly just didnt order the right things... the salt n pepper wings, though hot n fresh, were lacking in flavor - very canto i guess. the duck chow fun had a super weird flavor because i presume the duck slices werent very fresh.. bleh! and it was just covered in soy sauce but no depth of flavor either. blehhh.
author: Christina L.

description:
i really wanted to like this place because i had fond memories of eating here in my early twenties at the old space. it could be that the food is not as good, or more likely that my palate is more discriminating now. ;)

i found everything to be too greasy, so that i could barely finish it.  the chow fun had way too much bean sprouts.  the rolls were good, but cold ( i prefer them warm).

service is great, the guy upstairs is super nice and the space is bright and clean.  i probably won't come back for the food though, esp with R&G Lounge is right next door for a bit more $!
author: Josie M.

description: Sam Wo is a solid place to satisfy all your carby Chinese cravings. We ordered BBQ pork rice rolls, the duck noodles, and stewed beef soup noodles. Their stewed beef was tender, authentic-tasting, and flavorful, and reminded me a lot of stewed beef in Guangzhou/Canton. The rice rolls were slightly different from usual fare you'd see at dimsum places, but had a good balance of meat and rice noodle. The duck noodles looked pretty average but ended up being our favorite dish of the three. The noodles had a great, springy texture and a perfect amount of seasoning. It was easy to get every component of the dish in each bite since the duck was shredded into small pieces. Service was courteous and very friendly. Will definitely be back!
author: Tina X.

description:
Great food! I strongly recommend this place. 
The food is great and the prices are even better. We ate at "house of Nanking" which is supposed to be one of "the places" to eat at in China town and it didn't even come close to "Sam Wo". Don't waste your time looking another place. FYI, service could have been a little better 3 1/2 stars but the food makes up for it.
author: Hector D.

description: The high reviews for this place were very misleading. It was less than mediocre. I was super bummed about this bc we were in the mood for good Chinese food, but I should've known as soon as I saw the entree list full of Chinese American dishes and nothing authentic, that this was a bad idea. The Chinese donuts came not exactly cold, but unless fried dough is hot, it's crap. It was stale and you could smell the old grease. The only ok dishes were the Pork and Preserved Egg Congee and the chicken wings (nothing special but the only item that wasn't cold when it came out). The rest of our order wasn't even room temperature when it arrived and got increasingly colder as soon as it hit the table. Why go to a restaurant if the food isn't hot!?! I was excited to try the wet egg and shrimp over rice dish I saw pictures of on Yelp...it came out with cold rice and dry egg. I even showed the waiter the picture before ordering and that dry, cold mess was the atrocity we received. What I don't get is how there was a line of people when the food was so below average?!? It's Bc Yelpers do the disservice of lying to other diners. Don't make excuses for this place anymore with a rating above 2 stars. It was an $80 tab and I'm kicking myself for wasting that kind of money; it wasn't worth even $20. Save yourself the time, bc the history of this place doesn't matter if the food is bad. And btw, does it even count as historical when it's at a new location with no old world charm?  It's just another whatever Chinese spot with cheesy ambiance and sticky tables. If the food was great, anything goes, but it's just not.
author: Dagney T.

description: Good place to eat reasonable prices. The jook is tasty and the wonton are huge and meaty. The Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings are delicious, fresh & crispy. It's just like the  original one on Washington Street. This place gets very busy! When you're in S.F. Chinatown, don't know where to eat. This is the place to go "Sam Wo Restaurant" 713 Clay Street (Between Grant Ave. & Kearny St.) San Francisco, CA 94108
author: Edmund L.

description: Good Cantonese/Hong Kong style food served quickly and efficiently.  The staff is very nice and quick to refill water and tea.  Great comfort food and very reasonable prices.  The Jook or Porridge with Pork and Preserved Egg really filled me up, and went well with the BBQ Pork stuffed rice noodle.
author: David C.

description:
Just had a chance to eat here! (I'm visiting Phoenix) and had a chance to try the duck dry mixed noodle.... . . 


IT WAS FUCKING FANTASTIC!!!!!! 

It was a great price ($6.95) and phenomenal taste. I would 100% suggest this to my entire network. 

I had a chance to meet the staff (Julie & Howard) all of them were extremely sweet hard working people. 

If you're in the area, like modern interior design, good food & good people then eat here.
author: Jared L.

description: I ate here last night.  Had the wonton combination soup.  I got serious food born illness from this place.  I've been vomiting and having serious diarrhea all morning.  Seriously ruined my day.  Not sure what it would've been that did it.  Won't be coming back here.
author: Tyler R.

description:
The salt & pepper chicken wings are incredible! Ordered them to-go, but wish we could've tried more of their menu. 
Only downside is their hours. Every time we wanted to go back and dine-in, they were closed!
author: Grace D.

description: Excellent food... you must try Sam Wo's when you are in San Francisco!! So yummy!!
author: DaVina L.

description: Delicious and affordable food in Chinatown.  The only complaint is that they did not bring the fried rice or chow mein until AFTER all of our other food was served and eaten. We would have preferred to eat these as side dishes WITH our other dishes.  Also, we had to ask for serving spoons. All of the food was delicious and the workers were friendly.  We sat upstairs.  We would return based on the quality and taste of the food as well as the affordable prices.
author: Nicole D.

description: I ordered scramble egg with shrimp on white rice. It literally fried egg and shrimp that without any taste except egg and shrimp. It's like the cook even forgot to put salt in it. My friends ordered wanton soup and beef noodle and they said they only tasted water. Our savior that night was soy sauce and chilli on the table. All 7 of us were puzzling what the hype of this place. We have tasted better chinese food than this. The only good thing is that their service are fast and clean place.
author: Munirah M.

description:
I'll go ahead and admit this review is written with a heavy bias. I grew up frequenting the original Sam Wos, also known to us as "the rude waiter restaurant". My father, a loveable and curmudgeonly fellow, found the Rude Waiter endlessly entertaining, a hilarious alter ego if you will. 

I think it must have been fate when my friend and I wandered through the door this weekend, only to discover that this was the reincarnation of the Sam Wo's of my childhood. It's a Formica table, comfort food kind of place. But the quality of the food we had didn't disappoint. And I'm quite the critic when it comes to Chinese dives. 

We only had Peking duck chow fun and string beans, but they were the best chow fun and string beans I'd had in a very, very long time. The duck portions were stingy and not top quality cuts, but the flavor was fantastic. I wouldn't expect more for the price we paid, some eight bucks for a huge platter the two of us couldn't even finish. That is the point of a dive after all. Flavor over expense. True wok hay. Five stars for the new Sam Wos. 

There is no rude waiter of course. The wait staff is in fact wonderfully friendly and helpful. They joked around with us and treated us like old friends. If I lived in the city I would be eating here weekly.
author: Lisa B.

description:
So I had high hopes for this place. Sam Wo's recently reopened and i have been looking for a Chinese restaurant that is open late. Well, there was line before they were even open (this is expected for San Francisco). But the wait for a table wasn't long, we waited a while to order and waited for over 15 before anyone noticed we were done eating. We had our plates stacked hoping they would get the message but they ignored us. 

The reason i am giving Sam Wo's 1 star is because I am taking a star off for every hair that i found in the food. I thought it was my hair at first but no, there was another one buried in the noodles. The third one was the last straw, and the waiter saw me pulling the long hair out of the food and just made a grossed out face and ignored us after that. 

Lastly, I they lose another star because the wonton soup was so bland. It was just wontons and soupy water. The wonton's tasted extremely which sometimes may be a sign that it is not fresh. I ate one and stopped because i was worried i would get sick. I am really not a picky eater but this place really put a bad taste in my mouth (literally).
author: Vicky H.

description:
Amazing reconstruction of the past location! We loved the rice noodle roll- just as tasty as before.
The raw fish salad approximates the original but lacks key ingredient - toasted sesame seeds- and did not quite match our memory. Definitely coming back to try more dishes- lots of choices and open until 4 am on weekends.
author: Helen M.

description: Worthy of the hype. Delicious food, nothing fancy and that is the beauty. The service was great. I had the BBQ pork roll, very tasty with a rather generous portion. The Duck Chow fun had lots of duck, tasty noodles and crunchy veggies. A big plate too. Wish I was with others so I could have tried more dishes. I will go back!
author: Rich S.

description:
Short version:
Panda Express has better tasting food than this and I don't even like Panda Express

Long Version:
I'm in town for a day and have been eating oysters and seafood all day. So I was feeling hungry and the only place open at 11pm near my hotel is this place. It has decent rating so I gave it a try. Got jook(every chinese restaurant that I've ever been to call it congee) and braised beef noodle soup. These two item are what I call safe dishes. Usually pretty decent whether you're in LA, NY, Boston, Vancouver, Hong Kong or even Taiwan. Hell, you can even get this in Saigon (yes, there is a china town in Saigon). This was absolutely terrible. It had no flavor. I tried adding some soy sauce and chile but that didn't help either. So I paid and left feeling hungry. Good thing it was cheap. But just because it's cheap doesn't mean it doesn't have to taste good. I ended up ordering room service which I should have done in the first place.

It's hard to believe that this place has so many good reviews.
author: Trung T.

description: The food taste like hot trash. The  service is crappy. I would give it a 1 star. But Decided to give it a four star because it has been in business for over a hundred years., which is pretty impressive. Will not come back anytime soon unless desperate for hot trash and crappy service.
author: James K.

description:
Awesome restaurant for late night grub. When you find yourself in the Financial District, it's difficult as it is to find a good place to eat late at night, even on a Friday. 

Enter Sam Wo and its century old legacy. I guarantee you, this spot is worth your time and money. Try the chicken fried rice -- it's delicious, cheap and served at a good time. 

One of my favorite spots when visiting San Francisco. Highly recommend it. Will definitely come back next time.
author: Yaniv K.

description:
Came right before closing after a holiday party. Service was quick, and food was tasty.

I had wonton soup with beef stew and the BBQ pork roll app. The BBQ pork roll is definitely worth getting, especially dipped in their house made mustard sauce. It pinches your nose like wasabi, so beware!

We asked for mostly tendon bits in the soup, and the kitchen totally hooked it up for us! Great broth, great beef, and decent wontons (although they were a little soggy). Not bad for late night Chinatown!
author: Jessica C.

description: THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!! Best Chinese food I ever had and I have had a LOT of Chinese food. MUST have bbq pork rice rolls!! they were AMAZING!!!! highly recommended them. They were flavorful and slightly chewy. I can't say enough to express my love for them lol. We also had the Singapore noodles. These were really tasty. Curry dry flavor. But what blow my mind, besides the rolls, was the sweet and sour pork. Normally I do not order this because the sauce is overpowering but Sam Wo's one are to die for. The sauce was what you would imagine, sweet and sour but the pork was crunchy and that change everything. I was so full after but as soon the meal was over I started missing it again. I wanted to go back and starting considering my move to San Fran. Lol jk but seriously
author: Ryna O.

description:
Sam Wo is a fantastic Chinese restaurant near the Financial District! I had a few things on their menu and every time, I have never been disappointed! Not only is the food delicious but the quantity is large as well! This place is clean, service is efficient, and it's DELICIOUS!  

Make sure to come a little earlier to reserve a table. This place can get pretty crowded during lunch time.
author: John L.

description:
I'm very impressed with Sam Wo restaurant. Not only is it cheap and affordable, but it's also realllly tasty!! The atmosphere is friendly and clean. We were greeted by the staff when we walked in too. We went to the upstairs dining area. You can tell this place has been renovated nicely. It is extremely clean too. They give you complimentary tea when you sit down. 

We ordered the vegetables noodles and the BBQ pork rice rolls. The food came out in a reasonable amount of time and looked fresh and healthy. The portions here are also huge!!! So you really get a good amount of food for a very good price. The BBQ pork rice rolls were really tasty and I enjoyed them. However, I didn't expect them to be cold. I know this is the way they are supposed to be served, but I think they would taste better if they were room temp. or warm... The vegetable noodles were fresh and flavorful. They were extremely good and I recommend.

I would definitely come back here!!! I'm so glad I tried Sam Wo! Friendly, clean, efficient, cheap, tasty, and fresh.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description:
Cheap and basic Chinese food.  Service was friendly and efficient (sorry, no new rude waiters).
Plain decor but a few photos and articles of the late, great Edsel Ford Wong at the old location.  Very generous portions. They have some upstairs seating.
author: Osama B.

description: If your in the are it's a must stop. Clean atmosphere, fresh and great tasting. No wonder it's been a landmark for over 100 years.
author: A G.

description: I used to absolutely LOVE the original Sam Wo's and I finally made it back out to SF for my first visit to the new location hoping the food was still the exact same. The new venue is very pleasant and clean and they have a nice ambiance. The food of course I was definitely going to have several BBQ pork rice noodle rolls and they were excellent as always, along with the won ton soup, these wontons are the best around.  Now one thing I was super disappointed about was the other entree I always used to order ~ the sweet and sour pork over chow mein. These chow mein noodle are NOT the same at all. These new noodles are just like every other place when before the noodles where more soft and slimmer and tasted so much better. PLEASE bring back to old style noodles. Other than that I will be going back asap for more wontons and rolls!
author: Joel M.

description: We were immediatley seated upstairs which was awesome!  It was the perfect little spot with the perfect portion! Shared the beef and string beans (perfectly blanched & stir fried) and the chicken chow mein.  It was amazing! Service was on point and Howard was a complete professional.  Will definitely return to Sam Wo's and recommend to friends!
author: Odette D.

description:
So glad Sam Wo is back!!! My parents would always buy their BBQ pork ice rolls and being able to have those again was great. The BBQ pork rice rolls still taste the same (great!) and go really well with the hot mustard. 

I am hoping to come back sometime soon to try out the other options on the menu now that they are open again.
author: Breniel L.

description:
Had the plain won ton soup and it was amazing.  I also got a rice platter that scrambled egg, bbq pork and seam rice. 

Service was really slow but the Chinese new year parade was going on so made them popular and considering the holiday,  it was still great!
author: Jesslyn H.

description:
Have to admit, I never knew about the old Sam Wo's. When I saw Instagram pics of the BBQ Pork Rice Rolls, I had to make a visit yesterday. Verdict? Incredible!

Ever since our team relocated to Kearny near Chinatown, I've tossed my 4hb diet to the gutter and taken lunchtime advantage of all the wonderful places this location has to offer. Sam Wo's is by far my new favorite here.

Couple of tips: BBQ Pork Rice Noodles are wonderful any time of the day, but they are irresistible when fresh! The hot mustard sauce--it is that hot and that good!
author: Amelia C.

description: Amazing Ma Po Dofu. Definitely something most people would not order, but if you want something authentic then order this.
author: Clayton P.

description: Excited for new location.. I remember the old Sam wo.. Huge fan.. Was there on the last days.. Stood in line for over 2 hours to eat once more.
author: Frances L.

description:
It's odd, since they moved locations they also seem to have a "fresh" Yelp account.  I was a "regular" at the old location on Yelp.

Cleaner, faster, safer, better lit, better bathroom, not so much of a fire trap.  Will it have the (charm?) of the old location?  Time will tell.
author: Richard C.

description: The BBQ pork rolls always hits the spot. The price raised to 4.95 now. The scramble egg (wet) with beef over rice is also good. Haven't seen any rude waitress around yet.
author: Brian W.

description:
Curry BBQ Pork Noodle Soup:  The "curry" was just a squirt of ketchup with some curry powder thrown on the side.  WTF?  Very little meat and barely any broth as well; the only flavor was the "curry sauce" and quite frankly it was pretty disgusting.

This place is terrible and I am absolutely convinced that the 5 star reviews are written by people with a strong sense of nostalgia for the original restaurant and haven't tried their new location.  Who are these people trying to fool?

Easily the worst restaurant in Chinatown right now, eat anywhere else.
author: D D.

description: Fried rice w/ sesame, chicken chicken chow mein and chicken broccoli w/ fried rice  spicy. Super amazing, we found this place on Yelp, the reviews were correct, this food is amazing. Definitely a hidden gem in the city.
author: George S.

description: This was a nice family owned and operated restaurant located in Chinatown.  A large portion of their menu focuses on different types of chow mein.  They had  nice spicy mustard (a lot of heat) that went with it.
author: Shawn D.

description: Amazing food! We had a large group of 12 and they were able to accommodate us quickly. Fast friendly service!!
author: Colleen I.

description: Great food at the late night hours. Did my group very well for the time of night. Wonton soup was delicious, as well as the combo chow mein and tea. Yeah, the tea makes a bit of difference. Sometimes places has tea that sucks, but not this spot!
author: Chris C.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I have never eaten here and that I had reservations about this place only because it's been pegged as a tourist joint. We had a lion dance performance last night in Chinatown and we decided to come here after for dinner. Having never been to the old location, I had even bigger reservations to find a place that was brightly lit, newly painted, clean, and orderly. 

If you've lived here long enough and been to enough hole in the walls in Chinatown, you would realize that this is not your typical fare. Great, we're probably going to get ripped off for watered down chinese food. Imagine to my surprise when I sat down and saw that the prices were completely within line for what you would normally pay at similar places. The food itself is pretty decent. It's cantonese style, portions are ok, but what really really impressed me was their service. For a place that busy and that small, they have the friendliest waiters I have ever met in a very long time. While most waiters will treat you fairly when you go to a restaurant, they often forget that they're being observed as well when they are not at your table. How they greet other guests, how they communicate with each other, people are watching all the time. 

You can tell how much a waiter enjoys their job when they come to take your order. They'll either stand there impatiently while you flip flop through your decisions or help you decide in a friendly manner. Or when they bring out a dish and forget a side condiment. All that makes a difference. I would definitely come back just for the experience alone. Drop by for lunch here sometime, you won't regret it.
author: Eric L.

description:
Sam Wo is just brilliant, it's super inexpensive and so delicious! I've visited numerous times and loved it each time. Their chow mein is great, their fried rice is great, everything is great!

I'll always go for their bbq pork rice noodle rolls, they're absolutely fantastic. They are light and very tasty, I'd implore you to give them a go!
author: Johnathan L.

description: The old one was bad.... this one is better than the last, but not worth coming to.. maybe if you are from out of town... or really drunk
author: John F.

description: This has to be one of the best Chinese restaurants I've ever eaten at in my life. At first I was little freaked out because the area is very sketchy, and there was a line out the door. You have to sign up on the clipboard that's inside and make your way through the line. I saw there's only about 10 tables inside. Their egg rolls were great, sweet-and-sour pork was amazing, and their seafood soup was ridiculously good. The service was on point. And the price point was great for what they give you. It was much bigger portions than what I thought it would be. Each entrée is definitely shareable. If I ever go to San Francisco go again... I will definitely be back!
author: Keilaine R.

description:
Food was average. Service was nice, except our tea was lukewarm. 

Some questionable design/item placement choices:
1. The chopsticks in the holder touch the wall...not feeling that
2. The coat hooks are so low that my jacket covered the utensil holder

I'd come back in a little bit and see if things have improved. It would be nice if they did.
author: Jeffry C.

description: If you haven't had the raw fish salad ($20) here, you haven't had one of the most unique dishes in the western US. The menu offers plenty of more standard Chinese items like chow funs and rice dishes and soups, I had the shrimp chow fun and its plentiful bean sprouts and yummy sauce made the fresh nonsticky noodles taste amazing. I can't recommend a place more in SF.
author: John L.

description: I used to go to their old location for a very long time and was really bummed when they closed. A few years later, I learned that they were going to reopen in a new location, I was a bit scared that the food would not be as good. The first time I went to their new place, I was so happy to see that their food was just as yummy. I always get the BBQ pork wonton soup, it's my go to. The service is definitely a lot nicer than the previous location which is cool but I really go for the food. I am once again a frequent flyer here, I love Sam Wo's!
author: Michi R.

description: Cant wait to go back . Its bin years that they closed. Hope the ladies are still thier and the bbq noodle role , dam its
author: Jaime R.

description:
Thank you yelp for a great recommendation, came here for a late night snack.

Really good pork and preserved duck egg jook and fried dough.  The curry beef stew was nice though I like it a little more seasoned, but it's nothing a little chili pepper sauce can't improve on!

What's great is the service here is awesome.  They are really really friendly and helpful, not something you usually associate with a hole in the wall type of joint.

Definitely recommend!
author: Yi S.

description:
Me and my wife tried 2 different entrees. Both was not tasty and we didn't eat it. 
Find another place.
author: Ran M.

description: Came here per a friends recommendation who grew up in Chinatown and Yelp reviews weren't too shabby either. We got the kung pao and fried rice. I felt like the kung pao was the worst I've ever had! Was so shocked this was the product of a 100 year establishment in Chinatown! The chicken was smelly, food was watered down, and generally tasteless.  The egg rolls were ok but too oily. Not coming back!
author: Priya C.

description:
Came here at 11:30am and my friend and I got a table at noon.  Do be aware you have to put your name on the list inside the restaurant in order to get a table.  Since they just open for only 2 weeks, a lot of items are missing from their menu.  Service was quick as their wait staff knows they need to turn over a table rather quickly.  The food was just so so.  Their cash register was out of order, so cash only for now.

There are only 21 seats, so the wait will be long.
author: Angela T.

description: Took my mom and sister here for lunch while we were in Chinatown for the day. It was delicious! We had the BBQ Pork Noodle Roll, Donut, Chicken and Broccoli over Jasmine rice, House Fried Rice, House Chow Fun, and Spring Rolls. It was a lot of food! We are white San Jose natives, which I think is important to mention because tastes between cultures may vary for different palates.  They also had cold cans of diet coke, clean bathrooms and a friendly clean atmosphere. Will be bringing my touristy friends here and will be coming back myself! Thank you for a wonderful experience!
author: Annie T.

description: Found this restaurant in Chinatown based on Yelp reviews on our visit to SF. No qualms about the food, delicious and authentic. We ordered the beef noodles and you can taste the cured wok aroma. The wontons in the soup were big and meaty and the "pei tan jook" was comfort food for the Chinese soul!
author: ANGELA O.

description:
We were in San Francisco on June 29th with my son and his family.  I ask them if they wanted seafood or Chinese food.  Our grandkids voted for Chinese.  In that case I wanted to have Chinese food that wouldn't  be so American style.  We parked the van in a garage near Clay street, and as we were getting into the elevator, I ask a local man that was toting a large Chinese carry out bag if he could recommend a good one.  He said with no hesitations "Sam Wo"!    So we checked Yelp and saw that it was rated very good.  At first glance it looked like they might not be able to accommodate all eight of us, because it's narrow with kitchen on one side and dining on the other.  It reminds me of the many small restaurants in Manhattan.  Within minutes of inquiring if they could seat us, they had a table on the second floor.  
We were greeted  by a wonderful waiter, he was on point all night and interacted with our grandkids very well.
After exploring the menu I found some items I had never seen before.  So I had to try the Fish Jook, and I though it was very good.  My grandkids also tried some food that was off the normal American Chinese menu, and they loved it, Go Kids!  Out the door with two appetizers, drinks and tip for eight was about $80.  Not bad.
You know you can find the real deal, if the restaurant has been around over 100 years.
I'm sure there our other good restaurants in China Town that are as good, but if you don't want to drive around looking for a parking space, then Sam Wo is right across the street from the Public parking garage.
 BTW, you won't find General Tso's Chicken on the menu, because it's an American made up dish.
author: Doug B.

description: Sam Woo! Great food at a good price. The fish jook was awesome; good-sized pieces of fish with some ginger and green onion. The green beans with oyster sauce were cooked to perfection - not too crisp or too mushy OR oily! Duck dry mixed noodles were also very good - in fact, they tasted healthier than a chow mein... We'll worth the wait!
author: Ricardo L.

description:
Had dinner at this place tonight, and I have to give the host/I think owner and staff a big round of applause for the food and service tonight. I was leading a group of 12, and we didn't make a reservation (we weren't sure where we were going to eat). I called literally about 2 minutes before and asked if there was anyway to accomodate us, and they said they would make it work. 

We got there, and they had a large table set up for us in a cosy dining room upstairs above. One of our party asked if they could just bring us what they thought was best, and the host, in a lovely jolly christmas sweater said "not a problem."

We had a great meal of wonton soup, noodles, chicken, beef noodle, tofu and veggies, and it came out in record time. He explained what each dish was, and was diligent about making sure we all had our water glasses filled throughout the meal.

It was very good American Chinese cuisine, and they put up with us too. The best part, and probably most painful part for them, was spilling the total cost up 12 ways. And even though painful for the staff, the host joked with us about it, and took care of it with ease. 

I applaud, and deeply thank the Sam Wo staff for dealing with a big party, surprising us with great food, and a warm and welcoming service. Would recommend!
author: Mackenzie B.

description: The food was great and so was the staff.  We were there to take in the sites of San Francisco and found this spot. They had good ratings, so we thought it was safe.  Definitely a good choice.  We had a big group and the accommodated us quickly.
author: Julie D.

description: A little bit of the wait, remember to sign up when you enter (there's a little clipboard and pen). The iced milk tea is really good. And the service is relatively fast and friendly considering how many people come in. The atmosphere is small but cozy. Definitely would come again.
author: Reggie R.

description:
Loved the food. Servers were very helpful in choosing some dishes for my family. Had the bbq pork rolls, egg and beef rice, combination won ton soup, and family fun chow mein. All very good. 

Very clean and bright which is not the norm in Chinatown. 

Don't get the Chinese donuts unless you like a mouthful of grease with little taste.
author: David S.

description: Overrated...food looks good but taste average...some dish tastes too salty others too plain.
author: big c.

description:
Most importantly, the food was delicious, portions were plentiful, and service was polite and prompt.

This was your typical Chinatown, hole-in-the-wall, local restaurant. 

I saw that one review mentioned that not all the employees spoke English, which is a ridiculous statement because this is...C-H-I-N-A-T-O-W-N...many of the people that live here don't speak English so what would you expect.

If you want fancy or a typical Americanized oriental restaurant this is not for you....if you want a taste of Chinatown then give it a shot.
author: Michael L.

description: Classic Chinese fare. Small, intimate area and nice staff.
author: Ryan J.

description:
It's pretty good food and when you arrive late into San Fran -- it's a great stop. Having a place open for dinner at 10 pm was great. It totally hit the spot for a very late dinner!!!

I wasn't blow away by the flavour or styles of food. However, the staff was crazy friendly! Go here if you want a late night bite with great service.
author: Sam H.

description: Cheap and good restaurant. The fried chicken wings is fantastic. Crispy on the outside and juicy inside. The porridge is also very good.
author: Lum Kit L.

description: This place was so great! The wait wasn't too long, but it does fluctuate... When we were suited we placed our order and the food was fresh, fast to arrive and incredibly tasty! Would recommend!
author: Z B.

description: Came in for a quick bite of shrimp chow fun. Easy seating because we came in at an off hour on a Sunday. The dish came out pretty quickly, within 10 minutes of ordering, which was nice but also expected considering the few number of patrons currently in the restaurant. Deliciously greasy and at $10, not too bad. Granted that dish would be much cheaper at other Chinese restaurants, but the price comes with the more modern brand.
author: Jacqueline K.

description: Saw the 4 star review on yelp so decided to check it out.  Was seated pretty fast since it was late and the server was friendly. This definitely felt like a hole in the wall place. The waiter asked if I wanted water or tea, I said water and ordered a won ton mein. The food came pretty fast but wasn't 4 star quality or taste. The won tons were so overcooked the skins just fell off when I tried to grab them with my chopsticks. The noodles were ok (ie not overcooked) but the broth was pretty tasteless. Even after I added some chili paste and soy sauce, it still didn't taste right. Server never checked if my food was ok and I never saw the water I was offered. It's not like it was busy so not sure how everyone else thinks this place's food and service is so good. Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing and went at the wrong time.
author: Donny S.

description: Sam Wo was incredible. Went there for lunch on the recommendation of fellow Yelpers and was not disappointed. Truth be told, my trips to restaurants in San Francisco's Chinatown can be very hit or miss. Mostly miss for me. Chalk it up to my Western palate, but for whatever reason I've never been able to find a go-to spot. That is until today. Sam Wo is clean, friendly, and most importantly tasty! If you're in the area give it a shot. You will thank me for the rec.
author: Bryan W.

description:
Ahh...finally made it back there after so many yrs. we came after our ghost tour on a Saturday evening. It was about 9:30pm and the place was hopping. We put our name on the wait list by the wall and waited for about 15mins. It is a small place, like the old Sam Wo but it's only a one story building :-( oh, I so wish Edson, the mean waiter was still working there or just came around to joke with the patrons. 

The food, I must say is still just okay, not the best but it's the nostalgia that people come for. Sam Wo was the place my dad would seldom take us for Beef chow fun back in the 70's. This was a very special time for me since it was our shopping day...just dad and I. The fond memories of dad and I going there just the two of us is very clear in my mind. 

Tonite, I craved beef stew and Gai Lon over rice. My friends had their rice roll and another had soft scramble eggs with BBQ pork over rice. My dish came and the size is larger than what I expected. But for 10.00, it suffices the price to food ratio. However, my meat was luke warm. I just am a stickler for Luke warm food! And it had so much more tendon than I liked. Most people prefer the tendon but I wan neat!! It didn't have that much taste to me....had much better at Sun Kwong on Jackson/Hyde and $3.00 less. I tasted my friends scrambled egg rice dish and it was bland as well. The highlight are the rice rolls. I could eat two orders of those easily. 

But, I must say, the service is good. They are busy but do come around and make small talk or check on our water situation. The bathroom is a single unisex so the wait can be a challenge but at 10pm, it was clean, not smelly and well stocked of TP. (Rarity in Chinatown) oh, if you have a sever back problem, do not expect a chair with a back to lean on. The stools are from the old Sam Wo and tiny little stools they are! If you are a ladies size 16 and up, be careful...these still are not very sturdy. 

All in all, I will return for the rice roll and maybe the porridge. I think it is still cash only..maybe. But when in CT, do try Sam Wo for yourself.
author: Jessica L.

description: They have the best dry mixed noodles, I always go for the chicken dry noodles. There is always a line for to go or dine in, not the best choice if you are in hurry.
author: Tim C.

description: This place is strange. Apparently it was known for having the rudest waiters in the world, but the waiters and staff who served us were the nicest I've ever had! The dishes have pretty typical Chinese names, but they out looking distinctly not Chinese. I don't know how to describe it, but if you're used to Chinese food you'll know what I mean. Everything came out smelling pretty nice, but based on looks, I wasn't expecting much (not to say it was ugly, just not authentic). But man. Flavor overload. So unexpected. Prices are pretty damn good, service is good, and the food is really, really good. Plus the whole experience of eating here is confusing, which is something I like. Keeps you on your toes. Alerts you to the possibilities of the world. Nothing is how it seems. Would come back. oh yeah and it was one of the rare places in the area where you can get food after like 9pm on a Thursday (what's with this city??), so anyone looking for a late night dig, this won't disappoint
author: Cathy J.

description: Best Chinese Food Ever. Drove to this place one night from Santa Clara and it was well worth the trip. Hands down best chow mein. Service was great too!
author: Usman Q.

description: My favorite restaurant since 1973, used to come here after work or drink until it got suspended in 2012.very happy it has reborn.
author: Yin H.

description: Solid little hole in the wall.  We had chicken and broccoli over rice and beef and broccoli over rice.  Both were tasty and for $8.95 you get a huge portion.
author: Jay P.

description: I ordered the preserved vegetable and pork soup and instead I get a bowl full of noodles, very little vegetable and about 5 pieces of pork= definitely not what I was expecting! I asked if possible - can I get the beef stew instead and the manager wasn't having it. She didn't care about my concerns at all or about gaining another happy customer. They for sure have good food but what's up with the customer service :( I had to pay for a meal I didn't even eat!
author: Fatima M.

description: This place sucks. I got chicken wings, which smelled and looked real good, but when I bite into it, it was full of blood (wtf?) I should have asked them to re fry them but I was too hungry. Then I got the beef wonton soup, but the beef wasn't cooked well and a good amount of the meat was stuck between my teeth. I went home immediately after eating and flossed for a good 10 minutes. The wonton was also not very good - meat filling was pink on the inside, with no flavors
author: Roy C.

description: Cute little restaurant. There is a reason this place has been around so many years. The food is awesome. Everything we had was amazing BBQ pork fried rice, wonton soup, oyster beef and spring rolls.   The place was packed but the service was still great.
author: Lisa E.

description: I've never had fried rice as delicious as the chicken fried rice. The Chinese donuts (basically French bread that's fried in some concoction of deliciousness) were a great treat as well. The seating was a little tight but the service was friendly and the good was delicious and served quickly. We will definitely come back.
author: Derek G.

description: Nice seating, good service in Chinatown. Wonton noodles soup were meh, the congee was meh. The blanched vegetables were good. Opening hours were great though, so came by twice late in the night when nothing else was open.
author: Jeremy A.

description: We tried this place for the first time and both my husband and I weren't satisfied. The fried rice was super hard and dry, so thumbs down.. and our noodles were very oily and had a burnt taste to it. I actually had a really bad stomach ache after. Therefore, not going back!
author: marie l.

description: So far my favorite Singapore Rice Noodle dish in the Bay Area! Great balance of flavor and a reasonable quantity of protein compared to other nearby spots.
author: morgan p.

description: Rice rolls, noodle soups, fried rice, chow fun, what more can I ask for from a Chinese restaurant? Oh, and of course it's affordable! I usually order togo during lunch time. They're pretty quick with preparing the food. I don't think I've waited any longer than 5 minutes. The portions are pretty big. I normally get two meals out of it!
author: Lina C.

description: I came here with a friend and was slightly disappointed that the BBQ Pork Noodle Roll didn't have eggs in the roll like it use to.
author: Clarice L.

description: Food is delish! Authentic Dominican food, place is small, no booze, but so worth eating here!
author: Deedee O.

description: Food is just A-OK, as yelp suggests. Good that it's open late, which is why we visited... interesting history to this place, I guess...
author: Mingmei N.

description: Best noodles I've had if San Francisco in the last few years. Got the dry duck mixed noodles and the bbq pork rice noodle rolls for appetizer with their housemade spicy mustard... Fantastic stuff. And great prices. Coming back here soon!
author: David W.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurant to go to. They open up really late, perfect after work. I went there with my coworkers after work and got seated upstairs, which is perfect for groups.Their waitress and waitor, great customer services. My favoritie dish from there is their BBQ pork rice noodle roll. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Alice H.

description: Saw a vegetable beetle on my chopsuey!! I cancelled my order and is not happy about it!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Delicious. Came here with 5 people and sat upstairs in the small dinning area. We got a few different rice and noodle dishes. Everything was amazing. Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had, and it was incredibly fresh. The history here is equally impressive (this is a 100+ year old restaurant!). Plus the price is very affordable - every dish less than $10. Highly recommended!
author: Elliot K.

description: Not bad.  This evening was cold and windy and the delicious hot food was comforting.  My friend and I shared the spring rolls, green bean chicken, shrimp chow fun and pork fried rice.  Everything was a tad greasy but that is what makes it tasty.  I particularly liked the Shrimp Chow Fun and would return for this dish.
author: Donna P.

description: While visiting Chinatown we stopped by this little restaurant. They were very friendly inside. My mother is disabled and they were very accommodating. The food was good too. We tried the spring rolls, chicken wings and house fried rice. It was all flavorful. They brought out the food as it was fresh- so everything was hot.
author: Lillian Y.

description: This place exceeded my expectations. The food is good, especially for the price. The space is clean and comfortable and the service was exceptional. I will definitely return. I went on a Friday around 6:45 PM and was able to get a table right away but by the time I left there was quite a queue.
author: Yuxuan N.

description: cheap delicious chinese food. Also a plus is the fact that they close after bars close so you can satisfy your drunken munchies here. Even late at night, the service is great. The bbq pork rice rolls with their hot mustard sauce is what I'd come back for.
author: Derrick W.

description: This place is very small, the the service is quick and good. The food is tasty and fresh. Not to mention the cost of the entire meal for a party of 6 was purr of this world. Very inexpensive.
author: Stella S.

description: I've loved Sam Wo for the past 10 years now..  my love for the bbq pork rice noodles will never end.  Never.  Not ever.
author: Criselle O.

description: Since it was highly recommended on Yelp near our hotel, we checked it out. A clean place with friendly staff. The food was tasty, but not the best Chinese I've ever had. A bit disappointed for Chinatown. I was looking forward to trying the Chinese doughnut, but sadly they were out.  Be sure to order rice--for some reason that was an extra order.
author: R J.

description: What can you say about a hundred plus year old restaurant? The food was great and served fast and fresh. Prices were very reasonable. My best "hole in the wall" experience ever. We will make this a tradition for another 100 years!
author: Andrew B.

description: Enjoying the sights & locations of San Fransisco, my family & I entered into Korea town looking for food. Since there were so many to choose from, we used Yelp to help find a good place. We decided to come here since it had 4 stars. Plus it was late & the majority of the restaurants were closing or closed & this place was open until 3 am. This place is place small. Once seated & reviewed the menu, the waitress took our order & brought our food 20 minutes later. I got the mixed wonton soul, my daughter the beef stew, hubby the chicken fun something , and my son the sweet & sour chicken plus a side of Chinese donuts. Needless to say, we were disappointed. My soup tasted like water with chicken broth flavor. The dumplings were good but not enough BBQ pork or shrimp. There were at least 3 leaves of Bok choy plus I pulled out a piece of plastic from my mouth. I knew the te tire felt weird. I was done. Couldn't eat any more. My daughter's soup had no flavor what's so ever. I thought she was exaggerating so I tried it... nope.. it was bad.
