My son's sweet & sour chicken tasted like breaded pieces of chicken that were rolled in the sauce, the donuts were bland. The only good plate was my husband's food. That one had great flavor.  Looking at the tv screen waiting for my family to finish eating dinner, I saw this restaurant was featured in Connan O'Brians show ... I'm sorry but the hype for the restaurant from my personal experience & the plastic I pulled out of my mouth was not all it was cracked out to be. Service was great but not the food. I'm sorry.
author: O A.

description: Our new neighborhood spot!! Howard and the Sam Wo crew are fantastic! Inexpensive and absolutely delicious, we recommend the Duck eggs Jook every time!
author: Jovone W.

description: Diamond in rough! This is a fantastic place. Delicious food and off the charts customer service. Although it's a modest looking place, I rate it very high for those with family. I have a 1 year old, and he was made very comfortable and welcome here. I would recommend this place, blind-folded!
author: Ivan K.

description: The pork noodle rolls were my favorite thing!  The veggie chow mein and sesame chicken were also good.  The staff was super friendly and sweet!!
author: BB S.

description:
Friendly service, and really comfortable, homey atmosphere.

The food was good; I'd recommend choosing tea when you sit down, since it's pleasant and helps create the comfy atmosphere.
author: Drini C.

description: The place to be with anyone. You have never been to Chinatown, if you have never came here!!! One of the oldest restaurant in Chinatown and the food is really authentic!!!! Love this and would definitely come to this place again.
author: Waree R.

description: Singapore noodles are delicious as is the rice noodle roll. I crave both often.  The jook is filling, but lacks in flavor. Had to add a lot of seasoning to it.  Same goes for the wonton soup. Broth is bland and wonton filling has no flavor. I gave them 4 stars for my love for the Singapore noodles.
author: Chita P.

description: The food was delicious! I had the mixed vegetable chow fun with duck. My Aunt had the mixed vegetables over rice. My daughter had the chicken and broccoli over rice. The servings are big. If you have any lite eaters/children in your party they could share a dish.
author: Priscilla R.

description:
My last night in San Francisco...and I really wanted some Chinese...I trudged half a mile in the pouring and found this.."hole in the wall"! Walking in I was warmly greeted! Only a few small tables in a clean, updated "old school" style chinese restaurant. A pot of hot tea promptly showed up which was a nice welcome on the wet evening. 
The menu was simple, not too complex like many other Americanised places, with a symbol next to their house specials. I ordered the recommended Duck Noodle, and the Sesame Chicken. The duck noodles came first, I liked the noodles, it had a good texture, not too soggy. Several slices of braised duck with a generous heap of shredded lettuce sit atop the noodles in a braise sauce. It was good, for those that are familiar, think street style, simple, good, hot noodles. 
The sesame chicken was just what it says, just a little less sweet than your regular ones. The steamed rice that it was served with was very comforting. All in good price, comforting food. I didn't get to try many of the other recommended dishes, so I can't comment on the whole menu.
author: Kel Vin W.

description:
I'm Cantonese and this is some of the worst Cantonese food I've had.  The place was clean enough and we got seats right away.  

BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Roll: The noodles were super thick and bland.  The BBQ pork was ok.  The mustard sauce was decent.

Boat Jook: Super bland, no flavor.  

Duck fried rice: my friend had this dish.  I tried a small bowl, pretty bland and tasteless.
author: Spa E.

description: Let me start by saying that I am not giving Sam Wo 5 stars because I'm their friend. I never set foot there before, though my husband used to eat at the old one when he was a kid.  We started with an appetizer, bbq pork rice roll.  It was unlike any roll I've had at a Chinese restaurant--so delicious, not fried, and with a tiny bit of hot mustard on the side.  It was out of this world!  The chicken dry noodles were delicious and simple--noodles, shredded chicken, and strips of lettuce.  Very light, fresh, and did I mention it was "delicious"?  The other dishes we tried were the sweet n sour pork, sesame chicken, and broccoli w/oyster sauce (and of course steamed rice).  These were also very good and comparable to what you would find at other solid Chinese restaurants.  But because those first two dishes were spectacular, because the service was outstanding (though there was a small mistake in our order), and because the atmosphere was cheerful on New Year's Eve, Sam Wo gets 5 stars.  Also, I had coffee which usually I can't get at a Chinese restaurant.  Great place to eat in Chinatown!
author: Angie A.

description: Great low cost chinese food spot. Love the noodle dishes and soups. They don't deliver but I'll be ordering from this place through caviar.
author: John D.

description: The food was absolutely amazing! I got the wonton soup and the portion was good to share for 2. We also got the beef curry with rice, phenomenal! Highly recommend this place if you are craving good yet affordable Chinese food.
author: Roza M.

description:
been thinking about coming here since it opened long time ago but never got the chance. came today for lunch with a friend and thought, hmm, long narrow corridors  narrow stairs,  narrow long tables and stools   sort of like the old place.. so i thought hmm  maybe a great memory to come with the food, but was disappointed.

ordered a beef stew lo mein and was thinking it would be made with the traditional "shrimp noodles".. ..---ha jai mein, for those who know-- this is the 'standard' in 'quick' chinese ramen noodles..  something we all know from our fond memories of "siu yeh"....  but the noodles here were the white flour noodles and they were way over done... not al dente, not "springy" to the bite like hi jai mein, or wonton noodles...   and the beef stew had little brisket meat and more the  gelatinous tendon parts (not against that, but there should be meat too!)  and it came in a bowl and not a plate like "lo mein" usually is served.    not a favorite,  wont order it again.

we had a basic wonton soup and didnt find it very interesting.  the wontons did not have any distinctive taste or flavor and I couldn't tell if they had any shrimp in them, like many other places where the shrimp is found in chunks and not ground up with the pork.  

finally we ordered the rice rolls with bbq pork.  Now, if anyone remembers how these were in most dim sum shops in CT, made with glutinous rice flour and sprinkled with pieces of bbq pork, green onions, steamed and rolled up flat like a crepe, you'd remember them being light and not dense, savory and not sweet.  These were definitely not bringing back any happy memories.  These were dense and heavy (the rice roll themself) wrapped around pieces of bbq pork, cilantro, fried egg, like a sushi roll, and was seasoned  sweet/salty, emphasize the sweet!
i dont know if this is an attempt to be "fusion, contemporary, or what" but if this place was supposed to give us the opportunity to experience the ol sam wo, then it's iteration is all wrong.

Even the simplest chow mein Sam Wo used to have, simply seasoned with oyster sauce and green onions was light years better than what i had today.  

i'm sorry it didnt work.  would have liked to have brought up fond memories while eating..
author: dee c.

description: The only real purpose this place serves is late night eating after the bars/clubs. Mediocre food all the way around. Their popularity is based more on lore and chinatown nostalgia than present quality food. The Mongolian beef was barely edible - tough, chewy, and fat. Note to restaurant, please use decent quality flank steak. The jook with preserved egg and pork was pretty good though light on preserved egg and pork.  Service is quick and polite.
author: Eric C.

description: My wife and I decided to stroll through Chinatown while visiting San Francisco, and were immediately bombarded by unintelligible ladies and gentlemen.  They were passing out flyers and strongly encouraging us to eat at their restaurant, and stating that all the rest were "No Good".... In comes Yelp to help us decide our best option.  First, we checked the ratings of the advertised places, and found them to be very poorly reviewed.  So, we walked a few blocks over and went with the number 1 Yelp pick, Sam Wo Restaurant, and were not surprised to find it just as reviewed.  It was pretty busy, but had already planned on carry-out anyway.  The restaurant seemed very authentic and not any way similar to the tourist traps we saw on a Grant Street.  The prices were fair and the carry out order of Sesame Chicken was very good.  Sam Wo definitely lives up to its top rating on Yelp.
author: Darren C.

description: Just a great choice in Chinatown, love the history and ambiance of this landmark. Food was amazing and the  service was fantastic.
author: Kyle B.

description: This was such an amazing treat.  The food took me back to my childhood and dishes that I haven't had since my grandmother stopped cooking.  The BBQ pork rice noodle is an Asian fusion revelation.
author: Lis R.

description: A Hong Kong style street food restaurant. The price is inexpensive. The food is authentic. Like their pork and preserved eggs porridge, stir string bean, and BBQ pork noodle rol
author: Fang L.

description: The food is great. And the price is not high. It's a gem in Chinatown. I highly recommend this place.
author: Max G.

description: Love this place and so glad they've reopened. Best place to get late night Chinese food. The BBQ pork rice noodle roll is delicious and a must try!
author: Lisa A.

description: Great food. Big servings. We had the chicken curry with rice and the House Chow mein.
author: Catherine L.

description: Great food and even better service.  We had a really nice experience with the staff.  All the food was tasty and reasonable.  Love the salt and pepper chicken!
author: Grace M.

description: Small space with solid Chinese food. I really liked the BBQ pork rice noodle roll, sesame chicken, and the pea shoots with garlic! The duck chow fun was alright.  Servers were extremely friendly! Prices were good, especially for the portions.
author: Abby S.

description: I don't get it.  It's a very approachable place, friendlier than most traditional spots in Chinatown, but for us the food wasn't there.  We had the barbeque noodle, and that was OK, and a few other dishes.  I've had many great meals in Chinatown, but this wasn't one of them.
author: Mike W.

description: This place reminds me of the hole-in-the-wall kind of Cantonese Cafe in Guangzhou. Very nostalgic! I ordered the beef stew rice noodle. I won't say it is the best noodles I've ever had but it is absolutely authentic! The beef stew is so tender! I will definitely come back when I am in the area again
author: Danning X.

description: I am so happy they reopened!!! :) the food was just as good as I remembered from when I was a teenager.
author: Lauren T.

description: Ordered green beans with chicken and the house chow- mein DELICIOUS! Dishes are more ala carte style but they all taste good and you get plenty of food it's worth the price ,which is not that expensive average prices.  Bathrooms are clean and staff is friendly
author: L B.

description: Everything was excellent! The bbq rolls, the mongolian beef, the house beef chow mein(?), were amazing! Not salty, reasonable price, and their recommended dishes were good! The place was clean and the people were really friendly! Lots of veggies with the meat :)
author: Janice P.

description:
food: the bbq noodles. a very simple dish, but i love it. the noodles are soft, decent bbq pork. i love the combination of cilantro and everything. it brings it altogether in a tasty party for your mouth. ***4/5

service: they have a take out service now. i dont think they did before? the new location doenst have that run down feeling to it anymore. it was a charm it had. it managed to still have a dumb waiter system it seems. thats cool. i didnt stay in to eat. the service can be slow. it took a while before anybody acknowledge my existence and there were a few workers working the front. ***3/5

value: i think it's still cheap. this place brings nostalgia for me. it helps that food is still good. i always order the same thing here, but i really want to sit down and try the rest of the menu. ***4/5
author: Andy Z.

description: Tasty food (I had a super garlicky chicken chow mein), nice and fast service, bright and clean place. We'll come back for sure!
author: Katie D.

description: Ordered chicken and green beans to go, this is seriously the saltiest dish I have ever had! It felt like I'm eating salt directly! So bad!!! 2 bites and I'm done! Had to drink tons of water to make up for it. When I had bad food, I usually felt bad luck, but this kinda salty made me angry! OMG soooo bad!!!
author: Min G.

description:
I had been old Sam Wo restaurant way back in btw 1990 and early 2010 many times.  Today I went SF nearby to apply my passport.   After Done I walked to Chinatown tried grab some food to eat for late lunch. All the sudden, the memory of kitchen front and narrow staircase to upstairs came to me.   I remembered heard the news of reopened SamWo at TV and decided to find out where.   After asked few locals, finally I found the newly reopened restaurant.    But none of the employers inside was familiar to me. 
Anyway, I ordered the BBQ pork noodle roll.   Actually this is the first time I ordered this item. It was surprising me that the roll was very good.    It came out so quckly before I even wanted to change the order.    I was thinking it was like DimSum BBQ ChungFun, too soft skin. Actually it is not.    I like the noodle roll itself, thick enough, fresh and moisture.    It's was a little too much of 12 pieces for myself at one meal, but I finished all anyway.   I regret That before I never tried this item, but always ordered noodle soup or fried ChowFun.  Sounds like the price all goes up, but why not.   The living at SF is so expensive now.   I want to go back for this Noodle Roil as long as I am at that area.
author: Grace C.

description:
I LOVE this place. Especially the fried rice. I was a huge fan of their old location but it's definitely much more accessible and friendly the second time around. 

Still the same good food though.
author: Bella S.

description: Exactly what a neighborhood Chinese joint should be: fresh, homey Cantonese food at very reasonable prices and with quality a cut above everything in the same price range. Shrimp and scrambled eggs rice plate can be homey perfection (as it is here) or nearly inedible (as it is in too many other places).
author: Jane M.

description: I've heard so much about this restaurant, from friends, media, and all sorts of press. It did not disappoint me!! Food is fantastic, especially if you are looking for comfort food. Since it just newly opened, some staffs are still in training but picking up real quickly. I'm very satisfied overall. The line is always long during lunch hours, but it's worth it! The chow mein is delicious, and so is their signature porridge(jook). The BBQ Pork Rick rolls is awesome, and I suggest to also have the option of sweet soy sauce besides yellow mustard.
author: Fanny Z.

description:
Cheap, fast and good. As they say, pick two. It's cheap and fast and, well, good enough. Menu has the specialties designated to make for easy ordering. I approve of the pork rice rolls and duck dry noodle. Their special mustard is properly hot.

The max occupancy sign forms part of the ironic wall decoration upstairs.
author: Burger K.

description: Sam Wo? More like Sam Woaaaah blew my mind away! Delicious food and amazing customer service! I got the beef and broccoli and it came out very quickly, very happy with my experience here.
author: Laura R.

description: I have a weekly craving for the Signature Noodle Rolls and today I had it with the HK Milk Tea which was rich in flavor and potent! The way it's supposed to be. An excellent combination..
author: gordon g.

description:
We were visiting from Singapore. Had cravings for Chinese food. Decided to drop by Sam Wo, given its proximity and it's fabulous rating on Yelp. 

I have to say, the chefs needs to get back to Asia for a refresher course on how Asian food should taste like. 

The rice noodle roll were thick and it was served cold. 

The beef Fried rice noodle was close to tasteless, no wok hei at all. 

The porridge (jook) was tasteless and the consistency of the porridge looks amateurish. Definitely not a restaurant standard. 

The noodles were obviously over cooked and tasteless as well. 

There's some saving grace. Service is pretty good. Cheerful smile and all. Which is why I gave back a star.
author: Henry T.

description: BBQ pork rolls are still really great. Mixed noodle with duck was greasy, too much MSG,  and included two very, very small pieces of duck and a small piece of duck skin. Very disappointed with that. People who work there are nice and the service was very good.
author: B. L.

description: Amazing service and amazing food. We had the BBQ Noodle Roll, Duck Dried Noodle and Sesame Chicken and wish I had the capacity to try more! The guy with the pony tail is incredible and really knows quality client experience! Cannot wait to eat here again!
author: Lowyn Y.

description: 5 stars for the BBQ rice roll. I found it on Yelp and thought I have to try that. It's only 4.99 and you get oolong tea too. Also comes with a spicy mustard. I came back another day with husbands and we had it again! We also tried a curry pork noodle dish... It was eh!
author: Lydia H.

description: Loved it all! Awesome food, friendly and fast service (Howard you rock!) Will come back every time I come to SF.
author: Gina M.

description: The original Sam Wo,located in San Francisco's Chinatown was purportedly the oldest Chinese restaurant in the United States. It closed several years ago and I've missed it very much. It has been resurrected again in Chinatown of San Francisco. The new Sam Wo physically resembles the old one in many ways. It has an upstairs dining room. The old Sam Wo had, purportedly, the worlds rudest waiter. His name was Edsel Ford Fong- a surrealistic genius. The new Sam Wo has perhaps the worlds most pleasant and polite waiter. We went there last night and I enjoyed a plate of vegetable chow fun. It is open until 3 AM. It is funky, not as cheap as before, but what is?, And delicious. I am very glad that it has risen again like the Phoenix. Respect to Sam wo.
author: S. K.

description: It had been  over 10 years since I brought my kids to San Francisco and Sam Wo. Last time they were under 10. We were delighted to see that the tables and stools were retained but now in a bright, clean and modern setting. The service was friendly and welcoming. BBQ pork roll was delicious. The pork within was fresh and salty, a good mix with the cilantro and hot mustard.  Black beans gave extra dimension to the garlic braised green beans. Hot and still crunchy. Can't wait to come back for some jook.
author: Diane W.

description: Food is still as good as before. Just waiting for them to open the 2nd floor so there's more space for customers.
author: Francis C.

description: Sam Wo has been a favorite of my father's since before i was born, very glad to have it back. The BBQ pork fried rice and of course the BBQ pork rice noodle roll are very very good. Harold and Kenny provided awesome service also.
author: James T.

description: I'm very happy to see that Sam Wo's is back! The place is still a really comfy place and the food is simple yet delicious. I feel sorry for the staff on busy nights, because it gets hectic. We were sat down and waited 10 minutes for our menus. Now, if it were another place, I might have been a little irritated, but the people at Sam Wo's work hard and they do genuinely try to leave their customers satisfied. If you keep that in mind, go! You'll enjoy it!
author: Zachary D.

description:
Simply the best Cantonese breakfast/cafe restaurant in SF.

I had the best duck fried rice ever at Sam Wo. The pork with preserved egg jook tastes just like what mom makes at home. Wonton soup and Hong Kong style milk tea were both authentic and delicious. I can't wait to come back and try the other dishes!
author: Cindy L.

description:
One of the plainest Chinese restaurants I've been to in SF.  Certainly a tourist trap - the staff doesn't even speak Chinese.

Had 2 dishes, a chow fun and a curry chicken, both of which were very bland.  The milk tea was so extremely oversweetened, you could taste the individual sugar crystals.   All in all a poor experience and there are many better choices in Chinatown and around the city.
author: Josh Q.

description: Excellent hospitality and food is wonderful. Ambience is down home authentic though a little too small for my taste + no alcohol counts a star against. Regardless, if you're here, Go!
author: J. M.

description: Took a gang of Kids and Adults in to this place. They have an upstairs room that isn't visible. Skip the spring roles but everything else is spot on. My favorite was duck and fried rice, lots of duck in the dish and it was cooked perfect.beef and tomato chow Mein was like a Chinese spaghetti. The veggie chow main a must.
author: Jade E.

description: Excellent excellent food! Be sure to get the pork roll! The mustard is really spicey, so ease into it!
author: David E.

description: Came in with the family. Delicious food, great service in a family environment. Highly recommend the chicken fried rice!!! We had the chicken fried rice, Mongolian beef, sesame chicken, all delicious!
author: Norma K.

description: The ONLY reason I made this a 4 instead of a 5 was because of the drink options- no alcohol or fountain sodas. Otherwise, the food was AMAZING! We surprised them with a group of 9 of us and they sat us immediately and the food and service was very prompt. The food was amazing! We ordered Mongolian beef, kung pao chicken, chow mein, fried rice, the rice roll things, and spring rolls. All of the food was great. My favorite was the mongolian beef or the chow mein or the spring rolls. Shoot it was all good! Would definitely go back!
author: Cassandra S.

description:
Excellent value for the price. I had the BBQ noodle rolls (first item on the menu): fantastic! 
I will certainly go back next time I am in SF.
author: Gaby S.

description:
Hung Kee cross the street is better. 

We ordered beef brisket noodle and wonton soup. There is a hair in beef brisket, soup is very oily and noodle is not authentic. About the beef, it's all tendon and no brisket (meat). Also I agree with another review that wonton soup is very bland.
author: Eric W.

description: Wait is super long, my co-worker and I waited during prime Friday lunch hour for 30 minutes for a take-out meal, so please remember to order takeout instead by phone. Cash only. The servings portions are gigantic meant for 3 people. Very yummy cheap Chinese food at a historic hole-in-the-wall. The line is always very long, especially during weekday lunch hours.
author: Susan T.

description: I'm so excited that Sam Wo is back!  Not only is it back, but it's better than ever!  The new decor and ambience really bring out a classy retro-chic feeling that feels like much than just an upgrade of the old Sam Wo.  Same classic tastes, low prices, and late night snacking makes this place an A+++ recommend for me.
author: Henry Y.

description:
I am a very old time resident of SF went to original Sam Wo. Glad they reopened and we have not lost another piece of old SF.Clever they saved all the old marble tables, short stools, signs, give the old time feeling of former place.

We had the plain wonton, veg chow fun, curry chicken over riice, spring roll. All the food was very well done and perfect taste as it should be, down home cooking. Chow fun was especially good because they had the Wok heat flavor in it.

Will certainly go back again. Oh, nice flow of people and did not have to wait long to be seated.
Prices reasonable and portions nice.

Thank you Sam Wo for re-opening!
author: Charles W.

description: This place is excellent. The food is great, affordable and you will be served pretty quickly. The seating area is comfortable and looks/smells very clean. Everyone has been very polite while serving me.
author: Patrick M.

description: Congratulations for brand new Sam Wo , the place is clean the food is still the same . Service more much better now , but  I miss the rude grandma . My favorite is BBq pork rice noodle . U
author: tang c.

description: A minute walk from my place and I couldn't be happier. I got the chicken jook, and it was just what I needed. I've been missing home style hearty meals and Sam Wo will be seeing me more!
author: Eunice C.

description: Love coming here! I remember eating here when before it shut down temporarily, the food is great as usual. They have a second floor and their walls are filled with pictures of the old Sam Wo.
author: Michael V.

description: I don't know why it can't show Chinese character. It is terrible and I definitely won't come again. I mean the food is terribly bad
author: Henry T.

description: First visit to Chinatown and had the fortune to stop here for lunch. The BBQ beef noodle roll, duck chow fun and BBQ fried rice were wonderful, also very reasonably priced. Highly recommended!
author: Erin W.

description: Best Chinese restaurant in Chinatown! Service was great and I recommend the appetizer of the BBQ pork ! The wait was not too long even thought it was pretty packed. Too bad they don't have desserts and they can't serve alcohol but overall food is good and a great price!
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Food is good, good portions and good price. Just went to new location today and needed to check it out as we were Sam Wo regulars for years at the old place. Nothing fancy, no fortune cookies. Just good food at down to earth restaurant.
Had pork fried rice, BBQ pork wonton and vegetable chow fun. Took home the thick rice soup (jook) with fish. Excellent.
author: Greg K.

description: I appreciate the legacy of this place and that they could accommodate our large party upstairs but I found the food underwhelming. My family liked the pork rolls which seemed popular but my veggie dishes seemed to lack flavor. The veggies were fresh and the portions were generous however, I'll probably look for a new spot next time I'm in town.
author: Sistrsprkl S.

description: Uhm yummy yummy the chicken showmen and the chief wonton soup delicious .... This place the best China food in Chinatown
author: Fresia M.

description: Awesome, - quick, tasty, friendly, good! Had the house chow mei, absolutely delicious. The stir fried broccoli with garlic was crisp and very tasty.
author: Heidi W.

description: The good: the BBQ rice appetizer was outstanding. It's reasonably priced. The bad: The service is terrible. I ended up serving my entire party. It's so crowded it was uncomfortable. The person in back of me kept banging into me while I was eating. Wouldn't come back.
author: Peter B.

description: We came here upon a tour guides advice and especially because of the interesting and exciting history of the restaurant. Seating is cramped but for a quick small meal it will do. We had the pork rolls which were yummy! Also ordered chicken Kung pao (off the menu) and warm milk tea, both of which were just "meh." Glad we tried it out but aren't inspired to return.
author: Suzanne M.

description: Didn't disappoint. Great vibe and fantastic value. Went for lunch and lucky to get a table - it was very busy. Beautiful food.
author: John M.

description: We had two house specialities: house chow mein and shrimp and egg rice plate. Both were delicious and I can see why this place has been open for 100 years. Go! You won't regret it.
author: Haley K.

description: First time at Sam Wo. Food was excellent. My wife had the fish jook and she loved it. I had the recommended chow mein with shrimp, chicken, pork. It was very good. Also tried the recommended rice roll appetizer. I liked it. Staff was friendly. I would come back again. Other patrons were friendly. We are from The Villages in Florida.
author: John A.

description: My friend & I had a huge craving for Chinese food & upon reading the Yelp reviews for this place we decided to try Sam Wo out. Lemme tell you guys, they did NOT disappoint! I ordered the chicken chow mein & chicken fried rice, my friend got the broccoli beef with white rice & all three plates were delicious! The atmosphere was kind of meh, but we were in & it so quick it didn't even matter. When I'm back in town I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Mayerlin A.

description: Heh. Loved it. Feel like back in 70s, only not. All new all tasty. What lovely service. What original flavors, yeah, you should eat here.
author: Miguel L.

description: This place is really good for the price. It looks like a little hole in the wall from the outside, but is quite nice inside. It's a sit-down restaurant with very fast service. We got the wonton and beef soup, fried rice with duck, chow fun with shrimp, and chow mein with shrimp. All was enjoyed thoroughly. It's not fancy, but it's good!
author: Rachel S.

description:
The trademark of any Chinese mom is "I can make it (better)". So guess what my mom says after we have late lunch at the famous Sam Wo? My mom is a huge sucker for wonton soup and she's been to Yin Du and Hon's on Kearny was closed so here we are. The wait was 5 minutes. But there were 3 open tables as me and about 4 other people waited to be called. There is a wait list and as the waitress rattled off another five parties that were absent, it was clear that the place was understaffed. Another 5 minutes until we were waited on but afterwards the food came FAST. 

We decided on wonton soup with beef stew and a shrimp chow mein. The wontons were only pork with little crunchy bits of what I can assume are turnip or lettuce interspersed. There were 9 total. The broth was uninspiring and gave us forewarning as to how the beef would taste. It was colored very red from the bean curd it's traditionally cooked with but there was no indication of any flavor. Slippery and slightly tough, and neither salty nor savory, and also no turnips. Indeed, Mom was right. 

The chow mein though, wow. I normally scoff at ordering chow mein but the flavor was amazing. Now here is the salt and umami and sweetness the other dish is lacking. Garlicky, oniony, green oniony. It's also a very generous portion. That was the star. There, I could see why the name Sam Wo shines.
author: Rachel H.

description: Went there a few years ago and forgot about it, but it was one of the best Chinese places I've EVER been to.
author: Jason C.

description: This place is the bomb everything was delicious we were a party of 12. My spot when I  visit SF coming from the LBC
author: Joe A.

description: Chow mien and chow fun were equally amazing! The wait staff was pleasant and the atmosphere was authentic. We will definitely come here again, it was very clean too
author: Ti M.

description: Pleasantly surprised with this choice! Food was very good and inexpensive. We enjoyed our experience
author: Karen A.

description: Did not disappoint. Tip: share plates...the portions are huge! The chow mein and fried rice were both good. As well as the spring rolls. I'd pass on the wonton soup...it didn't have a lot of flavor.
author: Hope C.

description: This restaurant has an authentic feel while still being affordable with quick service. Every single one of us cleaned our plates and we're happy with our various selections, Kung pao chicken, sesame chicken, mixed fried rice, and beef with broccoli. For an affordable, quick meal this place can't be beat.
author: Sara K.

description: Great Chinese food place not bad for my 1st time being in the bay Howard was our waiter and I have to say his service and friendly attitude was far beyond expectations definitely will be coming back here when I'm out in this area :-)
author: Don M.

description: I went to Sam Wo on a whim while in San Francisco. I was in Chinatown and didn't have a clue as to where to eat. After a quick search on yelp, I found Sam Wo and decided to give them a try. So glad that we did. The place is small, but we were able to get a table upstairs right away. The service, food, portion sizes, and prices were all good. We had the beef chow fun and salt and pepper chicken.
author: Chon D.

description: The food was ok.  The service was so hap hazard.  The waiter was nice but not attentive at all. Ordered big house soup, house fried rice, SnS pork two beer and Waters all around.  Beers show up first. Then the big bowl of soup, but no bowls to share and only spoons for half of us?  After about five minutes finally get the waiter attention and ask for some mor spoons and the water.  Bowls show up, still no spoons.  Finally get his attention again, he brings the spoons still no water.  Ask again and finally get water.   SNSour Pork comes, and brings extra plates this time. it's ok, we finish and are wondering where's the fried rice?  After waiting another 5 or so minutes the other waitress looks over at me while she's about to go down the stairs and asks if we are waiting for another dish, I nod and she head down to the kitchen. A couple min later the waiter drops off the bill and says thanks for coming ? Yeah the rice is in the bill.  When he comes back he apologizes and asks if we still want the rice, we do, it's pretty good but not crazy good.  Maybe they were just having a bad night.  Bummer cuz they got a cool story, oldest restaurant and all, hope they pull it together.
author: Bill V.

description: their bbq noodle roll is just super yummy.  it wakes up all your tongues senses specially the sauce that goes with it.  definitely worth going back for.  price is very affordable.
author: Giselle G.

description: I really wanted to like this place because of all the hype that it has but it was really disappointing.  I ordered chicken and broccoli cause I thought you can't go wrong with that but the food had no flavor. The chicken was just boiled basically and the dish overall had no sauce and lacked a lot of the flavor that I love in Chinese cuisine. My husband got chicken fried rice and it was just ok. The only thing we like were the chicken wings.
author: ChrisNWill B.

description: HUGE portions, plenty to share. Mongolian beef (not on menu so ask for it) and fried rice was excellent.
author: Brent F.

description: This place has great food and friendly staff! It's also open late, which my husband and I took advantage of after a night out in North Beach. The sesame chicken and spring rolls were both delicious.
author: Cory P.

description: I have been eating here for years and I must say this place is great!!!! It is open late at night so if you're hungry and looking for a place to eat around midnight, then come here. It's good.
author: Richard L.

description: if you want to re-experience the dishes from the original Sam Wo, you can request a special order since most of the original dishes are no longer on the new menu. but only do it when they are not busy or they will yell at you! Duck roll, tomato beef chow mein, YUM!!!!.
author: Raymond L.

description: I've been to this place a handful of times and the food has always been wonderful. Yesterday on the other hand my mother was craving for some Sam Wo and she decided to not get our usual which is the BBQ lo mein and the BBQ noodle roll and instead got this spicy pork noodle dish. Don't get me wrong it was delicious, it wasn't until I got home about 6-7 hours later that I knew I had food poisoning. Not sure if it was maybe the pork that was so tender but possibly not cooked all the way but last night was a nightmare. I threw up every 20 mins ALL night. I'm really not trying to take anything away from this place since the food is so good but just a little heads up to the chef/owner so this doesn't happen again to me or another patron!
author: chyna b.

description: This place is awesome.  I was scared because it said that it was a bit of a tourist spot but decided to go anyways because the pics looked delicious.  We got there and there was a mix of locals and tourist.  We sat upstairs and was amazed only 1 person handling the whole second floor. But she was good. She handled all the tables like a champ and the food was so good and cheap too. You really cant go wrong here!
author: Danny F.

description: Came here for dinner and had delicious food and great service for around $10 - which isn't always easy to get in SF. It can be a little bit of a wait just because it is small, but it is well worth it. The staff is great and really kind for they were attentive in asking us if we need anything and were accommodating.
author: Allison N.

description:
Best Chinese food I've ever had! Literally everything we ordered was amazing! We had fried rice with pork, chow mein with chicken and bbq pork rice noodle and spring rolls. Seriously you have to come here!!

The food was so full of flavor! The guy behind me said he had been waiting for this for 4 years!
author: Chelsea M.

description: I came here to try their acclaimed BBQ pork roll but I thought  it was pretty average, it's just like any other Chinese rice roll with the only exception that theirs looks a bit prettier and is rolled. The BBQ was a bit dry and I was expecting more veggies, but there's actually only a couple sprigs of cilantro. Can't speak to anything else but the BBQ pork rolls are a bust.
author: Jenny W.

description:
This place is getting WORSE. I think the chef is getting LAZY, service attitude gets more UNPROFESSIONAL toward the end of each employee's shift, and the food orders are continuously wrong.

1. First, they put a lot of ginger slice in my duck jook, and I was later told they supposedly only do that for fish jook, then...

2. They deliver a salt-and-pepper fried chicken where the inside was COMPLETELY RAW AND BLOODY, once again they were highly unapologetic, no effort in compensation, and I was just later told issue was resolved...

3. Lastly was their UNPROFESSIONAL service attitude towards the end of their shift, I noticed one of their female employees became visibly "bitchy" to more than 1 tables with crude and unprofessional jokes.

I'm not sure if I'd want to come back or recommend this place to others to risk getting E. Coli from their uncooked raw food in the future, sigh...2 bad since they were cool for accepting all forms of credit cards
author: Keoini H.

description: I got the duck dry noodles and my girlfriend got the beef stew with wonton. I wish I could say the food was forgettable, but it wasn't... As soon as I got home, I had to throw up (seriously). That said, our waiter was probably one the friendliest and most gracious waiters that I've ever seen in Chinatown. I sincerely hope that the kitchen can rise to the level of the service. This is really @#$)(#$ ironic, since the original Sam Wo was famous for having the "world's rudest, worst, most insulting waiter"....
author: Da Wei S.

description: Food is delicious! A variance of options on the menu for such great entrees. Quick service and cute upstairs mezzanine for some privacy. Also complementary tea
author: Kassie L.

description: Awesome food, low key atmosphere, great cultural icon.
author: Douglas B.

description: a city treasure. great service and a reasonable price. the food is super yummy and they give you great portions.
author: Danielle C.

description: Have not been since 1993 when I lived in SF and it was a regular spot. Was in town and happy to see it was back. Scrambled eggs and beef over rice just like the old days. Fried rice was good. My son loved the sweet and sour pork. Really awesome that I don't have to bring my own beer like we used to.
author: Doug H.

description: Probably some of the best I've ever had. The service was exceptionally friendly and the food was absolutely delicious. A great find to stumble upon.
author: Sam L.

description: Great food and fast service. Don't be scare by the look of it. You will be surprised by the flavor of the food!
author: Andres R.

description: Yummy, open late, soul food Chinese restaurant that is steeped in tradition! The oldest Chinese restaurant in SF!
author: Kara S.

description: this is old world chinese. opened in 1912. you can feel the history in the place. reasonable menu, fast service, and good pricing. can't ask for more.
author: Gary O.

description: I've been coming to this place since I was a baby.  My grandma would take me to their old location on Washington...you know that old turquoise building that isn't a building at all, just a narrow alley between 2 buildings turned into a restaurant.  They have since left, rebranded and reopened on Clay.  So glad they are still here going strong.The Wonton Noodle Soup (with long noodles, mind you) is a very nostalgic thing for me.  And in my opinion you have no business eating here if you don't also order the BBQ Pork Rice Noodle Rolls.  I would live in a Chinese Take-Out container of these if I could.  There is a surly young woman who works the till here in the afternoon/evenings, but the staff don't seem to like her either so...I guess it's fine.  The family members and friends who run this place are lovely.  So glad to be back in SF and giving them my business, not that they need it.  They are always so busy :-)
author: Adrian C.

description: Horrible service, small portions, no waters. I wish we could give them 0 stars. Everything was always out. The entrees were served on a 6 in salad plate. Waited 50 minutes for 1 entree. Would never go again. Ever.
author: Michael C.

description: They were great about making the good onion and garlic free. It was all fresh. The chow me in and sesame chicken were delicious but I didn't like the taste of the need and broccoli. It tastes a bit lemony and undercooked. Great service and crowd.
author: Mmm M.

description: B.B.Q. Pork Dry Mixed Noodle was excellent.  $8 for a bowl full of delicious noodles that were slurp-a-licious!  Super-friendly staff in a very relaxed, fun place.  Great little hole-in-the wall.
author: Faba M.

description: The closest thing I've had to east coast chinese food. It wasn't good but not great. Definitely a language barrier. Small little spot with an interesting layout. It did the job for late night quick finds.
author: Ray A.

description: Awesome!!!  Only down side is the place is not big enough to sit al the people trying to get in. Good food, fast friendly service, fair price. So get here early and enjoy.
author: George E.

description: They are located on clay between grant and Kearny in Chinatown. I put in an order of their Bbq pork roll, duck chow mein and their milk tea to go and everything was delicious. I went in on a Friday night and it was pretty packed. It's still a little small and cramped, but it definitely looks a whole lot cleaner!
author: Amy C.

description: So good!!!  I loved their Chicken with String Beans.  So yummy!  Would recommend this for Chinese food lovers.
author: Adrienne W.

description: the food isn't really that good, but okay at best.  We ordered the wonton noodle soup which is much worse than many nearby places I've tried.    I also ordered the Chinese broccoli which was much too greasy and salty.     There are lots of better Chinese restaurants in the area.   I've been there three times this year.   The very last one was with my son.   We both thought we would not return.
author: Doris A.

description: super nice staff, super yummy food, super cheap :)Foof wasn't oily or over flavored.
author: Li S.

description: This place is delicious and inexpensive! The service was fast and friendly. I ordered the BBQ pork wonton soup and highly recommend.
author: Kim S.

description: We ordered the duck fried rice, beef jook and the combo wonton soup and it was awsome for a great price. (Under $10)service was incredible and really nice. 10/10 would come again.
author: Hea Seung K.

description: Called ahead for a 11:30 am reservation.  Arrived at 11:25 am.  Hostess told us to go upstairs.   Dined with 4 friends.  We ordered the tomato beef noodles, the dry duck noodles which came with a side of light soup,   the fish porridge,  mo po tofu with rice,  bbq  pork rice roll,  Chinese broccoli , and Chinese donut.  Food arrived within 5 to 8 minutes.  Quite fast.  Tea was refilled.  This is my 3rd trip to this restaurant.  Good service and yummy no nonsense food.
author: E. C.

description: Came here for my friend's birthday dinner and thought the food was excellent! The wonton soup, fried rice, and mapo tofu were the standouts for me. Excellent staff and service. I will be returning!
author: Susan K.

description: "The San Francisco of my youth no longer exist," said Herb Caen. This statement applies to the new location of Sam Wo. I went there often in the 1950's when Edsel was at the top of his game. I went after church, after bar-hopping and for nice warm jook.  I finally had the opportunity to visit on Monday the 2nd. I liked that they kept similar tables and stools. I ordered the bbq pork chow mein and pork/preserved egg jook with an order of fried doughnut. The chow mein was mediocre, more like lo mein. On the wet side, not fried crispy. Back in the day, the cooks made their chow mein with a very unique flavor that I could get ONLY at Sam Wo. The jook was also OK and you could get this anywhere. The fried  'ghost' was good. I will not return.
author: Gerry P.

description: Woohoo is right, wow what a nice surprise while I work on a Sunday afternoon.  I walked in and was pleasantly greeted by a friendly server behind the counter.  Although this is an eat-in restaurant which is very quaint I was placing an order to go.  The server recommended a few dishes and I figured I would order a few things to eat for dinner as well.  Since patience is not a virtue of mine I began to try the egg roll on my way back to the office...they were perfectly fried, crunchy not creasy...delicious.  I then tried their signature BBQ Pork Rice Noodles and let's just say that they did not make it back to office and it was only a few blocks away.  Although I was relatively full I did want to try the duck fried rice and it truly did not disappoint, YUM!
author: Anna P.

description: Sam Wo has reopened on Clay Street. Things has gotten a bit more pricey than before but it is still cheap compared to other places in the city. You can only get B.B.Q pork noodle roll at Sam Wo ... nowhere else.  Another dish that I really like is Dry Duck Mixed noodle... Delicious!!  The owner's daughter, Julie, has exceptional great services.  Sam Wo opens till 12am so it is a great place to hang out.
author: Evelyn W.

description: Unlike most chinatown spots, the waiter here was extremely warm, friendly and attentive despite it being very busy. Beat service i have ever had in Chinatown.  Really liked how much cleaner the new restaurant is. Great lighting too compared to the old spot.
author: S L.

description: I went there after reading so many positive reviews, and I normally don't give bad reviews, but this food was not good. I got Chow Main with Tomato and Beef and it turned out to be very sweet. It is full of tomato paste. Tastes like SpagettiOs from the can. There is very little beef and what is there is very chewy. It does not look at all as pictured on there website. Will not go there again!
author: Nozima T.

description: Oh man. I hadn't been here in years. I heard they closed and recently they reopened after renovations (not sure when that happened...). It's so tasty. The chow mein was perfection and wonton soup was delicious. The prices are still totally affordable. Such a good meal!!!
author: Rachel N.

description: My family & I we're regular customers at the former Washington Street location and always ordered their beef & greens chow mein. After they moved to their new location on Clay Street we noticed that they no longer use the same chow mein noodles & seem to have also changed the recipe & possibly a new cook. Very disappointing and unfortunately I'm no longer a regular customer.
author: Marcia G.

description: Great,great service. The staff is so nice and makes your experience so much more enjoyable. Something that is hard to find in Chinatown. The food was great as well. Don't miss out on their famous steamed pork rolls as appetizer! The place is small but an authentic shop and super cozy.
author: Srinath A.

description: Nothing fancy but the food was good and the portions were generous.
author: Michael M.

description: visited for dinner with a few friends , they were all very impressed . The BBQ pork rolls are off the hook!
author: Emilio C.

description: Got off the plane from Honolulu late and starving, took my son over to Sam Wo's for some noodles. My first time at the new location. Excellent. This is the food you will get at your friends' grandma's house. Simple and good. Old-school Chinese-American food, Cantonese cuisine. No pan-Asian fuss. Howard was running the joint with wit, skill and kindness. Thank you for a great meal in a great city.
author: Old N.

description: This place is AMAZING!!!! The BBQ Pork spring rolls were delicious. Best I've ever had. The chow mein was simple, yet very rich in flavor and non greasy whatsoever. The Hong Kong Tea was my favorite however. It's their own blend of teas and carnation milk. The staff were super friendly and very attentive. Will definitely be coming back when I return to San Francisco.
author: Marcos H.

description: Went to try out Sam Wo for the first time since it is re-open at a new location. The waiters and waitresses are friendly but a bit disorganized. Our order was wrong, waited a while to get the correct one,  then the white rice came when we finished eating! The dishes were definitely not traditonal Chinese. Portion sizes were small, favor and style of cooking were mismatched with the publicity and rating. Noodle was overcooked ramen, not the tradional fine noodle. What a disappointment!
author: lucia j.

description: Had beef with broccoli, veggie chow mein, and combination wonton. It was all delicious, fresh tasting, and the service was great.
author: Benny C.

description: Small, cozy place in China Town with polite staff and large portions. We were not wowed by the food, but it was good and quite filling.
author: Jack R.

description: Excellent lunch spot.  We had wonton soup that we split (a large bowl), the fried spring rolls, beef with greens stir fried noodles & duck fried rice.  All very tasty & complimenting.  Great & very friendly service - would return to try other items!
author: Eileen B.
